{"tularemianum_articles": "250", "tularemia": [{"archive_id": "7757997", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Ukraine: (KS) hare, 1st rep, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7757997", "date": "2019-09-06 12:46:15", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SWEDEN (05): SOURCES OF INFECTION\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 6 Sep 2019\nSource: Rikard Dryselius <rikard.dryselius@folkhalsomyndigheten.se> [edited]\n\n\n[re: ProMED-mail Tularemia - Sweden (04): further increase, RFI 20190905.6659382]\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nAccording to clinical reports, a majority (over 70%) of the reported cases during the ongoing outbreak of tularemia in Sweden appear to have contracted the infection through insect bites, mainly mosquito bites. For about 1/4 of the disease cases no path of infection is indicated, while mainly animal contact and in some cases drinking water is indicated as route of infection for the remaining cases.\n\n--\nRikard Dryselius\nFolkh\u00e4lsomyndigheten\n<rikard.dryselius@folkhalsomyndigheten.se>\n\n[ProMED thanks Rikard Dryselius for this clinical information. - SPAIN: (CASTILE AND LEON)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 6 Aug 2019\nSource: Cope [in Spanish, machine trans. edited]\nhttps://www.cope.es/emisoras/castilla-y-leon/palencia-provincia/palencia/noticias/ascienden-los-casos-confirmados-tularemia-palencia-20190806_474318\n\n\nThe leaders of Castile and Leon, through its territorial delegation in Palencia, has confirmed that as of yesterday, 5 Aug 2019, there are already 16 cases of tularemia in the province. There are 29 other probable cases that are under study.\n\nAccording to the last part issued from the regional administration, the detection of 3 other cases in Paredes de Nava is underway. Two cases that have been detected have occurred in the area of Palencia Rural and Saldana. In all of them it is stated that tularemia is due to environmental exposure, and none of them have required hospitalization.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of tularemia in these cases are not stated.\n\nVoles (http://www.voles.com/) are likely to be the reservoir here. They are often called meadow mice, or field mice, and occupy a wide variety of habitats, depending on the species. Generally, voles prefer areas with heavy ground cover of grasses, grass-like plants, or litter. They are active both day and night and throughout the year. Voles eat a variety of plants and animals. They frequently forage on grasses, forbs, roots, bulbs, tubers, bark, snails, and insects. To find food, voles construct tunnels and surface runways with many burrow openings. Several adults and young can live in these runway systems. This intricate network of tunnels and burrows provides voles with excellent shelter from the weather and protection from predators. Voles store seeds and other plant matter in underground chambers. A picture of a vole can be found at http://news-service.stanford.edu/news/2004/september22/gifs/Yellowstone_vole.jpg.\n\nPalencia is a province of northern Spain, in the northern part of the autonomous community of Castile and Leon in the northwest of the Iberian Peninsula. It is bordered by the provinces of Leon, Cantabria, Burgos, and Valladolid. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nPalencia, Castille and Le\u00f3n, Spain: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16299]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nTularemia - Spain: crayfish exposure 20140815.2684689\n2008\n----\nTularemia - Spain: (northern) 2007 20080815.2538\n2007\n----\nTularemia - Spain (03): (northern) 20071108.3626\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02) 20070813.2646\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir 20070811.2615\n1998\n----\nTularemia, human - Spain (02), Europe 19981003.1967\nTularemia, human, aquatic source? Generally, voles prefer areas with heavy ground cover of grasses, grass-like plants, or litter. They are active both day and night and throughout the year. Voles eat a variety of plants and animals. They frequently forage on grasses, forbs, roots, bulbs, tubers, bark, snails, and insects. To find food, voles construct tunnels and surface runways with many burrow openings. Generally, voles prefer areas with heavy ground cover of grasses, grass-like plants, or litter. They are active both day and night and throughout the year. Voles eat a variety of plants and animals. They frequently forage on grasses, forbs, roots, bulbs, tubers, bark, snails, and insects. To find food, voles construct tunnels and surface runways with many burrow openings. There are 29 other probable cases that are under study.\n\nAccording to the last part issued from the regional administration, the detection of 3 other cases in Paredes de Nava is underway. Two cases that have been detected have occurred in the area of Palencia Rural and Saldana. In all of them it is stated that tularemia is due to environmental exposure, and none of them have required hospitalization.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of tularemia in these cases are not stated.\n\nVoles (http://www.voles.com/) are likely to be the reservoir here. They are often called meadow mice, or field mice, and occupy a wide variety of habitats, depending on the species. Generally, voles prefer areas with heavy ground cover of grasses, grass-like plants, or litter. They are active both day and night and throughout the year. Voles eat a variety of plants and animals. They frequently forage on grasses, forbs, roots, bulbs, tubers, bark, snails, and insects. To find food, voles construct tunnels and surface runways with many burrow openings. Several adults and young can live in these runway systems. This intricate network of tunnels and burrows provides voles with excellent shelter from the weather and protection from predators. Voles store seeds and other plant matter in underground chambers. A picture of a vole can be found at http://news-service.stanford.edu/news/2004/september22/gifs/Yellowstone_vole.jpg.\n\nPalencia is a province of northern Spain, in the northern part of the autonomous community of Castile and Leon in the northwest of the Iberian Peninsula. It is bordered by the provinces of Leon, Cantabria, Burgos, and Valladolid. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nPalencia, Castille and Le\u00f3n, Spain: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16299]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nTularemia - Spain: crayfish exposure 20140815.2684689\n2008\n----\nTularemia - Spain: (northern) 2007 20080815.2538\n2007\n----\nTularemia - Spain (03): (northern) 20071108.3626\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02) 20070813.2646\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir 20070811.2615\n1998\n----\nTularemia, human - Spain (02), Europe 19981003.1967\nTularemia, human, aquatic source? - Spain (Cuenca )(02) 19980923.1904\nTularemia, human, aquatic source? - Spain (Cuenca) 19980921.1888\nTularemia, human - Spain 19980123.0170\n.................................................sb/ll/msp/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Valladolid", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Palencia Rural", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burgos", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Le\u00f3n", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cantabria", "country": "Spain"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6611184", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Spain: (CL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6611184", "date": "2019-08-07 18:08:09", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SPAIN: (CASTILE AND LEON)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 6 Aug 2019\nSource: Cope [in Spanish, machine trans. edited]\nhttps://www.cope.es/emisoras/castilla-y-leon/palencia-provincia/palencia/noticias/ascienden-los-casos-confirmados-tularemia-palencia-20190806_474318\n\n\nThe leaders of Castile and Leon, through its territorial delegation in Palencia, has confirmed that as of yesterday, 5 Aug 2019, there are already 16 cases of tularemia in the province. There are 29 other probable cases that are under study.\n\nAccording to the last part issued from the regional administration, the detection of 3 other cases in Paredes de Nava is underway. Two cases that have been detected have occurred in the area of Palencia Rural and Saldana. In all of them it is stated that tularemia is due to environmental exposure, and none of them have required hospitalization.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of tularemia in these cases are not stated.\n\nVoles (http://www.voles.com/) are likely to be the reservoir here. They are often called meadow mice, or field mice, and occupy a wide variety of habitats, depending on the species. Generally, voles prefer areas with heavy ground cover of grasses, grass-like plants, or litter. They are active both day and night and throughout the year. Voles eat a variety of plants and animals. They frequently forage on grasses, forbs, roots, bulbs, tubers, bark, snails, and insects. To find food, voles construct tunnels and surface runways with many burrow openings. Several adults and young can live in these runway systems. This intricate network of tunnels and burrows provides voles with excellent shelter from the weather and protection from predators. Voles store seeds and other plant matter in underground chambers. A picture of a vole can be found at http://news-service.stanford.edu/news/2004/september22/gifs/Yellowstone_vole.jpg.\n\nPalencia is a province of northern Spain, in the northern part of the autonomous community of Castile and Leon in the northwest of the Iberian Peninsula. It is bordered by the provinces of Leon, Cantabria, Burgos, and Valladolid. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nPalencia, Castille and Le\u00f3n, Spain: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16299]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nTularemia - Spain: crayfish exposure 20140815.2684689\n2008\n----\nTularemia - Spain: (northern) 2007 20080815.2538\n2007\n----\nTularemia - Spain (03): (northern) 20071108.3626\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02) 20070813.2646\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir 20070811.2615\n1998\n----\nTularemia, human - Spain (02), Europe 19981003.1967\nTularemia, human, aquatic source? - Spain (Cuenca )(02) 19980923.1904\nTularemia, human, aquatic source? - Spain (Cuenca) 19980921.1888\nTularemia, human - Spain 19980123.0170\n.................................................sb/ll/msp/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Valladolid", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Palencia Rural", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burgos", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Le\u00f3n", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cantabria", "country": "Spain"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6497308", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA: (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6497308", "date": "2018-07-12 21:56:52", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (05): (COLORADO) PNEUMONIA\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 11 Jul 2018\nSource: Times Call [edited]\nhttp://www.timescall.com/top-stories/ci_32001943/larimer-county-confirms-human-tularemia-case\n\n\nA Larimer County, [Colorado], resident has been confirmed as having the 1st human case of tularemia this season and is believed to have been exposed while gardening at home, according to the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment. The resident developed a lung infection from tularemia, which can be transmitted to people through insect bites, contaminated soil, or contact with an infected animal, according to a press release from the health department.\n\nAll warm-blooded animals, including pets and livestock, are susceptible to tularemia, though the bacterium normally occurs in rabbits, hares, muskrats, beaver, and small rodents. The bacterium that causes tularemia is in the urine and droppings of sick animals, contaminating the soil through that means. When a person turns up soil while gardening, mowing, or even blowing leaves, the bacteria can be inhaled, causing a pneumonic form of tularemia, the department stated.\n\nThe organism also can be transferred through contaminated food and water or even by putting hands to eyes, nose, or mouth after outdoor activities. Other ways to contract tularemia are through insect bites and by handling dead animals, according to a news release. Bacteria in animals can persist in soil or water for weeks, and it takes only a small amount to cause a transmission.\n\nByline: Pamela Johnson\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (in the laboratory or via an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _D. variabilis_ (dog tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe infection does not spread from person to person, essentially in contradiction to another category A bioterrorism agent, _Yersinia pestis_, in which the pneumonic form can easily be transmitted.\n\n_F. tularensis_ infection can present in a variety of ways depending on the route of acquisition. Even before the antimicrobial era, pneumonia due to inhalation of _F. tularensis_ seemed to account for most of the deaths related to the infection (1). A good review of the subject written by Thomas and Schaffner can be found in reference 2.\n\nCitations\n----------\n1. Foshay L. Cause of death in tularemia. Arch Intern Med. 1937; 60(1): 22-38. doi:10.1001/archinte.1937.00180010025002; abstract available at https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/article-abstract/542763.\n2. Thomas LD, Schaffner W. Tularemia pneumonia. Infect Dis N Am. 2010; 24(1): 43-55. doi: 10.1016/j.idc.2009.10.012; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20171544.\n\nLarimer County is located in the north central part of the state and can be seen on a map at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larimer_County,_Colorado. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nLarimer County, Colorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1298]\nSee Also\nTularemia - USA (04): (IL) wild rabbit, human 20180621.5866489\nTularemia - USA (10): (CO, SD) 20150801.3548673\nTularemia - USA (05): (AK) susp. 20150702.3480207\nTularemia - USA: (CO) 20150522.3379806\n.................................................sb/ll/tw/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6152385", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (10): (CO, SD) 20150801.3548673\nTularemia - USA (05): (AK) susp. 20150702.3480207\nTularemia - USA: (CO) 20150522.3379806\n.................................................sb/ll/tw/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6016232", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (08): (MA) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6016232", "date": "2018-07-12 21:56:52", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (05): (COLORADO) PNEUMONIA\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 11 Jul 2018\nSource: Times Call [edited]\nhttp://www.timescall.com/top-stories/ci_32001943/larimer-county-confirms-human-tularemia-case\n\n\nA Larimer County, [Colorado], resident has been confirmed as having the 1st human case of tularemia this season and is believed to have been exposed while gardening at home, according to the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment. The resident developed a lung infection from tularemia, which can be transmitted to people through insect bites, contaminated soil, or contact with an infected animal, according to a press release from the health department.\n\nAll warm-blooded animals, including pets and livestock, are susceptible to tularemia, though the bacterium normally occurs in rabbits, hares, muskrats, beaver, and small rodents. The bacterium that causes tularemia is in the urine and droppings of sick animals, contaminating the soil through that means. When a person turns up soil while gardening, mowing, or even blowing leaves, the bacteria can be inhaled, causing a pneumonic form of tularemia, the department stated.\n\nThe organism also can be transferred through contaminated food and water or even by putting hands to eyes, nose, or mouth after outdoor activities. Other ways to contract tularemia are through insect bites and by handling dead animals, according to a news release. Bacteria in animals can persist in soil or water for weeks, and it takes only a small amount to cause a transmission.\n\nByline: Pamela Johnson\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (in the laboratory or via an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _D. variabilis_ (dog tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe infection does not spread from person to person, essentially in contradiction to another category A bioterrorism agent, _Yersinia pestis_, in which the pneumonic form can easily be transmitted.\n\n_F. tularensis_ infection can present in a variety of ways depending on the route of acquisition. Even before the antimicrobial era, pneumonia due to inhalation of _F. tularensis_ seemed to account for most of the deaths related to the infection (1). A good review of the subject written by Thomas and Schaffner can be found in reference 2.\n\nCitations\n----------\n1. Foshay L. Cause of death in tularemia. Arch Intern Med. 1937; 60(1): 22-38. doi:10.1001/archinte.1937.00180010025002; abstract available at https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/article-abstract/542763.\n2. Thomas LD, Schaffner W. Tularemia pneumonia. Infect Dis N Am. 2010; 24(1): 43-55. doi: 10.1016/j.idc.2009.10.012; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20171544.\n\nLarimer County is located in the north central part of the state and can be seen on a map at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larimer_County,_Colorado. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nLarimer County, Colorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1298]\nSee Also\nTularemia - USA (04): (IL) wild rabbit, human 20180621.5866489\nTularemia - USA (08): (AZ) human, fatal, canine, 2016 20170824.5272785\nTularemia - USA (07): (AK) snowshoe hares 20170819.5260441\nTularemia - USA (06): (CO) wild rabbit 20170623.5127076\nTularemia - USA (05): (MN) feline exposure 20170611.5098241\nTularemia - USA (10): (CO, SD) 20150801.3548673\nTularemia - USA (05): (AK) susp. 20150702.3480207\nTularemia - USA: (CO) 20150522.3379806\n.................................................sb/ll/tw/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5945049", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (07): (CO, OR) beaver, marmot, corr", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5945049", "date": "2018-07-12 21:56:52", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (05): (COLORADO) PNEUMONIA\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 11 Jul 2018\nSource: Times Call [edited]\nhttp://www.timescall.com/top-stories/ci_32001943/larimer-county-confirms-human-tularemia-case\n\n\nA Larimer County, [Colorado], resident has been confirmed as having the 1st human case of tularemia this season and is believed to have been exposed while gardening at home, according to the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment. The resident developed a lung infection from tularemia, which can be transmitted to people through insect bites, contaminated soil, or contact with an infected animal, according to a press release from the health department.\n\nAll warm-blooded animals, including pets and livestock, are susceptible to tularemia, though the bacterium normally occurs in rabbits, hares, muskrats, beaver, and small rodents. The bacterium that causes tularemia is in the urine and droppings of sick animals, contaminating the soil through that means. When a person turns up soil while gardening, mowing, or even blowing leaves, the bacteria can be inhaled, causing a pneumonic form of tularemia, the department stated.\n\nThe organism also can be transferred through contaminated food and water or even by putting hands to eyes, nose, or mouth after outdoor activities. Other ways to contract tularemia are through insect bites and by handling dead animals, according to a news release. Bacteria in animals can persist in soil or water for weeks, and it takes only a small amount to cause a transmission.\n\nByline: Pamela Johnson\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _D. variabilis_ (dog tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe infection does not spread from person to person, essentially in contradiction to another category A bioterrorism agent, _Yersinia pestis_, in which the pneumonic form can easily be transmitted.\n\n_F. tularensis_ infection can present in a variety of ways depending on the route of acquisition. Even before the antimicrobial era, pneumonia due to inhalation of _F. tularensis_ seemed to account for most of the deaths related to the infection (1). USA (04): (CO) wild rabbit 20170505.5016005\nTularemia - USA (02): (CO) wild rabbit 20170423.4988936\n2016\n----\nTularemia - USA (15): (CO) human, wildlife 20161102.4602736\nTularemia - USA (10): (WY) 20160807.4396768\nTularemia - USA (05): (AZ) fatal 20160708.4333270\nPlague, tularemia - USA (NM) alert 20160615.4289092\nTularemia - USA: (MN, AK) feline, canine, lagomorph 20160529.4252246\n2015\n----\nTularemia - USA (18) 20151205.3842058\nTularemia - USA (10): (CO, SD) 20150801.3548673\nTularemia - USA (05): (AK) susp. 20150702.3480207\nTularemia - USA: (CO) 20150522.3379806\n.................................................sb/ll/tw/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5902451", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (05): (CO) pneumonia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5902451", "date": "2018-07-12 21:56:52", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (05): (COLORADO) PNEUMONIA\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 11 Jul 2018\nSource: Times Call [edited]\nhttp://www.timescall.com/top-stories/ci_32001943/larimer-county-confirms-human-tularemia-case\n\n\nA Larimer County, [Colorado], resident has been confirmed as having the 1st human case of tularemia this season and is believed to have been exposed while gardening at home, according to the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment. The resident developed a lung infection from tularemia, which can be transmitted to people through insect bites, contaminated soil, or contact with an infected animal, according to a press release from the health department.\n\nAll warm-blooded animals, including pets and livestock, are susceptible to tularemia, though the bacterium normally occurs in rabbits, hares, muskrats, beaver, and small rodents. The bacterium that causes tularemia is in the urine and droppings of sick animals, contaminating the soil through that means. When a person turns up soil while gardening, mowing, or even blowing leaves, the bacteria can be inhaled, causing a pneumonic form of tularemia, the department stated.\n\nThe organism also can be transferred through contaminated food and water or even by putting hands to eyes, nose, or mouth after outdoor activities. Other ways to contract tularemia are through insect bites and by handling dead animals, according to a news release. Bacteria in animals can persist in soil or water for weeks, and it takes only a small amount to cause a transmission.\n\nByline: Pamela Johnson\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (in the laboratory or via an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _D. variabilis_ (dog tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe infection does not spread from person to person, essentially in contradiction to another category A bioterrorism agent, _Yersinia pestis_, in which the pneumonic form can easily be transmitted.\n\n_F. tularensis_ infection can present in a variety of ways depending on the route of acquisition. Even before the antimicrobial era, pneumonia due to inhalation of _F. tularensis_ seemed to account for most of the deaths related to the infection (1). A good review of the subject written by Thomas and Schaffner can be found in reference 2.\n\nCitations\n----------\n1. Foshay L. Cause of death in tularemia. Arch Intern Med. 1937; 60(1): 22-38. doi:10.1001/archinte.1937.00180010025002; abstract available at https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/article-abstract/542763.\n2. Thomas LD, Schaffner W. Tularemia pneumonia. Infect Dis N Am. 2010; 24(1): 43-55. doi: 10.1016/j.idc.2009.10.012; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20171544.\n\nLarimer County is located in the north central part of the state and can be seen on a map at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larimer_County,_Colorado. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nLarimer County, Colorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1298]\nSee Also\nTularemia - USA (04): (IL) wild rabbit, human 20180621.5866489\nTularemia - USA (03): (IL) wild rabbit 20180619.5863284\nTularemia - USA (02): (KY) sentinel rabbit infected, alert 20180430.5775458\nTularemia - USA: (CA) infected ticks 20180215.5628959\n2017\n----\nTularemia - USA (08): (AZ) human, fatal, canine, 2016 20170824.5272785\nTularemia - USA (07): (AK) snowshoe hares 20170819.5260441\nTularemia - USA (06): (CO) wild rabbit 20170623.5127076\nTularemia - USA (05): (MN) feline exposure 20170611.5098241\nTularemia - USA (04): (CO) wild rabbit 20170505.5016005\nTularemia - USA (02): (CO) wild rabbit 20170423.4988936\n2016\n----\nTularemia - USA (15): (CO) human, wildlife 20161102.4602736\nTularemia - USA (10): (WY) 20160807.4396768\nTularemia - USA (05): (AZ) fatal 20160708.4333270\nPlague, tularemia - USA (NM) alert 20160615.4289092\nTularemia - USA: (MN, AK) feline, canine, lagomorph 20160529.4252246\n2015\n----\nTularemia - USA (18) 20151205.3842058\nTularemia - USA (10): (CO, SD) 20150801.3548673\nTularemia - USA (05): (AK) susp. 20150702.3480207\nTularemia - USA: (CO) 20150522.3379806\n.................................................sb/ll/tw/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5866489", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (04): (IL) wild rabbit, human", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5866489", "date": "2017-10-04 18:33:01", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - ARMENIA (02): (TAVUSH) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 Sep 2017\nSource: News.am [in Armenian, trans.by an Epicore participant, edited]\nhttps://med.news.am/arm/news/15665/tavushi-marzi-hing-gyuxeri-bnakichnerin-kpatvasten-tularemiayi-dem%E2%80%A4-artavazd-vanyan.html\n\n\nResidents of 5 Tavush provinces will be immunized against tularemia\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn total, 25 cases of tularemia infection were recorded in Armenia over the past month, 21 of them are residents of Artsvaberd village of Tavush region, 2 are residents of Kotayk region, and 2 from Yerevan. These last 4 people, as it turned out, visited the village of Artsvaberd. Currently, only 1 of the infected people continues to receive inpatient treatment. There were no severe cases of illness. Artavazd Vanyan, Head of the National Center for Disease Control and Prevention of MoH, said this during the parliamentary hearings in the Standing Committee on Health Care, Maternity and Social Welfare issues.\n\nAccording to him, the first case was clinically detected on [29 Aug 2017]. He was a resident of Yerevan who applied to the Nork infectious hospital. In early August [2017], this person had visited the village of Artsvaberd of Tavush region. The specialists of the Center visited the village and found out that some villagers already had some clinical manifestations of tularemia, and had been locally wrongfully treated for angina.\n\nAccording to Artavazd Vanyan, the investigation has shown that the infection in the village of Artsvaberd occurred from the end of July [2017] to the middle of August [2017]. The causative agent of tularemia was not isolated during the investigation of water and food samples, or from animals. That is, the infection occurred without a clear epizootic. The Center came to the conclusion that the infection could occur by air/dust- borne during haymaking, which is evidence of its forms, oculoglandular and angino-glandular [oroglandular? - Mod.LL], as well as the fact that all the affected lived close to one another.\n\n\"This is the first time in Armenia when people got sick with tularemia without a clear animal infection, and the first time that the transmission of the pathogen occurred by air/dust,\" Artavazd Vanyan said.\n\nHe added that the Artsvaberd village is located in the border with Azerbaijan, and Armenian specialists cannot conduct surveys of the entire territory. According to Artavazd Vanyan, Azerbaijan, like Armenia, is an endemic country for tularemia, and, probably, penetration of the animal reservoir took place from that side.\n\nTaking into account that the risk of infection continues, the Center decided to vaccinate all residents over 7 years of the village of Artsvaberd and neighboring villages - Chinari, Norashen, Choratan and Aygedzor. Vaccination, in his words, will protect them from tularemia in the next 5 years.\n\nAnswering the question of Ms. Margarita Yesayan, parliamentarian, about the possibility of deliberate contamination of Armenian territories, Artavazd Vanyan noted that, judging by the fact that there was a local outbreak, and not an epidemic, this seems unlikely.\n\nTularemia is a zoonotic infection in which patients experience intoxication, fever, and lymph node involvement. The causative agent of the disease is _Francisella tularensis_. Some animals, including rabbits, hare and water rats are considered carriers of tularemia bacteria. Infection is transmitted to a person by direct contact with sick animals or through contaminated food and water. There are fewer cases of tularemia infection by aspiration - for example, when processing grain products, threshing bread, and sometimes there are cases of infection through blood-sucking arthropods.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED sincerely thanks the EpiCore members who were able to supply the original citation in Armenian and then translate it into a cogent form. SB and I, using Google Translate, produced a version that was only partly understandable. Any further clarification of the translation would be appreciated.\n\nGuessing that angina-glandular likely means oropharyngeal involvement (as angina can refer to a severe sore throat); the presence of these manifestations suggests aerosolization of _F. tularensis_ with infection in the throat and conjunctivae. Contaminated hay or grass when manipulated could have caused infectious aerosols. Water transmission could have occurred but is less likely given oculoglandular involvement unless swimming was involved.\n\nA recent report regarding oculoglandular and oropharyngeal tularemia from Turkey is: Eren Gok S, Kocagul Celikbas A, Baykam N, et al: Evaluation of tularemia cases focusing on the oculoglandular form. J Infect Dev Ctries. 2014;8: 1277-1284. doi: 10.3855/jidc.3996. Available at: https://jidc.org/index.php/journal/article/view/25313604/1168.\n\nAbstract\n--------\n\"Introduction: Tularemia is a zoonotic disease caused by _Francisella tularensis_. The oculoglandular form is one of the rarest forms. In this study, we evaluated tularemia patients, focusing on the ocular form and the efficacy of early antimicrobial therapy.\n\n\"Methodology: During a tularemia outbreak, the epidemiological and clinical findings, laboratory assays, and drugs used for the treatment of 48 patients were recorded prospectively. The diagnosis of tularemia was confirmed with microagglutination test (MAT) as well as clinical findings.\n\n\"Results: The mean age of the subject was 48.6 years; 23 (47.9 percent) of them were female. 36 (81.25 percent) patients had clinical presentation compatible with oropharyngeal tularemia, 7 (14.58 percent) with oculoglandular tularemia, and 2 (4.1 percent) with ulceroglandular tularemia. The most common symptoms were fever (91.6 percent) and sore throat (81.2 percent), and the most common findings were lymphadenopathy (91.6 percent) and tonsillopharyngitis (81.2 percent). In the oculoglandular form, fever, lymphadenopathy, periorbital edema, conjunctival injection, and chemosis were found. The most distinctive ophthalmic feature was follicular conjunctivitis and conjunctival epithelial defects. A total of 45 cases had positive serological results with MAT. All the patients were treated with antimicrobials considered effective against _F. tularensis_, and topical antimicrobial treatment was given to the patients with oculoglandular tularemia. As many as 26 (54.16 percent) patients, who were admitted within 3 weeks of the onset of symptoms, recovered without sequel.\n\n\"Conclusions: During tularemia outbreaks, ocular involvement should be considered carefully. The early administration of appropriate treatment will be more effective in resolving the infection and preventing complications. Along with systemic antimicrobial therapy, topical treatment will help recovery.\"\n\nAgain, ProMED would much appreciate any other suggestions regarding the translation. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/133.]\nSee Also\nTularemia - Armenia: (TV) RFI 20171002.5355480\n2016\n----\nTularemia - Ukraine: (KR) 20160204.3995341\n2015\n----\nTularemia, animal - Czech Republic: (MO) hare 20150523.3380738\nTularemia - Kosovo (02) 20150216.3170249\nTularemia - Kosovo: RFI 20150212.3161852\n2013\n----\nTularemia - Russia (02): (KM) 20130919.1954010\nTularemia - Russia: (KM) 20130825.1898671\n2012\n----\nTularemia - Russia (02): (KX) susp. NOT anthrax 20121027.1366708\nTularemia - Russia: (AR) 20120906.1275268\n2008\n----\nTularemia - Russia: (Moscow) 20080722.2227\n2007\n----\nTularemia, hunter - Russia: (Amur) 20071207.3946\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky)(03) 20070910.2988\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky) 20070826.2804\n\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) (02) 20070316.0918\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) 20070314.0901\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy)(02) 20070127.0362\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) 20070124.0317\n2005\n----\nTularemia - Russia (European) 20050831.2577\nTularemia - Russia (Nizhniy Novgorod) 20050824.2503\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan)(02) 20050822.2467\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) 20050718.2066\nTularemia, hunters - Russia (Stavropol) 20050322.0825\nTularemia - Ukraine (Donetsk) 20050304.0663\n2003\n----\nTularemia, water-borne - Ukraine 20030808.1957\n2002\n----\nTularemia - Kosovo (02) 20020206.3498\nTularemia - Kosovo 20020118.3299\n.................................................sb/ll/ao/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KX", "country": "Belarus"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Aygedzor", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Kosovo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Artsvaberd", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Norashen", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Ukraine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ryazan)(02", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Armenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Armenia", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Stavropol", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kaspskiy)(02", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Kotayk", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5863284", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (03): (IL) wild rabbit", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5863284", "date": "2017-10-04 18:33:01", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - ARMENIA (02): (TAVUSH) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 Sep 2017\nSource: News.am [in Armenian, trans.by an Epicore participant, edited]\nhttps://med.news.am/arm/news/15665/tavushi-marzi-hing-gyuxeri-bnakichnerin-kpatvasten-tularemiayi-dem%E2%80%A4-artavazd-vanyan.html\n\n\nResidents of 5 Tavush provinces will be immunized against tularemia\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn total, 25 cases of tularemia infection were recorded in Armenia over the past month, 21 of them are residents of Artsvaberd village of Tavush region, 2 are residents of Kotayk region, and 2 from Yerevan. Vaccination, in his words, will protect them from tularemia in the next 5 years.\n\nAnswering the question of Ms. Margarita Yesayan, parliamentarian, about the possibility of deliberate contamination of Armenian territories, Artavazd Vanyan noted that, judging by the fact that there was a local outbreak, and not an epidemic, this seems unlikely.\n\nTularemia is a zoonotic infection in which patients experience intoxication, fever, and lymph node involvement. The causative agent of the disease is _Francisella tularensis_. Some animals, including rabbits, hare and water rats are considered carriers of tularemia bacteria. Infection is transmitted to a person by direct contact with sick animals or through contaminated food and water. There are fewer cases of tularemia infection by aspiration - for example, when processing grain products, threshing bread, and sometimes there are cases of infection through blood-sucking arthropods.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED sincerely thanks the EpiCore members who were able to supply the original citation in Armenian and then translate it into a cogent form. Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky)(03) 20070910.2988\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky) 20070826.2804\n\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) (02) 20070316.0918\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) 20070314.0901\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy)(02) 20070127.0362\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) 20070124.0317\n2005\n----\nTularemia - Russia (European) 20050831.2577\nTularemia - Russia (Nizhniy Novgorod) 20050824.2503\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan)(02) 20050822.2467\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) 20050718.2066\nTularemia, hunters - Russia (Stavropol) 20050322.0825\nTularemia - Ukraine (Donetsk) 20050304.0663\n2003\n----\nTularemia, water-borne - Ukraine 20030808.1957\n2002\n----\nTularemia - Kosovo (02) 20020206.3498\nTularemia - Kosovo 20020118.3299\n.................................................sb/ll/ao/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KX", "country": "Belarus"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Aygedzor", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Kosovo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Artsvaberd", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Norashen", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Ukraine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ryazan)(02", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Armenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Armenia", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Stavropol", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kaspskiy)(02", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Kotayk", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5775458", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (02): (KY) sentinel rabbit infected, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5775458", "date": "2017-10-04 18:33:01", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - ARMENIA (02): (TAVUSH) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 Sep 2017\nSource: News.am [in Armenian, trans.by an Epicore participant, edited]\nhttps://med.news.am/arm/news/15665/tavushi-marzi-hing-gyuxeri-bnakichnerin-kpatvasten-tularemiayi-dem%E2%80%A4-artavazd-vanyan.html\n\n\nResidents of 5 Tavush provinces will be immunized against tularemia\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn total, 25 cases of tularemia infection were recorded in Armenia over the past month, 21 of them are residents of Artsvaberd village of Tavush region, 2 are residents of Kotayk region, and 2 from Yerevan. These last 4 people, as it turned out, visited the village of Artsvaberd. Currently, only 1 of the infected people continues to receive inpatient treatment. There were no severe cases of illness. Artavazd Vanyan, Head of the National Center for Disease Control and Prevention of MoH, said this during the parliamentary hearings in the Standing Committee on Health Care, Maternity and Social Welfare issues.\n\nAccording to him, the first case was clinically detected on [29 Aug 2017]. He was a resident of Yerevan who applied to the Nork infectious hospital. In early August [2017], this person had visited the village of Artsvaberd of Tavush region. The specialists of the Center visited the village and found out that some villagers already had some clinical manifestations of tularemia, and had been locally wrongfully treated for angina.\n\nAccording to Artavazd Vanyan, the investigation has shown that the infection in the village of Artsvaberd occurred from the end of July [2017] to the middle of August [2017]. The causative agent of tularemia was not isolated during the investigation of water and food samples, or from animals. That is, the infection occurred without a clear epizootic. The Center came to the conclusion that the infection could occur by air/dust- borne during haymaking, which is evidence of its forms, oculoglandular and angino-glandular [oroglandular? - Mod.LL], as well as the fact that all the affected lived close to one another.\n\n\"This is the first time in Armenia when people got sick with tularemia without a clear animal infection, and the first time that the transmission of the pathogen occurred by air/dust,\" Artavazd Vanyan said.\n\nHe added that the Artsvaberd village is located in the border with Azerbaijan, and Armenian specialists cannot conduct surveys of the entire territory. According to Artavazd Vanyan, Azerbaijan, like Armenia, is an endemic country for tularemia, and, probably, penetration of the animal reservoir took place from that side.\n\nTaking into account that the risk of infection continues, the Center decided to vaccinate all residents over 7 years of the village of Artsvaberd and neighboring villages - Chinari, Norashen, Choratan and Aygedzor. Vaccination, in his words, will protect them from tularemia in the next 5 years.\n\nAnswering the question of Ms. Margarita Yesayan, parliamentarian, about the possibility of deliberate contamination of Armenian territories, Artavazd Vanyan noted that, judging by the fact that there was a local outbreak, and not an epidemic, this seems unlikely.\n\nTularemia is a zoonotic infection in which patients experience intoxication, fever, and lymph node involvement. The causative agent of the disease is _Francisella tularensis_. Some animals, including rabbits, hare and water rats are considered carriers of tularemia bacteria. Infection is transmitted to a person by direct contact with sick animals or through contaminated food and water. There are fewer cases of tularemia infection by aspiration - for example, when processing grain products, threshing bread, and sometimes there are cases of infection through blood-sucking arthropods.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED sincerely thanks the EpiCore members who were able to supply the original citation in Armenian and then translate it into a cogent form. SB and I, using Google Translate, produced a version that was only partly understandable. Any further clarification of the translation would be appreciated.\n\nGuessing that angina-glandular likely means oropharyngeal involvement (as angina can refer to a severe sore throat); the presence of these manifestations suggests aerosolization of _F. tularensis_ with infection in the throat and conjunctivae. Contaminated hay or grass when manipulated could have caused infectious aerosols. Water transmission could have occurred but is less likely given oculoglandular involvement unless swimming was involved.\n\nA recent report regarding oculoglandular and oropharyngeal tularemia from Turkey is: Eren Gok S, Kocagul Celikbas A, Baykam N, et al: Evaluation of tularemia cases focusing on the oculoglandular form. J Infect Dev Ctries. 2014;8: 1277-1284. doi: 10.3855/jidc.3996. Available at: https://jidc.org/index.php/journal/article/view/25313604/1168.\n\nAbstract\n--------\n\"Introduction: Tularemia is a zoonotic disease caused by _Francisella tularensis_. The oculoglandular form is one of the rarest forms. In this study, we evaluated tularemia patients, focusing on the ocular form and the efficacy of early antimicrobial therapy.\n\n\"Methodology: During a tularemia outbreak, the epidemiological and clinical findings, laboratory assays, and drugs used for the treatment of 48 patients were recorded prospectively. The diagnosis of tularemia was confirmed with microagglutination test (MAT) as well as clinical findings.\n\n\"Results: The mean age of the subject was 48.6 years; 23 (47.9 percent) of them were female. 36 (81.25 percent) patients had clinical presentation compatible with oropharyngeal tularemia, 7 (14.58 percent) with oculoglandular tularemia, and 2 (4.1 percent) with ulceroglandular tularemia. The most common symptoms were fever (91.6 percent) and sore throat (81.2 percent), and the most common findings were lymphadenopathy (91.6 percent) and tonsillopharyngitis (81.2 percent). In the oculoglandular form, fever, lymphadenopathy, periorbital edema, conjunctival injection, and chemosis were found. The most distinctive ophthalmic feature was follicular conjunctivitis and conjunctival epithelial defects. A total of 45 cases had positive serological results with MAT. All the patients were treated with antimicrobials considered effective against _F. tularensis_, and topical antimicrobial treatment was given to the patients with oculoglandular tularemia. As many as 26 (54.16 percent) patients, who were admitted within 3 weeks of the onset of symptoms, recovered without sequel.\n\n\"Conclusions: During tularemia outbreaks, ocular involvement should be considered carefully. The early administration of appropriate treatment will be more effective in resolving the infection and preventing complications. Along with systemic antimicrobial therapy, topical treatment will help recovery.\"\n\nAgain, ProMED would much appreciate any other suggestions regarding the translation. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/133.]\nSee Also\nTularemia - Armenia: (TV) RFI 20171002.5355480\n2016\n----\nTularemia - Ukraine: (KR) 20160204.3995341\n2015\n----\nTularemia, animal - Czech Republic: (MO) hare 20150523.3380738\nTularemia - Kosovo (02) 20150216.3170249\nTularemia - Kosovo: RFI 20150212.3161852\n2013\n----\nTularemia - Russia (02): (KM) 20130919.1954010\nTularemia - Russia: (KM) 20130825.1898671\n2012\n----\nTularemia - Russia (02): (KX) susp. NOT anthrax 20121027.1366708\nTularemia - Russia: (AR) 20120906.1275268\n2008\n----\nTularemia - Russia: (Moscow) 20080722.2227\n2007\n----\nTularemia, hunter - Russia: (Amur) 20071207.3946\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky)(03) 20070910.2988\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky) 20070826.2804\n\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) (02) 20070316.0918\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) 20070314.0901\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy)(02) 20070127.0362\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) 20070124.0317\n2005\n----\nTularemia - Russia (European) 20050831.2577\nTularemia - Russia (Nizhniy Novgorod) 20050824.2503\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan)(02) 20050822.2467\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) 20050718.2066\nTularemia, hunters - Russia (Stavropol) 20050322.0825\nTularemia - Ukraine (Donetsk) 20050304.0663\n2003\n----\nTularemia, water-borne - Ukraine 20030808.1957\n2002\n----\nTularemia - Kosovo (02) 20020206.3498\nTularemia - Kosovo 20020118.3299\n.................................................sb/ll/ao/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KX", "country": "Belarus"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Aygedzor", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Switzerland (02): 2017, commentary", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5762836", "date": "2017-10-04 18:33:01", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - ARMENIA (02): (TAVUSH) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 Sep 2017\nSource: News.am [in Armenian, trans.by an Epicore participant, edited]\nhttps://med.news.am/arm/news/15665/tavushi-marzi-hing-gyuxeri-bnakichnerin-kpatvasten-tularemiayi-dem%E2%80%A4-artavazd-vanyan.html\n\n\nResidents of 5 Tavush provinces will be immunized against tularemia\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn total, 25 cases of tularemia infection were recorded in Armenia over the past month, 21 of them are residents of Artsvaberd village of Tavush region, 2 are residents of Kotayk region, and 2 from Yerevan. These last 4 people, as it turned out, visited the village of Artsvaberd. Currently, only 1 of the infected people continues to receive inpatient treatment. There were no severe cases of illness. Artavazd Vanyan, Head of the National Center for Disease Control and Prevention of MoH, said this during the parliamentary hearings in the Standing Committee on Health Care, Maternity and Social Welfare issues.\n\nAccording to him, the first case was clinically detected on [29 Aug 2017]. He was a resident of Yerevan who applied to the Nork infectious hospital. In early August [2017], this person had visited the village of Artsvaberd of Tavush region. The specialists of the Center visited the village and found out that some villagers already had some clinical manifestations of tularemia, and had been locally wrongfully treated for angina.\n\nAccording to Artavazd Vanyan, the investigation has shown that the infection in the village of Artsvaberd occurred from the end of July [2017] to the middle of August [2017]. The causative agent of tularemia was not isolated during the investigation of water and food samples, or from animals. That is, the infection occurred without a clear epizootic. The Center came to the conclusion that the infection could occur by air/dust- borne during haymaking, which is evidence of its forms, oculoglandular and angino-glandular [oroglandular? - Mod.LL], as well as the fact that all the affected lived close to one another.\n\n\"This is the first time in Armenia when people got sick with tularemia without a clear animal infection, and the first time that the transmission of the pathogen occurred by air/dust,\" Artavazd Vanyan said.\n\nHe added that the Artsvaberd village is located in the border with Azerbaijan, and Armenian specialists cannot conduct surveys of the entire territory. According to Artavazd Vanyan, Azerbaijan, like Armenia, is an endemic country for tularemia, and, probably, penetration of the animal reservoir took place from that side.\n\nTaking into account that the risk of infection continues, the Center decided to vaccinate all residents over 7 years of the village of Artsvaberd and neighboring villages - Chinari, Norashen, Choratan and Aygedzor. Vaccination, in his words, will protect them from tularemia in the next 5 years.\n\nAnswering the question of Ms. Margarita Yesayan, parliamentarian, about the possibility of deliberate contamination of Armenian territories, Artavazd Vanyan noted that, judging by the fact that there was a local outbreak, and not an epidemic, this seems unlikely.\n\nTularemia is a zoonotic infection in which patients experience intoxication, fever, and lymph node involvement. The causative agent of the disease is _Francisella tularensis_. Some animals, including rabbits, hare and water rats are considered carriers of tularemia bacteria. Infection is transmitted to a person by direct contact with sick animals or through contaminated food and water. There are fewer cases of tularemia infection by aspiration - for example, when processing grain products, threshing bread, and sometimes there are cases of infection through blood-sucking arthropods.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED sincerely thanks the EpiCore members who were able to supply the original citation in Armenian and then translate it into a cogent form. Water transmission could have occurred but is less likely given oculoglandular involvement unless swimming was involved.\n\nA recent report regarding oculoglandular and oropharyngeal tularemia from Turkey is: Eren Gok S, Kocagul Celikbas A, Baykam N, et al: Evaluation of tularemia cases focusing on the oculoglandular form. J Infect Dev Ctries. 2014;8: 1277-1284. doi: 10.3855/jidc.3996. Available at: https://jidc.org/index.php/journal/article/view/25313604/1168.\n\nAbstract\n--------\n\"Introduction: Tularemia is a zoonotic disease caused by _Francisella tularensis_. The oculoglandular form is one of the rarest forms. In this study, we evaluated tularemia patients, focusing on the ocular form and the efficacy of early antimicrobial therapy.\n\n\"Methodology: During a tularemia outbreak, the epidemiological and clinical findings, laboratory assays, and drugs used for the treatment of 48 patients were recorded prospectively. The diagnosis of tularemia was confirmed with microagglutination test (MAT) as well as clinical findings.\n\n\"Results: The mean age of the subject was 48.6 years; 23 (47.9 percent) of them were female. 36 (81.25 percent) patients had clinical presentation compatible with oropharyngeal tularemia, 7 (14.58 percent) with oculoglandular tularemia, and 2 (4.1 percent) with ulceroglandular tularemia. The most common symptoms were fever (91.6 percent) and sore throat (81.2 percent), and the most common findings were lymphadenopathy (91.6 percent) and tonsillopharyngitis (81.2 percent). In the oculoglandular form, fever, lymphadenopathy, periorbital edema, conjunctival injection, and chemosis were found. The most distinctive ophthalmic feature was follicular conjunctivitis and conjunctival epithelial defects. A total of 45 cases had positive serological results with MAT. All the patients were treated with antimicrobials considered effective against _F. tularensis_, and topical antimicrobial treatment was given to the patients with oculoglandular tularemia. As many as 26 (54.16 percent) patients, who were admitted within 3 weeks of the onset of symptoms, recovered without sequel.\n\n\"Conclusions: During tularemia outbreaks, ocular involvement should be considered carefully. The early administration of appropriate treatment will be more effective in resolving the infection and preventing complications. Along with systemic antimicrobial therapy, topical treatment will help recovery.\"\n\nAgain, ProMED would much appreciate any other suggestions regarding the translation. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/133.]\nSee Also\nTularemia - Armenia: (TV) RFI 20171002.5355480\n2016\n----\nTularemia - Ukraine: (KR) 20160204.3995341\n2015\n----\nTularemia, animal - Czech Republic: (MO) hare 20150523.3380738\nTularemia - Kosovo (02) 20150216.3170249\nTularemia - Kosovo: RFI 20150212.3161852\n2013\n----\nTularemia - Russia (02): (KM) 20130919.1954010\nTularemia - Russia: (KM) 20130825.1898671\n2012\n----\nTularemia - Russia (02): (KX) susp. NOT anthrax 20121027.1366708\nTularemia - Russia: (AR) 20120906.1275268\n2008\n----\nTularemia - Russia: (Moscow) 20080722.2227\n2007\n----\nTularemia, hunter - Russia: (Amur) 20071207.3946\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky)(03) 20070910.2988\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky) 20070826.2804\n\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) (02) 20070316.0918\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) 20070314.0901\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy)(02) 20070127.0362\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) 20070124.0317\n2005\n----\nTularemia - Russia (European) 20050831.2577\nTularemia - Russia (Nizhniy Novgorod) 20050824.2503\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan)(02) 20050822.2467\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) 20050718.2066\nTularemia, hunters - Russia (Stavropol) 20050322.0825\nTularemia - Ukraine (Donetsk) 20050304.0663\n2003\n----\nTularemia, water-borne - Ukraine 20030808.1957\n2002\n----\nTularemia - Kosovo (02) 20020206.3498\nTularemia - Kosovo 20020118.3299\n.................................................sb/ll/ao/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KX", "country": "Belarus"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Aygedzor", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Kosovo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Artsvaberd", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Norashen", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Ukraine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ryazan)(02", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Armenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Armenia", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Stavropol", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kaspskiy)(02", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Kotayk", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5760078", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Switzerland: 2017", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5760078", "date": "2017-10-04 18:33:01", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - ARMENIA (02): (TAVUSH) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 Sep 2017\nSource: News.am [in Armenian, trans.by an Epicore participant, edited]\nhttps://med.news.am/arm/news/15665/tavushi-marzi-hing-gyuxeri-bnakichnerin-kpatvasten-tularemiayi-dem%E2%80%A4-artavazd-vanyan.html\n\n\nResidents of 5 Tavush provinces will be immunized against tularemia\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn total, 25 cases of tularemia infection were recorded in Armenia over the past month, 21 of them are residents of Artsvaberd village of Tavush region, 2 are residents of Kotayk region, and 2 from Yerevan. These last 4 people, as it turned out, visited the village of Artsvaberd. Currently, only 1 of the infected people continues to receive inpatient treatment. There were no severe cases of illness. Artavazd Vanyan, Head of the National Center for Disease Control and Prevention of MoH, said this during the parliamentary hearings in the Standing Committee on Health Care, Maternity and Social Welfare issues.\n\nAccording to him, the first case was clinically detected on [29 Aug 2017]. He was a resident of Yerevan who applied to the Nork infectious hospital. In early August [2017], this person had visited the village of Artsvaberd of Tavush region. The specialists of the Center visited the village and found out that some villagers already had some clinical manifestations of tularemia, and had been locally wrongfully treated for angina.\n\nAccording to Artavazd Vanyan, the investigation has shown that the infection in the village of Artsvaberd occurred from the end of July [2017] to the middle of August [2017]. The causative agent of tularemia was not isolated during the investigation of water and food samples, or from animals. That is, the infection occurred without a clear epizootic. The Center came to the conclusion that the infection could occur by air/dust- borne during haymaking, which is evidence of its forms, oculoglandular and angino-glandular [oroglandular? - Mod.LL], as well as the fact that all the affected lived close to one another.\n\n\"This is the first time in Armenia when people got sick with tularemia without a clear animal infection, and the first time that the transmission of the pathogen occurred by air/dust,\" Artavazd Vanyan said.\n\nHe added that the Artsvaberd village is located in the border with Azerbaijan, and Armenian specialists cannot conduct surveys of the entire territory. According to Artavazd Vanyan, Azerbaijan, like Armenia, is an endemic country for tularemia, and, probably, penetration of the animal reservoir took place from that side.\n\nTaking into account that the risk of infection continues, the Center decided to vaccinate all residents over 7 years of the village of Artsvaberd and neighboring villages - Chinari, Norashen, Choratan and Aygedzor. Vaccination, in his words, will protect them from tularemia in the next 5 years.\n\nAnswering the question of Ms. Margarita Yesayan, parliamentarian, about the possibility of deliberate contamination of Armenian territories, Artavazd Vanyan noted that, judging by the fact that there was a local outbreak, and not an epidemic, this seems unlikely.\n\nTularemia is a zoonotic infection in which patients experience intoxication, fever, and lymph node involvement. The causative agent of the disease is _Francisella tularensis_. Some animals, including rabbits, hare and water rats are considered carriers of tularemia bacteria. Infection is transmitted to a person by direct contact with sick animals or through contaminated food and water. There are fewer cases of tularemia infection by aspiration - for example, when processing grain products, threshing bread, and sometimes there are cases of infection through blood-sucking arthropods.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED sincerely thanks the EpiCore members who were able to supply the original citation in Armenian and then translate it into a cogent form. SB and I, using Google Translate, produced a version that was only partly understandable. Any further clarification of the translation would be appreciated.\n\nGuessing that angina-glandular likely means oropharyngeal involvement (as angina can refer to a severe sore throat); the presence of these manifestations suggests aerosolization of _F. tularensis_ with infection in the throat and conjunctivae. Contaminated hay or grass when manipulated could have caused infectious aerosols. Water transmission could have occurred but is less likely given oculoglandular involvement unless swimming was involved.\n\nA recent report regarding oculoglandular and oropharyngeal tularemia from Turkey is: Eren Gok S, Kocagul Celikbas A, Baykam N, et al: Evaluation of tularemia cases focusing on the oculoglandular form. J Infect Dev Ctries. 2014;8: 1277-1284. doi: 10.3855/jidc.3996. Available at: https://jidc.org/index.php/journal/article/view/25313604/1168.\n\nAbstract\n--------\n\"Introduction: Tularemia is a zoonotic disease caused by _Francisella tularensis_. The oculoglandular form is one of the rarest forms. In this study, we evaluated tularemia patients, focusing on the ocular form and the efficacy of early antimicrobial therapy.\n\n\"Methodology: During a tularemia outbreak, the epidemiological and clinical findings, laboratory assays, and drugs used for the treatment of 48 patients were recorded prospectively. The diagnosis of tularemia was confirmed with microagglutination test (MAT) as well as clinical findings.\n\n\"Results: The mean age of the subject was 48.6 years; 23 (47.9 percent) of them were female. 36 (81.25 percent) patients had clinical presentation compatible with oropharyngeal tularemia, 7 (14.58 percent) with oculoglandular tularemia, and 2 (4.1 percent) with ulceroglandular tularemia. The most common symptoms were fever (91.6 percent) and sore throat (81.2 percent), and the most common findings were lymphadenopathy (91.6 percent) and tonsillopharyngitis (81.2 percent). In the oculoglandular form, fever, lymphadenopathy, periorbital edema, conjunctival injection, and chemosis were found. The most distinctive ophthalmic feature was follicular conjunctivitis and conjunctival epithelial defects. A total of 45 cases had positive serological results with MAT. All the patients were treated with antimicrobials considered effective against _F. tularensis_, and topical antimicrobial treatment was given to the patients with oculoglandular tularemia. As many as 26 (54.16 percent) patients, who were admitted within 3 weeks of the onset of symptoms, recovered without sequel.\n\n\"Conclusions: During tularemia outbreaks, ocular involvement should be considered carefully. The early administration of appropriate treatment will be more effective in resolving the infection and preventing complications. Along with systemic antimicrobial therapy, topical treatment will help recovery.\"\n\nAgain, ProMED would much appreciate any other suggestions regarding the translation. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/133.]\nSee Also\nTularemia - Armenia: (TV) RFI 20171002.5355480\n2016\n----\nTularemia - Ukraine: (KR) 20160204.3995341\n2015\n----\nTularemia, animal - Czech Republic: (MO) hare 20150523.3380738\nTularemia - Kosovo (02) 20150216.3170249\nTularemia - Kosovo: RFI 20150212.3161852\n2013\n----\nTularemia - Russia (02): (KM) 20130919.1954010\nTularemia - Russia: (KM) 20130825.1898671\n2012\n----\nTularemia - Russia (02): (KX) susp.
