These last 4 people, as it turned out, visited the village of Artsvaberd. Currently, only 1 of the infected people continues to receive inpatient treatment. There were no severe cases of illness. Artavazd Vanyan, Head of the National Center for Disease Control and Prevention of MoH, said this during the parliamentary hearings in the Standing Committee on Health Care, Maternity and Social Welfare issues.\n\nAccording to him, the first case was clinically detected on [29 Aug 2017]. He was a resident of Yerevan who applied to the Nork infectious hospital. In early August [2017], this person had visited the village of Artsvaberd of Tavush region. The specialists of the Center visited the village and found out that some villagers already had some clinical manifestations of tularemia, and had been locally wrongfully treated for angina.\n\nAccording to Artavazd Vanyan, the investigation has shown that the infection in the village of Artsvaberd occurred from the end of July [2017] to the middle of August [2017]. The causative agent of tularemia was not isolated during the investigation of water and food samples, or from animals. That is, the infection occurred without a clear epizootic. The Center came to the conclusion that the infection could occur by air/dust- borne during haymaking, which is evidence of its forms, oculoglandular and angino-glandular [oroglandular? - Mod.LL], as well as the fact that all the affected lived close to one another.\n\n\"This is the first time in Armenia when people got sick with tularemia without a clear animal infection, and the first time that the transmission of the pathogen occurred by air/dust,\" Artavazd Vanyan said.\n\nHe added that the Artsvaberd village is located in the border with Azerbaijan, and Armenian specialists cannot conduct surveys of the entire territory. According to Artavazd Vanyan, Azerbaijan, like Armenia, is an endemic country for tularemia, and, probably, penetration of the animal reservoir took place from that side.\n\nTaking into account that the risk of infection continues, the Center decided to vaccinate all residents over 7 years of the village of Artsvaberd and neighboring villages - Chinari, Norashen, Choratan and Aygedzor. Vaccination, in his words, will protect them from tularemia in the next 5 years.\n\nAnswering the question of Ms. Margarita Yesayan, parliamentarian, about the possibility of deliberate contamination of Armenian territories, Artavazd Vanyan noted that, judging by the fact that there was a local outbreak, and not an epidemic, this seems unlikely.\n\nTularemia is a zoonotic infection in which patients experience intoxication, fever, and lymph node involvement. The causative agent of the disease is _Francisella tularensis_. Some animals, including rabbits, hare and water rats are considered carriers of tularemia bacteria. Infection is transmitted to a person by direct contact with sick animals or through contaminated food and water. There are fewer cases of tularemia infection by aspiration - for example, when processing grain products, threshing bread, and sometimes there are cases of infection through blood-sucking arthropods.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED sincerely thanks the EpiCore members who were able to supply the original citation in Armenian and then translate it into a cogent form. SB and I, using Google Translate, produced a version that was only partly understandable. Any further clarification of the translation would be appreciated.\n\nGuessing that angina-glandular likely means oropharyngeal involvement (as angina can refer to a severe sore throat); the presence of these manifestations suggests aerosolization of _F. tularensis_ with infection in the throat and conjunctivae. Contaminated hay or grass when manipulated could have caused infectious aerosols. Water transmission could have occurred but is less likely given oculoglandular involvement unless swimming was involved.\n\nA recent report regarding oculoglandular and oropharyngeal tularemia from Turkey is: Eren Gok S, Kocagul Celikbas A, Baykam N, et al: Evaluation of tularemia cases focusing on the oculoglandular form. J Infect Dev Ctries. 2014;8: 1277-1284. doi: 10.3855/jidc.3996. Available at: https://jidc.org/index.php/journal/article/view/25313604/1168.\n\nAbstract\n--------\n\"Introduction: Tularemia is a zoonotic disease caused by _Francisella tularensis_. The oculoglandular form is one of the rarest forms. In this study, we evaluated tularemia patients, focusing on the ocular form and the efficacy of early antimicrobial therapy.\n\n\"Methodology: During a tularemia outbreak, the epidemiological and clinical findings, laboratory assays, and drugs used for the treatment of 48 patients were recorded prospectively. The diagnosis of tularemia was confirmed with microagglutination test (MAT) as well as clinical findings.\n\n\"Results: The mean age of the subject was 48.6 years; 23 (47.9 percent) of them were female. 36 (81.25 percent) patients had clinical presentation compatible with oropharyngeal tularemia, 7 (14.58 percent) with oculoglandular tularemia, and 2 (4.1 percent) with ulceroglandular tularemia. The most common symptoms were fever (91.6 percent) and sore throat (81.2 percent), and the most common findings were lymphadenopathy (91.6 percent) and tonsillopharyngitis (81.2 percent). In the oculoglandular form, fever, lymphadenopathy, periorbital edema, conjunctival injection, and chemosis were found. The most distinctive ophthalmic feature was follicular conjunctivitis and conjunctival epithelial defects. A total of 45 cases had positive serological results with MAT. All the patients were treated with antimicrobials considered effective against _F. tularensis_, and topical antimicrobial treatment was given to the patients with oculoglandular tularemia. As many as 26 (54.16 percent) patients, who were admitted within 3 weeks of the onset of symptoms, recovered without sequel.\n\n\"Conclusions: During tularemia outbreaks, ocular involvement should be considered carefully. The early administration of appropriate treatment will be more effective in resolving the infection and preventing complications. Along with systemic antimicrobial therapy, topical treatment will help recovery.\"\n\nAgain, ProMED would much appreciate any other suggestions regarding the translation. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/133.]\nSee Also\nTularemia - Armenia: (TV) RFI 20171002.5355480\n2016\n----\nTularemia - Ukraine: (KR) 20160204.3995341\n2015\n----\nTularemia, animal - Czech Republic: (MO) hare 20150523.3380738\nTularemia - Kosovo (02) 20150216.3170249\nTularemia - Kosovo: RFI 20150212.3161852\n2013\n----\nTularemia - Russia (02): (KM) 20130919.1954010\nTularemia - Russia: (KM) 20130825.1898671\n2012\n----\nTularemia - Russia (02): (KX) susp. Ukraine 20030808.1957\n2002\n----\nTularemia - Kosovo (02) 20020206.3498\nTularemia - Kosovo 20020118.3299\n.................................................sb/ll/ao/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KX", "country": "Belarus"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Aygedzor", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Armenia: (TV) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5355480", "date": "2017-05-05 17:37:07", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (04): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 3 May 2017 7:53 AM\nSource: News Channel 13 abc [edited]\nhttp://www.kjct8.com/content/news/Dead-rabbit-421157643.html\n\n\nMesa County Public Health officials said a dead rabbit in Whitewater tested positive for tularemia, also known as rabbit fever. A Mesa County couple called health officials after finding the rabbit on their property. \"We've lived out here for over 20 years,\" said [CW]. \"We have a lot of coyotes, bobcats different things, badgers are out here.\"\n\nHealth officials said they have discovered rabbit fever in neighborhoods east and west of the Colorado National Monument.\n\n\"This particular rabbit like to go underneath my car; he hung out there most of the day. One day I came out here and he was dead,\" said [W]. \"I bagged it up and took it to the health department, so they examined it and they called me a couple days later saying it was positive for the rabbit disease.\"\n\nHomeowners who see multiple animals on their properties should call Mesa County Public Health right away, as it could be a sign of unusual disease activity in the area. \"In the last few years, we've seen an uptick in detecting it in wildlife and in people,\" explained Thomas Orr, an epidemiologist with Mesa County Public Health. \"We really want to get the message out so people don't get ill with this. If they do have sick pets or get sick themselves, it is treatable.\"\n\nBureau of Land Management spokesperson Chris Joyner said the disease is most common near the river. \"We've seen a lot of cases of Tularemia connected to the river corridors in our high use areas along the river. We have a lot recreation that takes place there,\" he said.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said to use masks when mowing the lawn to reduce inhaling bacteria. Experts also suggest cooking game meat thoroughly before eating. Tularemia is treatable, according to health officials. They said to contact your health care provider if you notice symptoms including infected ulcer-like bite, swollen glands, fever, dry cough, body aches and headaches.\n\n[byline: Jay Greene, Makenzie O'Keefe, Carly Moore]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A few days ago, there was a report of another dead rabbit infected with _Francicella tularensis_ in Whitewater, CO, about 250 miles west (see ProMED-mail post no. 20170423.4988936).\n\nTularemia is caused by the Gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Tularemia is largely confined to the northern hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the southern hemisphere._Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_(Type A) is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/awKN. - USA (08): (AZ) human, fatal, canine, 2016", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5272785", "date": "2017-05-05 17:37:07", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (04): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 3 May 2017 7:53 AM\nSource: News Channel 13 abc [edited]\nhttp://www.kjct8.com/content/news/Dead-rabbit-421157643.html\n\n\nMesa County Public Health officials said a dead rabbit in Whitewater tested positive for tularemia, also known as rabbit fever. A Mesa County couple called health officials after finding the rabbit on their property. \"We've lived out here for over 20 years,\" said [CW]. \"We have a lot of coyotes, bobcats different things, badgers are out here.\"\n\nHealth officials said they have discovered rabbit fever in neighborhoods east and west of the Colorado National Monument.\n\n\"This particular rabbit like to go underneath my car; he hung out there most of the day. One day I came out here and he was dead,\" said [W]. \"I bagged it up and took it to the health department, so they examined it and they called me a couple days later saying it was positive for the rabbit disease.\"\n\nHomeowners who see multiple animals on their properties should call Mesa County Public Health right away, as it could be a sign of unusual disease activity in the area. \"In the last few years, we've seen an uptick in detecting it in wildlife and in people,\" explained Thomas Orr, an epidemiologist with Mesa County Public Health. \"We really want to get the message out so people don't get ill with this. If they do have sick pets or get sick themselves, it is treatable.\"\n\nBureau of Land Management spokesperson Chris Joyner said the disease is most common near the river. \"We've seen a lot of cases of Tularemia connected to the river corridors in our high use areas along the river. We have a lot recreation that takes place there,\" he said.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said to use masks when mowing the lawn to reduce inhaling bacteria. Experts also suggest cooking game meat thoroughly before eating. Tularemia is treatable, according to health officials. They said to contact your health care provider if you notice symptoms including infected ulcer-like bite, swollen glands, fever, dry cough, body aches and headaches.\n\n[byline: Jay Greene, Makenzie O'Keefe, Carly Moore]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A few days ago, there was a report of another dead rabbit infected with _Francicella tularensis_ in Whitewater, CO, about 250 miles west (see ProMED-mail post no. 20170423.4988936).\n\nTularemia is caused by the Gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. A Mesa County couple called health officials after finding the rabbit on their property. \"We've lived out here for over 20 years,\" said [CW]. \"We have a lot of coyotes, bobcats different things, badgers are out here.\"\n\nHealth officials said they have discovered rabbit fever in neighborhoods east and west of the Colorado National Monument.\n\n\"This particular rabbit like to go underneath my car; he hung out there most of the day. One day I came out here and he was dead,\" said [W]. \"I bagged it up and took it to the health department, so they examined it and they called me a couple days later saying it was positive for the rabbit disease.\"\n\nHomeowners who see multiple animals on their properties should call Mesa County Public Health right away, as it could be a sign of unusual disease activity in the area. \"In the last few years, we've seen an uptick in detecting it in wildlife and in people,\" explained Thomas Orr, an epidemiologist with Mesa County Public Health. \"We really want to get the message out so people don't get ill with this. If they do have sick pets or get sick themselves, it is treatable.\"\n\nBureau of Land Management spokesperson Chris Joyner said the disease is most common near the river. \"We've seen a lot of cases of Tularemia connected to the river corridors in our high use areas along the river. We have a lot recreation that takes place there,\" he said.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said to use masks when mowing the lawn to reduce inhaling bacteria. Experts also suggest cooking game meat thoroughly before eating. Tularemia is treatable, according to health officials. They said to contact your health care provider if you notice symptoms including infected ulcer-like bite, swollen glands, fever, dry cough, body aches and headaches.\n\n[byline: Jay Greene, Makenzie O'Keefe, Carly Moore]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A few days ago, there was a report of another dead rabbit infected with _Francicella tularensis_ in Whitewater, CO, about 250 miles west (see ProMED-mail post no. 20170423.4988936).\n\nTularemia is caused by the Gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Tularemia is largely confined to the northern hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the southern hemisphere._Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_(Type A) is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/awKN. - USA (06): (CO) wild rabbit", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5127076", "date": "2017-05-05 17:37:07", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (04): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 3 May 2017 7:53 AM\nSource: News Channel 13 abc [edited]\nhttp://www.kjct8.com/content/news/Dead-rabbit-421157643.html\n\n\nMesa County Public Health officials said a dead rabbit in Whitewater tested positive for tularemia, also known as rabbit fever. A Mesa County couple called health officials after finding the rabbit on their property. \"We've lived out here for over 20 years,\" said [CW]. \"We have a lot of coyotes, bobcats different things, badgers are out here.\"\n\nHealth officials said they have discovered rabbit fever in neighborhoods east and west of the Colorado National Monument.\n\n\"This particular rabbit like to go underneath my car; he hung out there most of the day. One day I came out here and he was dead,\" said [W]. \"I bagged it up and took it to the health department, so they examined it and they called me a couple days later saying it was positive for the rabbit disease.\"\n\nHomeowners who see multiple animals on their properties should call Mesa County Public Health right away, as it could be a sign of unusual disease activity in the area. \"In the last few years, we've seen an uptick in detecting it in wildlife and in people,\" explained Thomas Orr, an epidemiologist with Mesa County Public Health. \"We really want to get the message out so people don't get ill with this. If they do have sick pets or get sick themselves, it is treatable.\"\n\nBureau of Land Management spokesperson Chris Joyner said the disease is most common near the river. \"We've seen a lot of cases of Tularemia connected to the river corridors in our high use areas along the river. We have a lot recreation that takes place there,\" he said.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said to use masks when mowing the lawn to reduce inhaling bacteria. Experts also suggest cooking game meat thoroughly before eating. Tularemia is treatable, according to health officials. They said to contact your health care provider if you notice symptoms including infected ulcer-like bite, swollen glands, fever, dry cough, body aches and headaches.\n\n[byline: Jay Greene, Makenzie O'Keefe, Carly Moore]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A few days ago, there was a report of another dead rabbit infected with _Francicella tularensis_ in Whitewater, CO, about 250 miles west (see ProMED-mail post no. 20170423.4988936).\n\nTularemia is caused by the Gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Tularemia is largely confined to the northern hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the southern hemisphere._Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_(Type A) is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/awKN. - Australia: (NS) possum", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5031168", "date": "2017-05-05 17:37:07", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (04): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 3 May 2017 7:53 AM\nSource: News Channel 13 abc [edited]\nhttp://www.kjct8.com/content/news/Dead-rabbit-421157643.html\n\n\nMesa County Public Health officials said a dead rabbit in Whitewater tested positive for tularemia, also known as rabbit fever. A Mesa County couple called health officials after finding the rabbit on their property. \"We've lived out here for over 20 years,\" said [CW]. \"We have a lot of coyotes, bobcats different things, badgers are out here.\"\n\nHealth officials said they have discovered rabbit fever in neighborhoods east and west of the Colorado National Monument.\n\n\"This particular rabbit like to go underneath my car; he hung out there most of the day. One day I came out here and he was dead,\" said [W]. \"I bagged it up and took it to the health department, so they examined it and they called me a couple days later saying it was positive for the rabbit disease.\"\n\nHomeowners who see multiple animals on their properties should call Mesa County Public Health right away, as it could be a sign of unusual disease activity in the area. \"In the last few years, we've seen an uptick in detecting it in wildlife and in people,\" explained Thomas Orr, an epidemiologist with Mesa County Public Health. \"We really want to get the message out so people don't get ill with this. If they do have sick pets or get sick themselves, it is treatable.\"\n\nBureau of Land Management spokesperson Chris Joyner said the disease is most common near the river. \"We've seen a lot of cases of Tularemia connected to the river corridors in our high use areas along the river. We have a lot recreation that takes place there,\" he said.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said to use masks when mowing the lawn to reduce inhaling bacteria. Experts also suggest cooking game meat thoroughly before eating. Tularemia is treatable, according to health officials. They said to contact your health care provider if you notice symptoms including infected ulcer-like bite, swollen glands, fever, dry cough, body aches and headaches.\n\n[byline: Jay Greene, Makenzie O'Keefe, Carly Moore]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A few days ago, there was a report of another dead rabbit infected with _Francicella tularensis_ in Whitewater, CO, about 250 miles west (see ProMED-mail post no. 20170423.4988936).\n\nTularemia is caused by the Gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Tularemia is largely confined to the northern hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the southern hemisphere._Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_(Type A) is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/awKN. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]\nSee Also\nTularemia - USA (03): increased northern spread, 1965-2013. 20170429.5003155\nTularemia - USA (02): (CO) wild rabbit 20170423.4988936\n2016\n---\nTularemia - USA (03): increased northern spread, 1965-2013", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5003155", "date": "2016-11-02 23:18:19", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (15): (COLORADO) HUMAN, WILDLIFE\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 1 Nov 2016\nSource: Craig Daily Press [edited]\nhttp://t.craigdailypress.com/news/2016/nov/01/rabbit-fever-confirmed-mesa-and-moffat-counties/?templates=tablet\n\n\nOne human, 2 wild animals and one domestic animal in Mesa County along with a domestic animal in Moffat County have tested positive for tularemia.\n\nAlso called rabbit fever, \"Tularemia is a fatal bacterial disease of rabbits and rodents that can spread to humans and other species,\" states the Colorado Parks and Wildlife fact sheet on tularemia.\n\nMore than 100 human cases of the disease were reported between January 2005 and August 2016 in Colorado. Of those, 16 cases occurred on the Western Slope in Delta (2), Eagle (2), Garfield (2), Grand (1), Gunnison (1), Mesa (5), Montrose (2) and Routt (1) counties, said the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment Tularemia Surveillance Report.\n\n\"Although tularemia can be life-threatening, most infections can be treated successfully with antibiotics,\" the CDC said. The majority of animals testing positive for the disease in Colorado were rabbits; however, other animals with the disease include: beavers, Colorado chipmunks, hamsters, mice, muskrats, prairie dogs, tree squirrels, coyote and fox, said the health department report.\n\n\"It's called rabbit fever but affects a wide variety of animals,\" said Mike Porras, CPW regional public information officer based in Grand Junction.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2015, 52 cases of human tularemia were reported in Colorado, more than 10 times the typical number of 0-4 cases reported annually from 1954-2013.\n\nThe state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9201. Mesa County in western Colorado can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]\nSee Also\nTularemia - USA (15): (COLORADO) HUMAN, WILDLIFE\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 1 Nov 2016\nSource: Craig Daily Press [edited]\nhttp://t.craigdailypress.com/news/2016/nov/01/rabbit-fever-confirmed-mesa-and-moffat-counties/?templates=tablet\n\n\nOne human, 2 wild animals and one domestic animal in Mesa County along with a domestic animal in Moffat County have tested positive for tularemia.\n\nAlso called rabbit fever, \"Tularemia is a fatal bacterial disease of rabbits and rodents that can spread to humans and other species,\" states the Colorado Parks and Wildlife fact sheet on tularemia.\n\nMore than 100 human cases of the disease were reported between January 2005 and August 2016 in Colorado. Of those, 16 cases occurred on the Western Slope in Delta (2), Eagle (2), Garfield (2), Grand (1), Gunnison (1), Mesa (5), Montrose (2) and Routt (1) counties, said the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment Tularemia Surveillance Report.\n\n\"Although tularemia can be life-threatening, most infections can be treated successfully with antibiotics,\" the CDC said. The majority of animals testing positive for the disease in Colorado were rabbits; however, other animals with the disease include: beavers, Colorado chipmunks, hamsters, mice, muskrats, prairie dogs, tree squirrels, coyote and fox, said the health department report.\n\n\"It's called rabbit fever but affects a wide variety of animals,\" said Mike Porras, CPW regional public information officer based in Grand Junction.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2015, 52 cases of human tularemia were reported in Colorado, more than 10 times the typical number of 0-4 cases reported annually from 1954-2013.\n\nThe state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9201. Netherlands 20160630.4317126", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4859944", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA: (MN ex SD) fish hook injury, 2016", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4859944", "date": "2016-11-02 23:18:19", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (15): (COLORADO) HUMAN, WILDLIFE\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 1 Nov 2016\nSource: Craig Daily Press [edited]\nhttp://t.craigdailypress.com/news/2016/nov/01/rabbit-fever-confirmed-mesa-and-moffat-counties/?templates=tablet\n\n\nOne human, 2 wild animals and one domestic animal in Mesa County along with a domestic animal in Moffat County have tested positive for tularemia.\n\nAlso called rabbit fever, \"Tularemia is a fatal bacterial disease of rabbits and rodents that can spread to humans and other species,\" states the Colorado Parks and Wildlife fact sheet on tularemia.\n\nMore than 100 human cases of the disease were reported between January 2005 and August 2016 in Colorado. Of those, 16 cases occurred on the Western Slope in Delta (2), Eagle (2), Garfield (2), Grand (1), Gunnison (1), Mesa (5), Montrose (2) and Routt (1) counties, said the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment Tularemia Surveillance Report.\n\n\"Although tularemia can be life-threatening, most infections can be treated successfully with antibiotics,\" the CDC said. The majority of animals testing positive for the disease in Colorado were rabbits; however, other animals with the disease include: beavers, Colorado chipmunks, hamsters, mice, muskrats, prairie dogs, tree squirrels, coyote and fox, said the health department report.\n\n\"It's called rabbit fever but affects a wide variety of animals,\" said Mike Porras, CPW regional public information officer based in Grand Junction.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2015, 52 cases of human tularemia were reported in Colorado, more than 10 times the typical number of 0-4 cases reported annually from 1954-2013.\n\nThe state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9201. Mesa County in western Colorado can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]\nSee Also\nTularemia - USA (15): (COLORADO) HUMAN, WILDLIFE\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 1 Nov 2016\nSource: Craig Daily Press [edited]\nhttp://t.craigdailypress.com/news/2016/nov/01/rabbit-fever-confirmed-mesa-and-moffat-counties/?templates=tablet\n\n\nOne human, 2 wild animals and one domestic animal in Mesa County along with a domestic animal in Moffat County have tested positive for tularemia.\n\nAlso called rabbit fever, \"Tularemia is a fatal bacterial disease of rabbits and rodents that can spread to humans and other species,\" states the Colorado Parks and Wildlife fact sheet on tularemia.\n\nMore than 100 human cases of the disease were reported between January 2005 and August 2016 in Colorado. Of those, 16 cases occurred on the Western Slope in Delta (2), Eagle (2), Garfield (2), Grand (1), Gunnison (1), Mesa (5), Montrose (2) and Routt (1) counties, said the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment Tularemia Surveillance Report.\n\n\"Although tularemia can be life-threatening, most infections can be treated successfully with antibiotics,\" the CDC said. The majority of animals testing positive for the disease in Colorado were rabbits; however, other animals with the disease include: beavers, Colorado chipmunks, hamsters, mice, muskrats, prairie dogs, tree squirrels, coyote and fox, said the health department report.\n\n\"It's called rabbit fever but affects a wide variety of animals,\" said Mike Porras, CPW regional public information officer based in Grand Junction.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2015, 52 cases of human tularemia were reported in Colorado, more than 10 times the typical number of 0-4 cases reported annually from 1954-2013.\n\nThe state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9201. Mesa County in western Colorado can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]\nSee Also\nTularemia - USA (14): (TX) 20161020.4572972\nTularemia - USA (13): (CO) 20160922.4505993\nTularemia - USA (12): (CO) human ex dog susp 20160903.4463335\nTularemia - USA (11): (CO) ulceroglandular 20160827.4445877\nTularemia - USA (10): (WY) 20160807.4396768\nTularemia - USA (09): (CO) wild rabbit 20160802.4388644\nTularemia - USA (08): (MN) feline 20160725.4366704\nTularemia - USA (07): (CO) wild rabbit 20160717.4350932\nTularemia - USA (06): (NM) increased range 20160713.4342491\nTularemia - USA (05): (AZ) fatal 20160708.4333270\nTularemia - USA (04): (CO) 20160630.4318916\nTularemia - Netherlands 20160630.4317126\nTularemia - USA (03): (CO) pneumonic 20160618.4295395\nPlague, tularemia - USA (NM) alert 20160615.4289092\nTularemia - USA (02): (MN) feline 20160603.4262502\nTularemia - USA: (MN,AK) feline, canine, lagomorph 20160529.4252246\n.................................................sb/ll/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-08-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Moffat County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Grand", "country": "Saint Martin"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mesa County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Grand Junction", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Netherlands 20160630.4317126", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4572972", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tularemia - USA (14): (TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4572972", "date": "2016-07-17 14:19:23", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (07): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 Jul 2016\nSource: KRDO [edited]\nhttp://www.krdo.com/news/Pueblo-County-rabbit-tests-positive-for-Tularemia/40732732\n\n\nPueblo County [Colorado] rabbit tests positive for tularemia\n------------------------------------------------------------\nRabbit fever has again been confirmed in Pueblo County.\n\nA rabbit that was collected from the Hatchet Ranch area in the southwestern part of the county has tested positive for tularemia.\n\n\"Pueblo residents are advised that tularemia-causing bacteria may be present in some of the mammals -- especially rabbits, rodents and hares, and on the ground where these animals may be active,\" said Vicki Carlton, program manager in the Environmental Health and Emergency Preparedness division at the Pueblo City-County Health Department. \"Although there are no human cases of tularemia identified in Pueblo so far this year [2016], Colorado has experienced human tularemia cases in people who have been exposed to contaminated soil, drinking contaminated water or inhaling bacteria,\" she said.\n\nTypical signs of infection in humans include fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, chest pain, and coughing. Tularemia can be effectively treated with antibiotics; therefore should you have any of these early signs, contact your medical provider.\n\nDogs and cats also get tularemia by eating infected rabbits or other rodents and through tick and deer fly bites. If your pet shows symptoms of illness including fever, nasal and eye discharge, and skin sores, take it to a veterinarian promptly. Tularemia is easily treated if diagnosed early in dogs and cats.\n\nRecommended precautions include:\n\n- Avoid handling wild animals.\n\n- When outdoors near places where wild rabbits or rodents are present, wear insect repellent containing DEET.\n\n- Use a dust mask when mowing or doing yard work. Do not mow over animal carcasses.\n\n- Leash your pets when outdoors and keep them away from dead animals.\n\n- Routinely use a tick and flea prevention treatment on pets.\n\n- If a dead animal must be moved, avoid direct contact with it. Wear insect repellent to protect yourself from its fleas or ticks, and use a long-handled shovel to scoop it up. Place it in a garbage bag and dispose in an outdoor trash receptacle. Wash your hands with soap and water afterwards.\n\n- Wear proper footwear outdoors where dead animals have been found.\n\n- Do not go barefoot or wear sandals while gardening, mowing or landscaping.\n\n- Wear gloves while gardening or landscaping, and wash your hands after these activities.\n\n- Do not drink unpurified water from streams or lakes or allow your pets to drink surface waters.\n\n- If you hunt, trap or skin animals, take additional steps: Use impervious gloves when skinning or handling animals, especially rabbits. Cook the meat of wild rabbits thoroughly to a temperature of 165 degrees F or higher.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following information is quoted from \"Tularemia Surveillance\" (last modified on 24 Jul 2015) on the APHIS-USDA National Wildlife Disease Program (NWDP) website, available at https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/ourfocus/wildlifedamage/programs/SA_NWDP/CT_Tularemia.\n\n\"Tularemia has been identified as a disease of concern to human, wildlife and domestic animal populations within the United States. It, like plague, is considered a 'Category A' disease by the Department of Homeland Security, meaning it could potentially be used as a bioterrorist agent.\n\nLocation\nTularemia is found most often in the South-Central and Western US, mostly in rural areas. It is also found internationally, throughout the Northern Hemisphere in places like Japan, Russia and Scandinavia.\n\nDisease Agent\nTularemia is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_.\n\nAffected Species\nTularemia mostly affects, and is reservoired within, a variety of mammals including (but not limited to) beavers, water voles, rabbits, hares, skunks and coyotes.\n\nThe disease is not contagious from human to human, but can be spread by the bites of fleas, ticks and other arthropods that have fed on infected wildlife, or by contact with the carcass of the infected animal. Reported human cases of tularemia in the United States currently average about 200 yearly, a dramatic reduction from the over 1000 cases per year that occurred in the 1930s and 1940s.\n\nNWDP Activities\nNWDP biologists and their collaborators are currently sampling aquatic rodents and other susceptible species across the US to detect the presence of tularemia antibodies in their blood. Due to the focus on early detection, local health professionals can be alerted when tularemia is present in a region and take this into consideration when examining certain symptoms.\n\nIn humans, tularemia 1st emerges as a flu-like illness. Depending on the method of exposure to the bacterium, infected individuals may also experience lesions, swollen lymph glands and even the development of pneumonia. When these symptoms are positively identified as tularemia, they can be treated with prescription antibiotics.\" - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/903.]\nSee Also\nTularemia - USA (09): (CO) muskrat, alert 20150728.3542178\nTularemia - USA (08): (ND): human, animal 20150726.3537551\nTularemia - USA (07): (NM) 20150715.3510564\nTularemia - USA (06): (CO) rabbit, alert 20150703.3482641\nTularemia - USA (05): (AK) susp. 20150702.3480207\nTularemia - USA (04): (CO) rabbit, dog 20150702.3479571\nTularemia - USA (03): (CO) 20150626.3467769\nTularemia - USA (02): (CO) 20150603.3403896\nTularemia - USA: (CO) 20150522.3379806\n.................................................sb/crd/je/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-07-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Pueblo City - USA (12): (CO) human ex dog susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4463335", "date": "2016-07-17 14:19:23", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (07): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 Jul 2016\nSource: KRDO [edited]\nhttp://www.krdo.com/news/Pueblo-County-rabbit-tests-positive-for-Tularemia/40732732\n\n\nPueblo County [Colorado] rabbit tests positive for tularemia\n------------------------------------------------------------\nRabbit fever has again been confirmed in Pueblo County.\n\nA rabbit that was collected from the Hatchet Ranch area in the southwestern part of the county has tested positive for tularemia.\n\n\"Pueblo residents are advised that tularemia-causing bacteria may be present in some of the mammals -- especially rabbits, rodents and hares, and on the ground where these animals may be active,\" said Vicki Carlton, program manager in the Environmental Health and Emergency Preparedness division at the Pueblo City-County Health Department. \"Although there are no human cases of tularemia identified in Pueblo so far this year [2016], Colorado has experienced human tularemia cases in people who have been exposed to contaminated soil, drinking contaminated water or inhaling bacteria,\" she said.\n\nTypical signs of infection in humans include fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, chest pain, and coughing. Tularemia can be effectively treated with antibiotics; therefore should you have any of these early signs, contact your medical provider.\n\nDogs and cats also get tularemia by eating infected rabbits or other rodents and through tick and deer fly bites. If your pet shows symptoms of illness including fever, nasal and eye discharge, and skin sores, take it to a veterinarian promptly. Tularemia is easily treated if diagnosed early in dogs and cats.\n\nRecommended precautions include:\n\n- Avoid handling wild animals.\n\n- When outdoors near places where wild rabbits or rodents are present, wear insect repellent containing DEET.\n\n- Use a dust mask when mowing or doing yard work. Do not mow over animal carcasses.\n\n- Leash your pets when outdoors and keep them away from dead animals.\n\n- Routinely use a tick and flea prevention treatment on pets.\n\n- If a dead animal must be moved, avoid direct contact with it. Wear insect repellent to protect yourself from its fleas or ticks, and use a long-handled shovel to scoop it up. Place it in a garbage bag and dispose in an outdoor trash receptacle. Wash your hands with soap and water afterwards.\n\n- Wear proper footwear outdoors where dead animals have been found.\n\n- Do not go barefoot or wear sandals while gardening, mowing or landscaping.\n\n- Wear gloves while gardening or landscaping, and wash your hands after these activities.\n\n- Do not drink unpurified water from streams or lakes or allow your pets to drink surface waters.\n\n- If you hunt, trap or skin animals, take additional steps: Use impervious gloves when skinning or handling animals, especially rabbits. Cook the meat of wild rabbits thoroughly to a temperature of 165 degrees F or higher.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following information is quoted from \"Tularemia Surveillance\" (last modified on 24 Jul 2015) on the APHIS-USDA National Wildlife Disease Program (NWDP) website, available at https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/ourfocus/wildlifedamage/programs/SA_NWDP/CT_Tularemia.\n\n\"Tularemia has been identified as a disease of concern to human, wildlife and domestic animal populations within the United States. It, like plague, is considered a 'Category A' disease by the Department of Homeland Security, meaning it could potentially be used as a bioterrorist agent.\n\nLocation\nTularemia is found most often in the South-Central and Western US, mostly in rural areas. It is also found internationally, throughout the Northern Hemisphere in places like Japan, Russia and Scandinavia.\n\nDisease Agent\nTularemia is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_.\n\nAffected Species\nTularemia mostly affects, and is reservoired within, a variety of mammals including (but not limited to) beavers, water voles, rabbits, hares, skunks and coyotes.\n\nThe disease is not contagious from human to human, but can be spread by the bites of fleas, ticks and other arthropods that have fed on infected wildlife, or by contact with the carcass of the infected animal. Reported human cases of tularemia in the United States currently average about 200 yearly, a dramatic reduction from the over 1000 cases per year that occurred in the 1930s and 1940s.\n\nNWDP Activities\nNWDP biologists and their collaborators are currently sampling aquatic rodents and other susceptible species across the US to detect the presence of tularemia antibodies in their blood. Due to the focus on early detection, local health professionals can be alerted when tularemia is present in a region and take this into consideration when examining certain symptoms.\n\nIn humans, tularemia 1st emerges as a flu-like illness. Depending on the method of exposure to the bacterium, infected individuals may also experience lesions, swollen lymph glands and even the development of pneumonia. When these symptoms are positively identified as tularemia, they can be treated with prescription antibiotics.\" - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/903.]\nSee Also\nTularemia - USA (06): (NM) increased range 20160713.4342491\nTularemia - USA (05): (AZ) fatal 20160708.4333270\nTularemia - USA (04): (CO) 20160630.4318916\nTularemia - USA (03): (CO) pneumonic 20160618.4295395\nPlague, tularemia - USA (NM) alert 20160615.4289092\nTularemia - USA (02): (MN) feline 20160603.4262502\nTularemia - USA: (MN,AK) feline, canine, lagomorph 20160529.4252246\n2015\n----\nTularemia - USA (18) 20151205.3842058\nTularemia - USA (17): (WY, NE) 20150925.3670429\nTularemia - USA (16): (AZ) rabbits 20150830.3612365\nTularemia - USA (15): (CO) rabbits 20150828.3608721\nTularemia - USA (14): (WY) fatality 20150825.3599260\nTularemia - USA (13): (NM, WY, AZ) human, animal 20150819.3580618\nTularemia - USA (12): (AK) hare, human 20150818.3586385\nTularemia - USA (11): (WY) rabbit 20150802.3553047\nTularemia - USA (10): (CO, SD) 20150801.3548673\nTularemia - USA (09): (CO) muskrat, alert 20150728.3542178\nTularemia - USA (08): (ND): human, animal 20150726.3537551\nTularemia - USA (07): (NM) 20150715.3510564\nTularemia - USA (06): (CO) rabbit, alert 20150703.3482641\nTularemia - USA (05): (AK) susp. 20150702.3480207\nTularemia - USA (04): (CO) rabbit, dog 20150702.3479571\nTularemia - USA (03): (CO) 20150626.3467769\nTularemia - USA (02): (CO) 20150603.3403896\nTularemia - USA: (CO) 20150522.3379806\n.................................................sb/crd/je/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-07-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Pueblo City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Pueblo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4445877", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (11): (CO) ulceroglandular", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4445877", "date": "2016-07-17 14:19:23", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (07): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 Jul 2016\nSource: KRDO [edited]\nhttp://www.krdo.com/news/Pueblo-County-rabbit-tests-positive-for-Tularemia/40732732\n\n\nPueblo County [Colorado] rabbit tests positive for tularemia\n------------------------------------------------------------\nRabbit fever has again been confirmed in Pueblo County.\n\nA rabbit that was collected from the Hatchet Ranch area in the southwestern part of the county has tested positive for tularemia.\n\n\"Pueblo residents are advised that tularemia-causing bacteria may be present in some of the mammals -- especially rabbits, rodents and hares, and on the ground where these animals may be active,\" said Vicki Carlton, program manager in the Environmental Health and Emergency Preparedness division at the Pueblo City-County Health Department. \"Although there are no human cases of tularemia identified in Pueblo so far this year [2016], Colorado has experienced human tularemia cases in people who have been exposed to contaminated soil, drinking contaminated water or inhaling bacteria,\" she said.\n\nTypical signs of infection in humans include fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, chest pain, and coughing. Tularemia can be effectively treated with antibiotics; therefore should you have any of these early signs, contact your medical provider.\n\nDogs and cats also get tularemia by eating infected rabbits or other rodents and through tick and deer fly bites. If your pet shows symptoms of illness including fever, nasal and eye discharge, and skin sores, take it to a veterinarian promptly. Tularemia is easily treated if diagnosed early in dogs and cats.\n\nRecommended precautions include:\n\n- Avoid handling wild animals.\n\n- When outdoors near places where wild rabbits or rodents are present, wear insect repellent containing DEET.\n\n- Use a dust mask when mowing or doing yard work. Do not mow over animal carcasses.\n\n- Leash your pets when outdoors and keep them away from dead animals.\n\n- Routinely use a tick and flea prevention treatment on pets.\n\n- If a dead animal must be moved, avoid direct contact with it. Wear insect repellent to protect yourself from its fleas or ticks, and use a long-handled shovel to scoop it up. Place it in a garbage bag and dispose in an outdoor trash receptacle. Wash your hands with soap and water afterwards.\n\n- Wear proper footwear outdoors where dead animals have been found.\n\n- Do not go barefoot or wear sandals while gardening, mowing or landscaping.\n\n- Wear gloves while gardening or landscaping, and wash your hands after these activities.\n\n- Do not drink unpurified water from streams or lakes or allow your pets to drink surface waters.\n\n- If you hunt, trap or skin animals, take additional steps: Use impervious gloves when skinning or handling animals, especially rabbits. Cook the meat of wild rabbits thoroughly to a temperature of 165 degrees F or higher.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following information is quoted from \"Tularemia Surveillance\" (last modified on 24 Jul 2015) on the APHIS-USDA National Wildlife Disease Program (NWDP) website, available at https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/ourfocus/wildlifedamage/programs/SA_NWDP/CT_Tularemia.\n\n\"Tularemia has been identified as a disease of concern to human, wildlife and domestic animal populations within the United States. It, like plague, is considered a 'Category A' disease by the Department of Homeland Security, meaning it could potentially be used as a bioterrorist agent.\n\nLocation\nTularemia is found most often in the South-Central and Western US, mostly in rural areas. It is also found internationally, throughout the Northern Hemisphere in places like Japan, Russia and Scandinavia.\n\nDisease Agent\nTularemia is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_.\n\nAffected Species\nTularemia mostly affects, and is reservoired within, a variety of mammals including (but not limited to) beavers, water voles, rabbits, hares, skunks and coyotes.\n\nThe disease is not contagious from human to human, but can be spread by the bites of fleas, ticks and other arthropods that have fed on infected wildlife, or by contact with the carcass of the infected animal. Reported human cases of tularemia in the United States currently average about 200 yearly, a dramatic reduction from the over 1000 cases per year that occurred in the 1930s and 1940s.\n\nNWDP Activities\nNWDP biologists and their collaborators are currently sampling aquatic rodents and other susceptible species across the US to detect the presence of tularemia antibodies in their blood. Due to the focus on early detection, local health professionals can be alerted when tularemia is present in a region and take this into consideration when examining certain symptoms.\n\nIn humans, tularemia 1st emerges as a flu-like illness. Depending on the method of exposure to the bacterium, infected individuals may also experience lesions, swollen lymph glands and even the development of pneumonia. When these symptoms are positively identified as tularemia, they can be treated with prescription antibiotics.\" - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/903.]\nSee Also\nTularemia - USA (09): (CO) wild rabbit", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4388644", "date": "2016-07-17 14:19:23", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (07): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 Jul 2016\nSource: KRDO [edited]\nhttp://www.krdo.com/news/Pueblo-County-rabbit-tests-positive-for-Tularemia/40732732\n\n\nPueblo County [Colorado] rabbit tests positive for tularemia\n------------------------------------------------------------\nRabbit fever has again been confirmed in Pueblo County.\n\nA rabbit that was collected from the Hatchet Ranch area in the southwestern part of the county has tested positive for tularemia.\n\n\"Pueblo residents are advised that tularemia-causing bacteria may be present in some of the mammals -- especially rabbits, rodents and hares, and on the ground where these animals may be active,\" said Vicki Carlton, program manager in the Environmental Health and Emergency Preparedness division at the Pueblo City-County Health Department. \"Although there are no human cases of tularemia identified in Pueblo so far this year [2016], Colorado has experienced human tularemia cases in people who have been exposed to contaminated soil, drinking contaminated water or inhaling bacteria,\" she said.\n\nTypical signs of infection in humans include fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, chest pain, and coughing. Tularemia can be effectively treated with antibiotics; therefore should you have any of these early signs, contact your medical provider.\n\nDogs and cats also get tularemia by eating infected rabbits or other rodents and through tick and deer fly bites. If your pet shows symptoms of illness including fever, nasal and eye discharge, and skin sores, take it to a veterinarian promptly. Tularemia is easily treated if diagnosed early in dogs and cats.\n\nRecommended precautions include:\n\n- Avoid handling wild animals.\n\n- When outdoors near places where wild rabbits or rodents are present, wear insect repellent containing DEET.\n\n- Use a dust mask when mowing or doing yard work. Do not mow over animal carcasses.\n\n- Leash your pets when outdoors and keep them away from dead animals.\n\n- Routinely use a tick and flea prevention treatment on pets.\n\n- If a dead animal must be moved, avoid direct contact with it. Wear insect repellent to protect yourself from its fleas or ticks, and use a long-handled shovel to scoop it up. Place it in a garbage bag and dispose in an outdoor trash receptacle. Wash your hands with soap and water afterwards.\n\n- Wear proper footwear outdoors where dead animals have been found.\n\n- Do not go barefoot or wear sandals while gardening, mowing or landscaping.\n\n- Wear gloves while gardening or landscaping, and wash your hands after these activities.\n\n- Do not drink unpurified water from streams or lakes or allow your pets to drink surface waters.\n\n- If you hunt, trap or skin animals, take additional steps: Use impervious gloves when skinning or handling animals, especially rabbits. Cook the meat of wild rabbits thoroughly to a temperature of 165 degrees F or higher.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following information is quoted from \"Tularemia Surveillance\" (last modified on 24 Jul 2015) on the APHIS-USDA National Wildlife Disease Program (NWDP) website, available at https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/ourfocus/wildlifedamage/programs/SA_NWDP/CT_Tularemia.\n\n\"Tularemia has been identified as a disease of concern to human, wildlife and domestic animal populations within the United States. It, like plague, is considered a 'Category A' disease by the Department of Homeland Security, meaning it could potentially be used as a bioterrorist agent.\n\nLocation\nTularemia is found most often in the South-Central and Western US, mostly in rural areas. It is also found internationally, throughout the Northern Hemisphere in places like Japan, Russia and Scandinavia.\n\nDisease Agent\nTularemia is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_.\n\nAffected Species\nTularemia mostly affects, and is reservoired within, a variety of mammals including (but not limited to) beavers, water voles, rabbits, hares, skunks and coyotes.\n\nThe disease is not contagious from human to human, but can be spread by the bites of fleas, ticks and other arthropods that have fed on infected wildlife, or by contact with the carcass of the infected animal. Reported human cases of tularemia in the United States currently average about 200 yearly, a dramatic reduction from the over 1000 cases per year that occurred in the 1930s and 1940s.\n\nNWDP Activities\nNWDP biologists and their collaborators are currently sampling aquatic rodents and other susceptible species across the US to detect the presence of tularemia antibodies in their blood. Due to the focus on early detection, local health professionals can be alerted when tularemia is present in a region and take this into consideration when examining certain symptoms.\n\nIn humans, tularemia 1st emerges as a flu-like illness. Depending on the method of exposure to the bacterium, infected individuals may also experience lesions, swollen lymph glands and even the development of pneumonia. When these symptoms are positively identified as tularemia, they can be treated with prescription antibiotics.\" - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/903.]\nSee Also\nTularemia - USA (NM) alert 20160615.4289092\nTularemia - USA (02): (MN) feline 20160603.4262502\nTularemia - USA: (MN,AK) feline, canine, lagomorph 20160529.4252246\n2015\n----\nTularemia - USA (18) 20151205.3842058\nTularemia - USA (17): (WY, NE) 20150925.3670429\nTularemia - USA (16): (AZ) rabbits 20150830.3612365\nTularemia - USA (15): (CO) rabbits 20150828.3608721\nTularemia - USA (14): (WY) fatality 20150825.3599260\nTularemia - USA (13): (NM, WY, AZ) human, animal 20150819.3580618\nTularemia - USA (12): (AK) hare, human 20150818.3586385\nTularemia - USA (11): (WY) rabbit 20150802.3553047\nTularemia - USA (10): (CO, SD) 20150801.3548673\nTularemia - USA (09): (CO) muskrat, alert 20150728.3542178\nTularemia - USA (08): (ND): human, animal 20150726.3537551\nTularemia - USA (07): (NM) 20150715.3510564\nTularemia - USA (06): (CO) rabbit, alert 20150703.3482641\nTularemia - USA (05): (AK) susp. 20150702.3480207\nTularemia - USA (04): (CO) rabbit, dog 20150702.3479571\nTularemia - USA (03): (CO) 20150626.3467769\nTularemia - USA (02): (CO) 20150603.3403896\nTularemia - USA: (CO) 20150522.3379806\n.................................................sb/crd/je/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-07-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Pueblo City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Pueblo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4366704", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (08): (MN) feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4366704", "date": "2016-07-17 14:19:23", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (07): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 Jul 2016\nSource: KRDO [edited]\nhttp://www.krdo.com/news/Pueblo-County-rabbit-tests-positive-for-Tularemia/40732732\n\n\nPueblo County [Colorado] rabbit tests positive for tularemia\n------------------------------------------------------------\nRabbit fever has again been confirmed in Pueblo County.\n\nA rabbit that was collected from the Hatchet Ranch area in the southwestern part of the county has tested positive for tularemia.\n\n\"Pueblo residents are advised that tularemia-causing bacteria may be present in some of the mammals -- especially rabbits, rodents and hares, and on the ground where these animals may be active,\" said Vicki Carlton, program manager in the Environmental Health and Emergency Preparedness division at the Pueblo City-County Health Department. \"Although there are no human cases of tularemia identified in Pueblo so far this year [2016], Colorado has experienced human tularemia cases in people who have been exposed to contaminated soil, drinking contaminated water or inhaling bacteria,\" she said.\n\nTypical signs of infection in humans include fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, chest pain, and coughing. Tularemia can be effectively treated with antibiotics; therefore should you have any of these early signs, contact your medical provider.\n\nDogs and cats also get tularemia by eating infected rabbits or other rodents and through tick and deer fly bites. If your pet shows symptoms of illness including fever, nasal and eye discharge, and skin sores, take it to a veterinarian promptly. Tularemia is easily treated if diagnosed early in dogs and cats.\n\nRecommended precautions include:\n\n- Avoid handling wild animals.\n\n- When outdoors near places where wild rabbits or rodents are present, wear insect repellent containing DEET.\n\n- Use a dust mask when mowing or doing yard work. Do not mow over animal carcasses.\n\n- Leash your pets when outdoors and keep them away from dead animals.\n\n- Routinely use a tick and flea prevention treatment on pets.\n\n- If a dead animal must be moved, avoid direct contact with it. Wear insect repellent to protect yourself from its fleas or ticks, and use a long-handled shovel to scoop it up. Place it in a garbage bag and dispose in an outdoor trash receptacle. Wash your hands with soap and water afterwards.\n\n- Wear proper footwear outdoors where dead animals have been found.\n\n- Do not go barefoot or wear sandals while gardening, mowing or landscaping.\n\n- Wear gloves while gardening or landscaping, and wash your hands after these activities.\n\n- Do not drink unpurified water from streams or lakes or allow your pets to drink surface waters.\n\n- If you hunt, trap or skin animals, take additional steps: Use impervious gloves when skinning or handling animals, especially rabbits. Cook the meat of wild rabbits thoroughly to a temperature of 165 degrees F or higher.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following information is quoted from \"Tularemia Surveillance\" (last modified on 24 Jul 2015) on the APHIS-USDA National Wildlife Disease Program (NWDP) website, available at https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/ourfocus/wildlifedamage/programs/SA_NWDP/CT_Tularemia.\n\n\"Tularemia has been identified as a disease of concern to human, wildlife and domestic animal populations within the United States. It, like plague, is considered a 'Category A' disease by the Department of Homeland Security, meaning it could potentially be used as a bioterrorist agent.\n\nLocation\nTularemia is found most often in the South-Central and Western US, mostly in rural areas. It is also found internationally, throughout the Northern Hemisphere in places like Japan, Russia and Scandinavia.\n\nDisease Agent\nTularemia is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_.\n\nAffected Species\nTularemia mostly affects, and is reservoired within, a variety of mammals including (but not limited to) beavers, water voles, rabbits, hares, skunks and coyotes.\n\nThe disease is not contagious from human to human, but can be spread by the bites of fleas, ticks and other arthropods that have fed on infected wildlife, or by contact with the carcass of the infected animal. Reported human cases of tularemia in the United States currently average about 200 yearly, a dramatic reduction from the over 1000 cases per year that occurred in the 1930s and 1940s.\n\nNWDP Activities\nNWDP biologists and their collaborators are currently sampling aquatic rodents and other susceptible species across the US to detect the presence of tularemia antibodies in their blood. Due to the focus on early detection, local health professionals can be alerted when tularemia is present in a region and take this into consideration when examining certain symptoms.\n\nIn humans, tularemia 1st emerges as a flu-like illness. Depending on the method of exposure to the bacterium, infected individuals may also experience lesions, swollen lymph glands and even the development of pneumonia. When these symptoms are positively identified as tularemia, they can be treated with prescription antibiotics.\" - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/903.]\nSee Also\nTularemia -
