USA (03): (NM) human, feline, canine, alert 20130628.1797147\n.................................................sb/ll/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3537551", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (08): (ND): human, animal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3537551", "date": "2015-07-26 12:59:52", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (09): (NEBRASKA, WYOMING), ALERT\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 21 Jul 2015\nSource: KOTA-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.kotatv.com/news/nebraska-news/sb-county-health-department-announces-an-increase-in-tularemia-cases/34279732\n\n\nThe Scotts Bluff County Health Department has been notified of a significant increase in positive tularemia cases in the county and eastern Wyoming over the past couple weeks. According to their press release, tularemia, also known as rabbit fever or deer fly fever, is a bacterial disease associated with various animal species. It frequently affects rabbits, hares and rodents and has been associated with rabbit and rodent die-offs.\n\nHumans can be infected with the bacteria through many different sources including through the bite of an infected insect, usually a tick or deerfly, handling infected animal carcasses, consuming contaminated food or water, or by inhalation of the bacteria. Tularemia is treatable with appropriate antimicrobials.\n\nSymptoms usually appear 3 to 5 days after exposure and can include a sudden high fever, headaches, swollen lymph nodes, muscle and joint pain and a sore or lesion at the site where the bacteria entered the body.\n\nTo avoid exposure to tularemia, the Scotts Bluff County Health Department encourages people to avoid handling sick or dead animals, wear rubber gloves when skinning or handling animals, cook meat thoroughly, use protective clothing and insect repellents to avoid deer-fly and tick bites, avoid untreated drinking water, and use DEET or other tick repellents during tick season.\n\n[Byline: Sydney Kern]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not apparently related to bioterrorism in this case, tularemia is a category A bioterrorism agent, and the pneumonic form is likely to be the one associated with intentional spread.\n\nTularemia is caused by _Francisella tularensis_, a small, non-motile, Gram negative intracellular coccobacillus. It can be found in a variety of animal hosts, notably lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), aquatic rodents (muskrats, beavers, and water voles), other rodents (water and wood rats and mice), squirrels, and cats. In the United States an outbreak involving commercially distributed prairie dogs occurred in 2002.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as, _Acanthamoeba_), which can become airborne in some settings, and may represent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. In one case, bacteria were aerosolized from the fur of a dog as it shook itself off after entering a home. Finally, there are several reports of tularemia in humans following bites from infected domestic cats. It is highly infectious, with as few as 10 organisms needed to cause disease. Humans can develop severe and sometimes fatal illness but do not transmit the disease to others. The typical incubation period is 3-5 days, with a range of 1-14 days. - Mod.LL\n\nProMED HealthMaps:\nNebraska: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/229,\nWyoming: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251.]\nSee Also\nTularemia - USA (09): (NE, WY) alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3537025", "date": "2015-07-26 12:59:52", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (09): (NEBRASKA, WYOMING), ALERT\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 21 Jul 2015\nSource: KOTA-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.kotatv.com/news/nebraska-news/sb-county-health-department-announces-an-increase-in-tularemia-cases/34279732\n\n\nThe Scotts Bluff County Health Department has been notified of a significant increase in positive tularemia cases in the county and eastern Wyoming over the past couple weeks. According to their press release, tularemia, also known as rabbit fever or deer fly fever, is a bacterial disease associated with various animal species. It frequently affects rabbits, hares and rodents and has been associated with rabbit and rodent die-offs.\n\nHumans can be infected with the bacteria through many different sources including through the bite of an infected insect, usually a tick or deerfly, handling infected animal carcasses, consuming contaminated food or water, or by inhalation of the bacteria. Tularemia is treatable with appropriate antimicrobials.\n\nSymptoms usually appear 3 to 5 days after exposure and can include a sudden high fever, headaches, swollen lymph nodes, muscle and joint pain and a sore or lesion at the site where the bacteria entered the body.\n\nTo avoid exposure to tularemia, the Scotts Bluff County Health Department encourages people to avoid handling sick or dead animals, wear rubber gloves when skinning or handling animals, cook meat thoroughly, use protective clothing and insect repellents to avoid deer-fly and tick bites, avoid untreated drinking water, and use DEET or other tick repellents during tick season.\n\n[Byline: Sydney Kern]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not apparently related to bioterrorism in this case, tularemia is a category A bioterrorism agent, and the pneumonic form is likely to be the one associated with intentional spread.\n\nTularemia is caused by _Francisella tularensis_, a small, non-motile, Gram negative intracellular coccobacillus. It can be found in a variety of animal hosts, notably lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), aquatic rodents (muskrats, beavers, and water voles), other rodents (water and wood rats and mice), squirrels, and cats. In the United States an outbreak involving commercially distributed prairie dogs occurred in 2002.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as, _Acanthamoeba_), which can become airborne in some settings, and may represent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. In one case, bacteria were aerosolized from the fur of a dog as it shook itself off after entering a home. Finally, there are several reports of tularemia in humans following bites from infected domestic cats. It is highly infectious, with as few as 10 organisms needed to cause disease. Humans can develop severe and sometimes fatal illness but do not transmit the disease to others. The typical incubation period is 3-5 days, with a range of 1-14 days. - Mod.LL\n\nProMED HealthMaps:\nNebraska: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/229,\nWyoming: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251.]\nSee Also\nTularemia - USA (08): (WY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3520085", "date": "2015-06-03 04:39:45", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (02): (COLORADO)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 May 2015\nSource: The Denver Channel [edited]\nhttp://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/health/tularemia-patient-in-lafayette-dies-of-other-medical-complications\n\n\nFollowing increased reports of tularemia over the past few years, a patient who recently contracted the disease while gardening has died of other medical complications. Boulder County Public Health spokeswoman Chana Goussetis said the Lafayette resident tested positive for tularemia after developing symptoms of high fever, headache, and general malaise. It is believed the patient contracted the illness while mowing and gardening.\n\nWhile this person was the 1st to test positive for tularemia in Boulder County in 2015, the county health department says 3 other cases were reported elsewhere in Colorado. All were associated with people who had recently been gardening or landscaping. Seven animals have also tested positive for the disease in 2015.\n\n\"People become infected with tularemia through skin contact with infected animal tissue or through the bite of infected insects, most commonly ticks and deer flies,\" Goussetis said. \"The bacteria can also be inhaled when infected animal tissue is broken up into small particles and spread in the air, such as when an infected carcass is mowed over.\" In 2014, 16 people tested positive for the disease in Colorado, Goussetis said. Five of those were residents of Boulder County.\n\n\"Symptoms of tularemia include an abrupt onset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, difficulty breathing, bloody sputum, and respiratory failure,\" Goussetis said. \"Symptoms also include skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, diarrhea, or pneumonia. Tularemia is treatable when detected early.\"\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. Although hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be infected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are important in its ecology.\n\nHumans become infected through various mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type of exposure will dictate the form of the disease manifestation, with cutaneous exposures usually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms.\n\nThe state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4519. Boulder County in north central Colorado can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia - USA: (CO) 20150522.3379806\n2014\n---\nTularemia - USA (07): (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3510564", "date": "2015-06-03 04:39:45", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (02): (COLORADO)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 May 2015\nSource: The Denver Channel [edited]\nhttp://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/health/tularemia-patient-in-lafayette-dies-of-other-medical-complications\n\n\nFollowing increased reports of tularemia over the past few years, a patient who recently contracted the disease while gardening has died of other medical complications. Boulder County Public Health spokeswoman Chana Goussetis said the Lafayette resident tested positive for tularemia after developing symptoms of high fever, headache, and general malaise. It is believed the patient contracted the illness while mowing and gardening.\n\nWhile this person was the 1st to test positive for tularemia in Boulder County in 2015, the county health department says 3 other cases were reported elsewhere in Colorado. All were associated with people who had recently been gardening or landscaping. Seven animals have also tested positive for the disease in 2015.\n\n\"People become infected with tularemia through skin contact with infected animal tissue or through the bite of infected insects, most commonly ticks and deer flies,\" Goussetis said. \"The bacteria can also be inhaled when infected animal tissue is broken up into small particles and spread in the air, such as when an infected carcass is mowed over.\" In 2014, 16 people tested positive for the disease in Colorado, Goussetis said. Five of those were residents of Boulder County.\n\n\"Symptoms of tularemia include an abrupt onset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, difficulty breathing, bloody sputum, and respiratory failure,\" Goussetis said. \"Symptoms also include skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, diarrhea, or pneumonia. Tularemia is treatable when detected early.\"\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. Although hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be infected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are important in its ecology.\n\nHumans become infected through various mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type of exposure will dictate the form of the disease manifestation, with cutaneous exposures usually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms.\n\nThe state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4519. USA (06): (CO) rabbit, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3482641", "date": "2015-06-03 04:39:45", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (02): (COLORADO)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 May 2015\nSource: The Denver Channel [edited]\nhttp://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/health/tularemia-patient-in-lafayette-dies-of-other-medical-complications\n\n\nFollowing increased reports of tularemia over the past few years, a patient who recently contracted the disease while gardening has died of other medical complications. Boulder County Public Health spokeswoman Chana Goussetis said the Lafayette resident tested positive for tularemia after developing symptoms of high fever, headache, and general malaise. It is believed the patient contracted the illness while mowing and gardening.\n\nWhile this person was the 1st to test positive for tularemia in Boulder County in 2015, the county health department says 3 other cases were reported elsewhere in Colorado. All were associated with people who had recently been gardening or landscaping. Seven animals have also tested positive for the disease in 2015.\n\n\"People become infected with tularemia through skin contact with infected animal tissue or through the bite of infected insects, most commonly ticks and deer flies,\" Goussetis said. \"The bacteria can also be inhaled when infected animal tissue is broken up into small particles and spread in the air, such as when an infected carcass is mowed over.\" In 2014, 16 people tested positive for the disease in Colorado, Goussetis said. Five of those were residents of Boulder County.\n\n\"Symptoms of tularemia include an abrupt onset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, difficulty breathing, bloody sputum, and respiratory failure,\" Goussetis said. \"Symptoms also include skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, diarrhea, or pneumonia. Tularemia is treatable when detected early.\"\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. Although hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be infected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are important in its ecology.\n\nHumans become infected through various mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type of exposure will dictate the form of the disease manifestation, with cutaneous exposures usually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms.\n\nThe state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4519. Boulder County in north central Colorado can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia - USA: (CO) 20150522.3379806\n2014\n---\nTularemia - Boulder County Public Health spokeswoman Chana Goussetis said the Lafayette resident tested positive for tularemia after developing symptoms of high fever, headache, and general malaise. It is believed the patient contracted the illness while mowing and gardening.\n\nWhile this person was the 1st to test positive for tularemia in Boulder County in 2015, the county health department says 3 other cases were reported elsewhere in Colorado. All were associated with people who had recently been gardening or landscaping. Seven animals have also tested positive for the disease in 2015.\n\n\"People become infected with tularemia through skin contact with infected animal tissue or through the bite of infected insects, most commonly ticks and deer flies,\" Goussetis said. \"The bacteria can also be inhaled when infected animal tissue is broken up into small particles and spread in the air, such as when an infected carcass is mowed over.\" In 2014, 16 people tested positive for the disease in Colorado, Goussetis said. Five of those were residents of Boulder County.\n\n\"Symptoms of tularemia include an abrupt onset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, difficulty breathing, bloody sputum, and respiratory failure,\" Goussetis said. \"Symptoms also include skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, diarrhea, or pneumonia. Tularemia is treatable when detected early.\"\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. Although hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be infected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are important in its ecology.\n\nHumans become infected through various mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. It is believed the patient contracted the illness while mowing and gardening.\n\nWhile this person was the 1st to test positive for tularemia in Boulder County in 2015, the county health department says 3 other cases were reported elsewhere in Colorado. All were associated with people who had recently been gardening or landscaping. Seven animals have also tested positive for the disease in 2015.\n\n\"People become infected with tularemia through skin contact with infected animal tissue or through the bite of infected insects, most commonly ticks and deer flies,\" Goussetis said. \"The bacteria can also be inhaled when infected animal tissue is broken up into small particles and spread in the air, such as when an infected carcass is mowed over.\" In 2014, 16 people tested positive for the disease in Colorado, Goussetis said. Five of those were residents of Boulder County.\n\n\"Symptoms of tularemia include an abrupt onset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, difficulty breathing, bloody sputum, and respiratory failure,\" Goussetis said. \"Symptoms also include skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, diarrhea, or pneumonia. Tularemia is treatable when detected early.\"\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. Although hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be infected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are important in its ecology.\n\nHumans become infected through various mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type of exposure will dictate the form of the disease manifestation, with cutaneous exposures usually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms.\n\nThe state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4519. Boulder County in north central Colorado can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia - USA: (CO) 20150522.3379806\n2014\n---\nTularemia - USA (09): (CO) humans, beavers 20141206.3014671\nTularemia - USA (08): (CO) hunter warning 20141003.2829512\nTularemia - USA (07): (CO) 20140923.2798680\nTularemia - USA (06): (CO) 20140918.2783744\nTularemia - USA (05): (CO) 20140912.2763100\nTularemia - USA (04): (IL, CO) fatal 20140813.2684686\nTularemia - USA (03): (CA) feline 20140711.2602339\nTularemia - USA (02): (NM) 20140711.2601188\nTularemia - USA: (CO) rabbit 20140705.2589884\n2013\n---\nTularemia - USA (04): (NE) 20130629.1798960\nTularemia - USA (03): (NM) human, feline, canine, alert 20130628.1797147\nTularemia - USA (02): (NE) 20130624.1789311\nTularemia - USA: (NC) hunters 20130226.1560910\n.................................................ll/msp/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Boulder County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3380738", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, animal - Czech Republic: (MO) hare", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3380738", "date": "2014-09-12 13:43:44", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (05): (COLORADO)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Larimer County\n[2] Boulder County\n\n******\n[1] Larimer County\nDate: Fri 5 Sep 2014\nSource: The Coloradoan [edited]\nhttp://www.coloradoan.com/story/news/local/2014/09/05/second-human-case-tularemia-confirmed-larimer/15135067/\n\n\nA 2nd human case of tularemia was confirmed on Fri 5 Sep 2014. A Larimer County resident has been hospitalized. The unidentified resident is thought to have been infected with the potentially life-threatening bacteria while mowing tall grass in an area where infected rabbits were previously present, Larimer County Department of Health and Environment officials said.\n\nThe bacterium can be transmitted by handling of sick or dead animals infected with tularemia. Infection can also arise from the bite of infected insects (ticks and deer flies), by eating or drinking contaminated food or water and by the inhalation of airborne bacteria.\n\nA rabbit in southeast Fort Collins tested positive for tularemia in July 2014, putting many on heightened alert, primarily in areas around Trilby Road between Timberline Road and Fossil Creek and the northwest section of Fossil Creek Wetlands natural area.\n\nThe 1st case of a Larimer County resident sickened by tularemia surfaced in early August 2014.\n\nHow to prevent tularemia:\n- avoid handling dead animals;\n- leash your pets when outdoors and keep them away from dead animals;\n- if a dead animal must be moved, avoid direct contact with it. Put on a repellent to protect yourself from its fleas or ticks, and use a shovel to scoop it up. Place it in a plastic bag and dispose in an outdoor trash receptacle. Wash your hands;\n- when outdoors near places where rabbits or rodents are present, wear an insect repellent containing DEET;\n- keep pets confined and away from dead animals;\n- routinely use a tick and flea preventative on pets. Read the label and consult your veterinarian if you are unsure what to use.\n\n[Byline: Jason Pohl]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Acquiring _Francisella tularensis_ by lawn mowing usually causes pneumonia as the infection's manifestation. Skinning infected animals or acquiring the infection from a deer fly or tick bite will cause the ulceroglandular form. Oroglandular or oculoglandular forms can also occur depending on the site of exposure and a \"typhoidal\" form with bacteremia may occur. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] Boulder County\nDate: Thu 4 Sep 2014\nSource: CBS4 [edited]\nhttp://denver.cbslocal.com/2014/09/04/rabbit-fever-patient-released-from-hospital/\n\n\nAn infant from Longmont is recovering at home after being released from the hospital where he was treated for what's known at \"rabbit fever.\" The infant, just 10 weeks old, is the 1st human case of Tularemia in Boulder County. There have been at least 2 other cases in Broomfield and Larimer Counties. \"We get to go home. It's been a long couple of weeks,\" said the infant's mother.\n\nThe infant was released from Children's Hospital 14 days after contracting a disease that could have killed him. He's believed to have been exposed to tularemia at a family picnic after he was bitten by a tick. He was taken to Children's Hospital with a high fever and put on antibiotics. \"It [the temperature] got higher and higher so I took him in to the ER and once I got there they basically told me, 'Your baby's really sick and he's not leaving. He has to stay,'\" said the mother.\n\n\"This case was very lucky, they weren't very ill, they caught it very early,\" said Bolder County Public Health spokeswoman Kylie Chilton.\n\nOne case of rabbit fever was confirmed in a dead vole in a popular field in Boulder County. There are usually only 4 cases a year in Colorado but that has quadrupled in 2014 because heavy rain has fueled vegetation and given rabbits more places to live. \"As long as we continue to see warm temperatures and also these animals are around, then we may see that disease still,\" said Chilton.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nThe manifestations of tularemia are not specifically stated. Tularemia is not a very common infection in the USA and much less common in infants because they are usually not in circumstances where they would be exposed. Deer fly or tick-associated transmission is most likely in this infant. Although rashes, other than ulcers at the inoculation site, are not common, another report of tularemia in an infant described a vesicular rash (Byington CL, Bender JM, Ampofo K, et al: Tularemia with vesicular skin lesions may be mistaken for infection with herpes viruses. Clin Infect Dis 2008; 47(1): e4-e6; http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/47/1/e4.long). The authors point out that in Edward Francis' original description of the disease, he described a vesicular rash in one person and other studies have also reported rashes, including some with a vesicular component. - A Larimer County resident has been hospitalized. The unidentified resident is thought to have been infected with the potentially life-threatening bacteria while mowing tall grass in an area where infected rabbits were previously present, Larimer County Department of Health and Environment officials said.\n\nThe bacterium can be transmitted by handling of sick or dead animals infected with tularemia. Infection can also arise from the bite of infected insects (ticks and deer flies), by eating or drinking contaminated food or water and by the inhalation of airborne bacteria.\n\nA rabbit in southeast Fort Collins tested positive for tularemia in July 2014, putting many on heightened alert, primarily in areas around Trilby Road between Timberline Road and Fossil Creek and the northwest section of Fossil Creek Wetlands natural area.\n\nThe 1st case of a Larimer County resident sickened by tularemia surfaced in early August 2014.\n\nHow to prevent tularemia:\n- avoid handling dead animals;\n- leash your pets when outdoors and keep them away from dead animals;\n- if a dead animal must be moved, avoid direct contact with it. Put on a repellent to protect yourself from its fleas or ticks, and use a shovel to scoop it up. Place it in a plastic bag and dispose in an outdoor trash receptacle. Wash your hands;\n- when outdoors near places where rabbits or rodents are present, wear an insect repellent containing DEET;\n- keep pets confined and away from dead animals;\n- routinely use a tick and flea preventative on pets. Read the label and consult your veterinarian if you are unsure what to use.\n\n[Byline: Jason Pohl]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Acquiring _Francisella tularensis_ by lawn mowing usually causes pneumonia as the infection's manifestation. Skinning infected animals or acquiring the infection from a deer fly or tick bite will cause the ulceroglandular form. Oroglandular or oculoglandular forms can also occur depending on the site of exposure and a \"typhoidal\" form with bacteremia may occur. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] Boulder County\nDate: Thu 4 Sep 2014\nSource: CBS4 [edited]\nhttp://denver.cbslocal.com/2014/09/04/rabbit-fever-patient-released-from-hospital/\n\n\nAn infant from Longmont is recovering at home after being released from the hospital where he was treated for what's known at \"rabbit fever.\" The infant, just 10 weeks old, is the 1st human case of Tularemia in Boulder County. There have been at least 2 other cases in Broomfield and Larimer Counties. \"We get to go home. It's been a long couple of weeks,\" said the infant's mother.\n\nThe infant was released from Children's Hospital 14 days after contracting a disease that could have killed him. He's believed to have been exposed to tularemia at a family picnic after he was bitten by a tick. He was taken to Children's Hospital with a high fever and put on antibiotics. \"It [the temperature] got higher and higher so I took him in to the ER and once I got there they basically told me, 'Your baby's really sick and he's not leaving. He has to stay,'\" said the mother.\n\n\"This case was very lucky, they weren't very ill, they caught it very early,\" said Bolder County Public Health spokeswoman Kylie Chilton.\n\nOne case of rabbit fever was confirmed in a dead vole in a popular field in Boulder County. There are usually only 4 cases a year in Colorado but that has quadrupled in 2014 because heavy rain has fueled vegetation and given rabbits more places to live. \"As long as we continue to see warm temperatures and also these animals are around, then we may see that disease still,\" said Chilton.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209. Tularemia is not a very common infection in the USA and much less common in infants because they are usually not in circumstances where they would be exposed. Deer fly or tick-associated transmission is most likely in this infant. Although rashes, other than ulcers at the inoculation site, are not common, another report of tularemia in an infant described a vesicular rash (Byington CL, Bender JM, Ampofo K, et al: Tularemia with vesicular skin lesions may be mistaken for infection with herpes viruses. Clin Infect Dis 2008; 47(1): e4-e6; http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/47/1/e4.long). The authors point out that in Edward Francis' original description of the disease, he described a vesicular rash in one person and other studies have also reported rashes, including some with a vesicular component. - USA (03): (CO) rabbit 20101031.3945\nTularemia, animal - USA: (CO) feline 20100718.2401\nTularemia, wildlife - USA (02): (CO) beavers 20100513.1555\n.................................................ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-07-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Coloradoan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Broomfield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Taipei", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ER", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fort Collins", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3014671", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (09): (CO) humans, beavers", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3014671", "date": "2014-09-12 13:43:44", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (05): (COLORADO)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Larimer County\n[2] Boulder County\n\n******\n[1] Larimer County\nDate: Fri 5 Sep 2014\nSource: The Coloradoan [edited]\nhttp://www.coloradoan.com/story/news/local/2014/09/05/second-human-case-tularemia-confirmed-larimer/15135067/\n\n\nA 2nd human case of tularemia was confirmed on Fri 5 Sep 2014. A Larimer County resident has been hospitalized. The unidentified resident is thought to have been infected with the potentially life-threatening bacteria while mowing tall grass in an area where infected rabbits were previously present, Larimer County Department of Health and Environment officials said.\n\nThe bacterium can be transmitted by handling of sick or dead animals infected with tularemia. Infection can also arise from the bite of infected insects (ticks and deer flies), by eating or drinking contaminated food or water and by the inhalation of airborne bacteria.\n\nA rabbit in southeast Fort Collins tested positive for tularemia in July 2014, putting many on heightened alert, primarily in areas around Trilby Road between Timberline Road and Fossil Creek and the northwest section of Fossil Creek Wetlands natural area.\n\nThe 1st case of a Larimer County resident sickened by tularemia surfaced in early August 2014.\n\nHow to prevent tularemia:\n- avoid handling dead animals;\n- leash your pets when outdoors and keep them away from dead animals;\n- if a dead animal must be moved, avoid direct contact with it. Put on a repellent to protect yourself from its fleas or ticks, and use a shovel to scoop it up. Place it in a plastic bag and dispose in an outdoor trash receptacle. Wash your hands;\n- when outdoors near places where rabbits or rodents are present, wear an insect repellent containing DEET;\n- keep pets confined and away from dead animals;\n- routinely use a tick and flea preventative on pets. Read the label and consult your veterinarian if you are unsure what to use.\n\n[Byline: Jason Pohl]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Acquiring _Francisella tularensis_ by lawn mowing usually causes pneumonia as the infection's manifestation. Skinning infected animals or acquiring the infection from a deer fly or tick bite will cause the ulceroglandular form. Oroglandular or oculoglandular forms can also occur depending on the site of exposure and a \"typhoidal\" form with bacteremia may occur. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] Boulder County\nDate: Thu 4 Sep 2014\nSource: CBS4 [edited]\nhttp://denver.cbslocal.com/2014/09/04/rabbit-fever-patient-released-from-hospital/\n\n\nAn infant from Longmont is recovering at home after being released from the hospital where he was treated for what's known at \"rabbit fever.\" The infant, just 10 weeks old, is the 1st human case of Tularemia in Boulder County. There have been at least 2 other cases in Broomfield and Larimer Counties. \"We get to go home. It's been a long couple of weeks,\" said the infant's mother.\n\nThe infant was released from Children's Hospital 14 days after contracting a disease that could have killed him. He's believed to have been exposed to tularemia at a family picnic after he was bitten by a tick. He was taken to Children's Hospital with a high fever and put on antibiotics. \"It [the temperature] got higher and higher so I took him in to the ER and once I got there they basically told me, 'Your baby's really sick and he's not leaving. He has to stay,'\" said the mother.\n\n\"This case was very lucky, they weren't very ill, they caught it very early,\" said Bolder County Public Health spokeswoman Kylie Chilton.\n\nOne case of rabbit fever was confirmed in a dead vole in a popular field in Boulder County. There are usually only 4 cases a year in Colorado but that has quadrupled in 2014 because heavy rain has fueled vegetation and given rabbits more places to live. \"As long as we continue to see warm temperatures and also these animals are around, then we may see that disease still,\" said Chilton.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nThe manifestations of tularemia are not specifically stated. Tularemia is not a very common infection in the USA and much less common in infants because they are usually not in circumstances where they would be exposed. Deer fly or tick-associated transmission is most likely in this infant. Although rashes, other than ulcers at the inoculation site, are not common, another report of tularemia in an infant described a vesicular rash (Byington CL, Bender JM, Ampofo K, et al: Tularemia with vesicular skin lesions may be mistaken for infection with herpes viruses. Clin Infect Dis 2008; 47(1): e4-e6; http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/47/1/e4.long). The authors point out that in Edward Francis' original description of the disease, he described a vesicular rash in one person and other studies have also reported rashes, including some with a vesicular component. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia - USA (04): (IL, CO) fatal 20140813.2684686\nTularemia - USA (03): (CA) feline 20140711.2602339\nTularemia - USA (02): (NM) 20140711.2601188\nTularemia - USA: (CO) rabbit 20140705.2589884\n2013\n----\nTularemia - USA (08): 2001-2010 20131130.2083934\nTularemia - USA (07): (MA) 20130905.1926007\nTularemia - USA (06): (CO) rabbit 20130818.1886594\nTularemia - USA (05): (AK) snowshoe hare 20130702.1802498\nTularemia - USA (04): (NE) 20130629.1798960\nTularemia - USA (03): (NM) human, feline, canine, alert 20130628.1797147\nTularemia - USA (02): (NE) 20130624.1789311\nTularemia - USA: (NC) hunters 20130226.1560910\n2011\n----\nTularemia - USA (03): (CO) rabbit 20101031.3945\nTularemia, animal - USA: (CO) feline 20100718.2401\nTularemia, wildlife - USA (02): (CO) beavers 20100513.1555\n.................................................ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-07-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Coloradoan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Broomfield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Taipei", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ER", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fort Collins", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2829512", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (08): (CO) hunter warning", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2829512", "date": "2014-09-12 13:43:44", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (05): (COLORADO)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Larimer County\n[2] Boulder County\n\n******\n[1] Larimer County\nDate: Fri 5 Sep 2014\nSource: The Coloradoan [edited]\nhttp://www.coloradoan.com/story/news/local/2014/09/05/second-human-case-tularemia-confirmed-larimer/15135067/\n\n\nA 2nd human case of tularemia was confirmed on Fri 5 Sep 2014. A Larimer County resident has been hospitalized. The unidentified resident is thought to have been infected with the potentially life-threatening bacteria while mowing tall grass in an area where infected rabbits were previously present, Larimer County Department of Health and Environment officials said.\n\nThe bacterium can be transmitted by handling of sick or dead animals infected with tularemia. Infection can also arise from the bite of infected insects (ticks and deer flies), by eating or drinking contaminated food or water and by the inhalation of airborne bacteria.\n\nA rabbit in southeast Fort Collins tested positive for tularemia in July 2014, putting many on heightened alert, primarily in areas around Trilby Road between Timberline Road and Fossil Creek and the northwest section of Fossil Creek Wetlands natural area.\n\nThe 1st case of a Larimer County resident sickened by tularemia surfaced in early August 2014.\n\nHow to prevent tularemia:\n- avoid handling dead animals;\n- leash your pets when outdoors and keep them away from dead animals;\n- if a dead animal must be moved, avoid direct contact with it. Put on a repellent to protect yourself from its fleas or ticks, and use a shovel to scoop it up. Place it in a plastic bag and dispose in an outdoor trash receptacle. Wash your hands;\n- when outdoors near places where rabbits or rodents are present, wear an insect repellent containing DEET;\n- keep pets confined and away from dead animals;\n- routinely use a tick and flea preventative on pets. Read the label and consult your veterinarian if you are unsure what to use.\n\n[Byline: Jason Pohl]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Acquiring _Francisella tularensis_ by lawn mowing usually causes pneumonia as the infection's manifestation. Skinning infected animals or acquiring the infection from a deer fly or tick bite will cause the ulceroglandular form. Oroglandular or oculoglandular forms can also occur depending on the site of exposure and a \"typhoidal\" form with bacteremia may occur. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] Boulder County\nDate: Thu 4 Sep 2014\nSource: CBS4 [edited]\nhttp://denver.cbslocal.com/2014/09/04/rabbit-fever-patient-released-from-hospital/\n\n\nAn infant from Longmont is recovering at home after being released from the hospital where he was treated for what's known at \"rabbit fever.\" The infant, just 10 weeks old, is the 1st human case of Tularemia in Boulder County. There have been at least 2 other cases in Broomfield and Larimer Counties. \"We get to go home. It's been a long couple of weeks,\" said the infant's mother.\n\nThe infant was released from Children's Hospital 14 days after contracting a disease that could have killed him. He's believed to have been exposed to tularemia at a family picnic after he was bitten by a tick. He was taken to Children's Hospital with a high fever and put on antibiotics. \"It [the temperature] got higher and higher so I took him in to the ER and once I got there they basically told me, 'Your baby's really sick and he's not leaving. He has to stay,'\" said the mother.\n\n\"This case was very lucky, they weren't very ill, they caught it very early,\" said Bolder County Public Health spokeswoman Kylie Chilton.\n\nOne case of rabbit fever was confirmed in a dead vole in a popular field in Boulder County. There are usually only 4 cases a year in Colorado but that has quadrupled in 2014 because heavy rain has fueled vegetation and given rabbits more places to live. \"As long as we continue to see warm temperatures and also these animals are around, then we may see that disease still,\" said Chilton.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nThe manifestations of tularemia are not specifically stated. Tularemia is not a very common infection in the USA and much less common in infants because they are usually not in circumstances where they would be exposed. Deer fly or tick-associated transmission is most likely in this infant. Although rashes, other than ulcers at the inoculation site, are not common, another report of tularemia in an infant described a vesicular rash (Byington CL, Bender JM, Ampofo K, et al: Tularemia with vesicular skin lesions may be mistaken for infection with herpes viruses. Clin Infect Dis 2008; 47(1): e4-e6; http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/47/1/e4.long). The authors point out that in Edward Francis' original description of the disease, he described a vesicular rash in one person and other studies have also reported rashes, including some with a vesicular component. - The unidentified resident is thought to have been infected with the potentially life-threatening bacteria while mowing tall grass in an area where infected rabbits were previously present, Larimer County Department of Health and Environment officials said.\n\nThe bacterium can be transmitted by handling of sick or dead animals infected with tularemia. Put on a repellent to protect yourself from its fleas or ticks, and use a shovel to scoop it up. Place it in a plastic bag and dispose in an outdoor trash receptacle. A Larimer County resident has been hospitalized. The unidentified resident is thought to have been infected with the potentially life-threatening bacteria while mowing tall grass in an area where infected rabbits were previously present, Larimer County Department of Health and Environment officials said.\n\nThe bacterium can be transmitted by handling of sick or dead animals infected with tularemia. Infection can also arise from the bite of infected insects (ticks and deer flies), by eating or drinking contaminated food or water and by the inhalation of airborne bacteria.\n\nA rabbit in southeast Fort Collins tested positive for tularemia in July 2014, putting many on heightened alert, primarily in areas around Trilby Road between Timberline Road and Fossil Creek and the northwest section of Fossil Creek Wetlands natural area.\n\nThe 1st case of a Larimer County resident sickened by tularemia surfaced in early August 2014.\n\nHow to prevent tularemia:\n- avoid handling dead animals;\n- leash your pets when outdoors and keep them away from dead animals;\n- if a dead animal must be moved, avoid direct contact with it. Put on a repellent to protect yourself from its fleas or ticks, and use a shovel to scoop it up. Place it in a plastic bag and dispose in an outdoor trash receptacle. Wash your hands;\n- when outdoors near places where rabbits or rodents are present, wear an insect repellent containing DEET;\n- keep pets confined and away from dead animals;\n- routinely use a tick and flea preventative on pets. Read the label and consult your veterinarian if you are unsure what to use.\n\n[Byline: Jason Pohl]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Acquiring _Francisella tularensis_ by lawn mowing usually causes pneumonia as the infection's manifestation. Skinning infected animals or acquiring the infection from a deer fly or tick bite will cause the ulceroglandular form. Oroglandular or oculoglandular forms can also occur depending on the site of exposure and a \"typhoidal\" form with bacteremia may occur. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] Boulder County\nDate: Thu 4 Sep 2014\nSource: CBS4 [edited]\nhttp://denver.cbslocal.com/2014/09/04/rabbit-fever-patient-released-from-hospital/\n\n\nAn infant from Longmont is recovering at home after being released from the hospital where he was treated for what's known at \"rabbit fever.\" The infant, just 10 weeks old, is the 1st human case of Tularemia in Boulder County. There have been at least 2 other cases in Broomfield and Larimer Counties. \"We get to go home. It's been a long couple of weeks,\" said the infant's mother.\n\nThe infant was released from Children's Hospital 14 days after contracting a disease that could have killed him. He's believed to have been exposed to tularemia at a family picnic after he was bitten by a tick. He was taken to Children's Hospital with a high fever and put on antibiotics. \"It [the temperature] got higher and higher so I took him in to the ER and once I got there they basically told me, 'Your baby's really sick and he's not leaving. He has to stay,'\" said the mother.\n\n\"This case was very lucky, they weren't very ill, they caught it very early,\" said Bolder County Public Health spokeswoman Kylie Chilton.\n\nOne case of rabbit fever was confirmed in a dead vole in a popular field in Boulder County. There are usually only 4 cases a year in Colorado but that has quadrupled in 2014 because heavy rain has fueled vegetation and given rabbits more places to live. \"As long as we continue to see warm temperatures and also these animals are around, then we may see that disease still,\" said Chilton.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nThe manifestations of tularemia are not specifically stated. Tularemia is not a very common infection in the USA and much less common in infants because they are usually not in circumstances where they would be exposed. Deer fly or tick-associated transmission is most likely in this infant. Although rashes, other than ulcers at the inoculation site, are not common, another report of tularemia in an infant described a vesicular rash (Byington CL, Bender JM, Ampofo K, et al: Tularemia with vesicular skin lesions may be mistaken for infection with herpes viruses. Clin Infect Dis 2008; 47(1): e4-e6; http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/47/1/e4.long). The authors point out that in Edward Francis' original description of the disease, he described a vesicular rash in one person and other studies have also reported rashes, including some with a vesicular component. - Spain: crayfish exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2684689", "date": "2013-09-06 17:39:42", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, WILDLIFE - NETHERLANDS: (LIMBURG) HARE, FIRST REPORT, OIE\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Sep 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2013; 26(36) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14023\n\n\nTularemia, Netherlands\n----------------------\nInformation received on 5 Sep 2013 from Dr Christianne Bruschke, Chief Veterinary Officer, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, The Hague, Netherlands\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification (Final report)\nDate of start of the event: 4 Sep 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 4 Sep 2013\nReport date: 4 Sep 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 5 Sep 2013\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 1953\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Francisella tularensis_\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Limburg (Leudal)\nDate of start of the outbreak: 2013\nOutbreak status: Resolved (4 Sep 2013)\nEpidemiological unit: Not applicable\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / ** / ** / 100 percent / **\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n**Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: No vaccination, No treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral Veterinary Institute (CVI), Lelystad (national laboratory) / Brown hare (European hare) / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 4 Sep 2013/ Positive\n\nFuture reporting: The event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a zoonosis caused by _Francisella tularensis_. The causative bacterium is a Gram-negative coccoid rod, 0.2-0.5 micrometre x 0.7-1.0 micrometre, non-motile and non-spore-forming organism that is an obligate aerobe with optimal growth at 37 degrees C. It occurs naturally in lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), and in rodents, especially microtine rodents (such as voles, vole rats and muskrats), and beavers. A wide range of other mammals and several species of birds have also been reported to be infected. Among domestic animals, the cat seems to be able to act as a carrier of the bacterium.\n\nTwo types of _F. tularensis_ are recognised on the basis of cultural characteristics, epidemiology, and virulence in some hosts. Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits, and most of the isolates ferment glycerol. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _palaearctica_ (Type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers, muskrats) in northern North America, and in hares and small rodents in Eurasia.\n\nThe disease is characterised by fever, depression and septicaemia. In humans, there may be ulcers or abscesses at the site of inoculation (this is rarely seen in animals), and swelling of the regional lymph nodes.\n\nIt is important to understand that there is a high risk of direct infection of humans by direct contact with this organism. For the above and additional background information, including diagnostic methods, please refer to OIE Terrestrial Manual 2012, Chapter 2.1.18 \"Tularemia\" at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf\n(adopted by the World Assembly of Delegates of the OIE in May 2012).\n\nOIE's internationally agreed requirements pertaining to tularemia are spelled out in chapter 8.15 of OIE's Terrestrial Animal Health Code, available at http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=169&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.8.15.htm.\n\nAccording to the most recent 6-month OIE report, tularemia was reported as present in 6 countries (Czech Republic, Denmark, Sweden, France, Germany, and Switzerland). In addition, Spain and the United States have reported the disease limited to certain zones. In 82 countries the disease has never been reported, and in 40 the disease was reported absent in this period. On the other hand, most countries have not specified surveillance for tularemia, some maintain \"general surveillance\" and very few maintain \"targeted surveillance\" countries (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist).\n\nA map showing the distribution of disease in domestic and/or wild species can be obtained at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/Diseasedistributionmap. (Note: at both WAHID links, to view the information on tularemia, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease).\n\nAlthough Tularemia had not been reported in the Netherlands since 1953, this event should not come as a surprise since the disease is present in the surrounding countries such as Germany, France and Belgium. The Dutch province of Limburg is situated in south Netherlands, bordering Germany and Belgium. The Dutch source \"Groene Ruimte\", cited at the end of the commentary, says: \"The bacterium has been recently demonstrated in 3 percent of hares found dead in northern Germany. It is spread over France. The last case in Belgium, a hare, was reported in 2011\" (http://www.groeneruimte.nl/nieuws/artikel.html?id=151747). - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/8l5l.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nTularemia, wildlife - Denmark: east, hare, OIE 20121129.1431026\n2011\n----\nTularemia, wildlife - France: (PC) hare 20110715.2142\nTularemia - Norway: (central) 20110225.0622\n2008\n----\nTularemia, human, hare, 2007 - Germany: (Baden-Wuerttemberg) 20080218.0640\n2007\n----\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02) 20070813.2646\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir 20070811.2615\n.................................................crd/arn/mpp/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-09-05 00:00:00", "1953-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-09-04 00:00:00", "2012-05-16 00:00:00", "1953-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Limburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baden - Wuerttemberg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Hague", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Czech Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2684686", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (04): (IL, CO) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2684686", "date": "2013-09-06 17:39:42", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, WILDLIFE - NETHERLANDS: (LIMBURG) HARE, FIRST REPORT, OIE\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Sep 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2013; 26(36) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14023\n\n\nTularemia, Netherlands\n----------------------\nInformation received on 5 Sep 2013 from Dr Christianne Bruschke, Chief Veterinary Officer, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, The Hague, Netherlands\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification (Final report)\nDate of start of the event: 4 Sep 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 4 Sep 2013\nReport date: 4 Sep 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 5 Sep 2013\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 1953\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Francisella tularensis_\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Limburg (Leudal)\nDate of start of the outbreak: 2013\nOutbreak status: Resolved (4 Sep 2013)\nEpidemiological unit: Not applicable\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / ** / ** / 100 percent / **\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n**Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: No vaccination, No treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral Veterinary Institute (CVI), Lelystad (national laboratory) / Brown hare (European hare) / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 4 Sep 2013/ Positive\n\nFuture reporting: The event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a zoonosis caused by _Francisella tularensis_. The causative bacterium is a Gram-negative coccoid rod, 0.2-0.5 micrometre x 0.7-1.0 micrometre, non-motile and non-spore-forming organism that is an obligate aerobe with optimal growth at 37 degrees C. It occurs naturally in lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), and in rodents, especially microtine rodents (such as voles, vole rats and muskrats), and beavers. A wide range of other mammals and several species of birds have also been reported to be infected. Among domestic animals, the cat seems to be able to act as a carrier of the bacterium.\n\nTwo types of _F. tularensis_ are recognised on the basis of cultural characteristics, epidemiology, and virulence in some hosts. Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits, and most of the isolates ferment glycerol. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _palaearctica_ (Type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers, muskrats) in northern North America, and in hares and small rodents in Eurasia.\n\nThe disease is characterised by fever, depression and septicaemia. In humans, there may be ulcers or abscesses at the site of inoculation (this is rarely seen in animals), and swelling of the regional lymph nodes.\n\nIt is important to understand that there is a high risk of direct infection of humans by direct contact with this organism. For the above and additional background information, including diagnostic methods, please refer to OIE Terrestrial Manual 2012, Chapter 2.1.18 \"Tularemia\" at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf\n(adopted by the World Assembly of Delegates of the OIE in May 2012).\n\nOIE's internationally agreed requirements pertaining to tularemia are spelled out in chapter 8.15 of OIE's Terrestrial Animal Health Code, available at http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=169&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.8.15.htm.\n\nAccording to the most recent 6-month OIE report, tularemia was reported as present in 6 countries (Czech Republic, Denmark, Sweden, France, Germany, and Switzerland). In addition, Spain and the United States have reported the disease limited to certain zones. In 82 countries the disease has never been reported, and in 40 the disease was reported absent in this period. On the other hand, most countries have not specified surveillance for tularemia, some maintain \"general surveillance\" and very few maintain \"targeted surveillance\" countries (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist).\n\nA map showing the distribution of disease in domestic and/or wild species can be obtained at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/Diseasedistributionmap. (Note: at both WAHID links, to view the information on tularemia, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease).\n\nAlthough Tularemia had not been reported in the Netherlands since 1953, this event should not come as a surprise since the disease is present in the surrounding countries such as Germany, France and Belgium. The Dutch province of Limburg is situated in south Netherlands, bordering Germany and Belgium. The Dutch source \"Groene Ruimte\", cited at the end of the commentary, says: \"The bacterium has been recently demonstrated in 3 percent of hares found dead in northern Germany. It is spread over France. The last case in Belgium, a hare, was reported in 2011\" (http://www.groeneruimte.nl/nieuws/artikel.html?id=151747). - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/8l5l.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nTularemia, wildlife - Denmark: east, hare, OIE 20121129.1431026\n2011\n----\nTularemia, wildlife - France: (PC) hare 20110715.2142\nTularemia - Norway: (central) 20110225.0622\n2008\n----\nTularemia, human, hare, 2007 - Germany: (Baden-Wuerttemberg) 20080218.0640\n2007\n----\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02) 20070813.2646\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir 20070811.2615\n.................................................crd/arn/mpp/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-09-05 00:00:00", "1953-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-09-04 00:00:00", "2012-05-16 00:00:00", "1953-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Limburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia - USA (03): (CA) feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2602339", "date": "2013-09-06 17:39:42", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, WILDLIFE - NETHERLANDS: (LIMBURG) HARE, FIRST REPORT, OIE\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Sep 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2013; 26(36) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14023\n\n\nTularemia, Netherlands\n----------------------\nInformation received on 5 Sep 2013 from Dr Christianne Bruschke, Chief Veterinary Officer, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, The Hague, Netherlands\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification (Final report)\nDate of start of the event: 4 Sep 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 4 Sep 2013\nReport date: 4 Sep 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 5 Sep 2013\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 1953\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Francisella tularensis_\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Limburg (Leudal)\nDate of start of the outbreak: 2013\nOutbreak status: Resolved (4 Sep 2013)\nEpidemiological unit: Not applicable\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / ** / ** / 100 percent / **\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n**Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: No vaccination, No treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral Veterinary Institute (CVI), Lelystad (national laboratory) / Brown hare (European hare) / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 4 Sep 2013/ Positive\n\nFuture reporting: The event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a zoonosis caused by _Francisella tularensis_. The causative bacterium is a Gram-negative coccoid rod, 0.2-0.5 micrometre x 0.7-1.0 micrometre, non-motile and non-spore-forming organism that is an obligate aerobe with optimal growth at 37 degrees C. It occurs naturally in lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), and in rodents, especially microtine rodents (such as voles, vole rats and muskrats), and beavers. A wide range of other mammals and several species of birds have also been reported to be infected. Among domestic animals, the cat seems to be able to act as a carrier of the bacterium.\n\nTwo types of _F. tularensis_ are recognised on the basis of cultural characteristics, epidemiology, and virulence in some hosts. Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits, and most of the isolates ferment glycerol. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _palaearctica_ (Type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers, muskrats) in northern North America, and in hares and small rodents in Eurasia.\n\nThe disease is characterised by fever, depression and septicaemia. In humans, there may be ulcers or abscesses at the site of inoculation (this is rarely seen in animals), and swelling of the regional lymph nodes.\n\nIt is important to understand that there is a high risk of direct infection of humans by direct contact with this organism. For the above and additional background information, including diagnostic methods, please refer to OIE Terrestrial Manual 2012, Chapter 2.1.18 \"Tularemia\" at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf\n(adopted by the World Assembly of Delegates of the OIE in May 2012).\n\nOIE's internationally agreed requirements pertaining to tularemia are spelled out in chapter 8.15 of OIE's Terrestrial Animal Health Code, available at http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=169&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.8.15.htm.\n\nAccording to the most recent 6-month OIE report, tularemia was reported as present in 6 countries (Czech Republic, Denmark, Sweden, France, Germany, and Switzerland). In addition, Spain and the United States have reported the disease limited to certain zones. In 82 countries the disease has never been reported, and in 40 the disease was reported absent in this period. On the other hand, most countries have not specified surveillance for tularemia, some maintain \"general surveillance\" and very few maintain \"targeted surveillance\" countries (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist).\n\nA map showing the distribution of disease in domestic and/or wild species can be obtained at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/Diseasedistributionmap. (Note: at both WAHID links, to view the information on tularemia, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease).\n\nAlthough Tularemia had not been reported in the Netherlands since 1953, this event should not come as a surprise since the disease is present in the surrounding countries such as Germany, France and Belgium. The Dutch province of Limburg is situated in south Netherlands, bordering Germany and Belgium. The Dutch source \"Groene Ruimte\", cited at the end of the commentary, says: \"The bacterium has been recently demonstrated in 3 percent of hares found dead in northern Germany. It is spread over France. The last case in Belgium, a hare, was reported in 2011\" (http://www.groeneruimte.nl/nieuws/artikel.html?id=151747). - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/8l5l.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nTularemia, wildlife - The causative bacterium is a Gram-negative coccoid rod, 0.2-0.5 micrometre x 0.7-1.0 micrometre, non-motile and non-spore-forming organism that is an obligate aerobe with optimal growth at 37 degrees C. Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits, and most of the isolates ferment glycerol. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _palaearctica_ (Type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers, muskrats) in northern North America, and in hares and small rodents in Eurasia.\n\nThe disease is characterised by fever, depression and septicaemia.
