The causative bacterium is a Gram-negative coccoid rod, 0.2-0.5 micrometre x 0.7-1.0 micrometre, non-motile and non-spore-forming organism that is an obligate aerobe with optimal growth at 37 degrees C. It occurs naturally in lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), and in rodents, especially microtine rodents (such as voles, vole rats and muskrats), and beavers. A wide range of other mammals and several species of birds have also been reported to be infected. Among domestic animals, the cat seems to be able to act as a carrier of the bacterium.\n\nTwo types of _F. tularensis_ are recognised on the basis of cultural characteristics, epidemiology, and virulence in some hosts. Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits, and most of the isolates ferment glycerol. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _palaearctica_ (Type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers, muskrats) in northern North America, and in hares and small rodents in Eurasia.\n\nThe disease is characterised by fever, depression and septicaemia. In humans, there may be ulcers or abscesses at the site of inoculation (this is rarely seen in animals), and swelling of the regional lymph nodes.\n\nIt is important to understand that there is a high risk of direct infection of humans by direct contact with this organism. For the above and additional background information, including diagnostic methods, please refer to OIE Terrestrial Manual 2012, Chapter 2.1.18 \"Tularemia\" at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf\n(adopted by the World Assembly of Delegates of the OIE in May 2012).\n\nOIE's internationally agreed requirements pertaining to tularemia are spelled out in chapter 8.15 of OIE's Terrestrial Animal Health Code, available at http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=169&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.8.15.htm.\n\nAccording to the most recent 6-month OIE report, tularemia was reported as present in 6 countries (Czech Republic, Denmark, Sweden, France, Germany, and Switzerland). In addition, Spain and the United States have reported the disease limited to certain zones. In 82 countries the disease has never been reported, and in 40 the disease was reported absent in this period. On the other hand, most countries have not specified surveillance for tularemia, some maintain \"general surveillance\" and very few maintain \"targeted surveillance\" countries (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist).\n\nA map showing the distribution of disease in domestic and/or wild species can be obtained at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/Diseasedistributionmap. (Note: at both WAHID links, to view the information on tularemia, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease).\n\nAlthough Tularemia had not been reported in the Netherlands since 1953, this event should not come as a surprise since the disease is present in the surrounding countries such as Germany, France and Belgium. The Dutch province of Limburg is situated in south Netherlands, bordering Germany and Belgium. The Dutch source \"Groene Ruimte\", cited at the end of the commentary, says: \"The bacterium has been recently demonstrated in 3 percent of hares found dead in northern Germany. It is spread over France. The last case in Belgium, a hare, was reported in 2011\" (http://www.groeneruimte.nl/nieuws/artikel.html?id=151747). - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/8l5l.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nTularemia, wildlife - Denmark: east, hare, OIE 20121129.1431026\n2011\n----\nTularemia, wildlife - France: (PC) hare 20110715.2142\nTularemia - Norway: (central) 20110225.0622\n2008\n----\nTularemia, human, hare, 2007 - Germany: (Baden-Wuerttemberg) 20080218.0640\n2007\n----\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02) 20070813.2646\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir 20070811.2615\n.................................................crd/arn/mpp/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-09-05 00:00:00", "1953-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-09-04 00:00:00", "2012-05-16 00:00:00", "1953-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Limburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baden - Wuerttemberg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Hague", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Czech Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2083934", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (08): 2001-2010", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2083934", "date": "2013-09-06 17:39:42", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, WILDLIFE - NETHERLANDS: (LIMBURG) HARE, FIRST REPORT, OIE\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Sep 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2013; 26(36) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14023\n\n\nTularemia, Netherlands\n----------------------\nInformation received on 5 Sep 2013 from Dr Christianne Bruschke, Chief Veterinary Officer, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, The Hague, Netherlands\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification (Final report)\nDate of start of the event: 4 Sep 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 4 Sep 2013\nReport date: 4 Sep 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 5 Sep 2013\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 1953\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Francisella tularensis_\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Limburg (Leudal)\nDate of start of the outbreak: 2013\nOutbreak status: Resolved (4 Sep 2013)\nEpidemiological unit: Not applicable\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / ** / ** / 100 percent / **\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n**Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: No vaccination, No treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral Veterinary Institute (CVI), Lelystad (national laboratory) / Brown hare (European hare) / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 4 Sep 2013/ Positive\n\nFuture reporting: The event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a zoonosis caused by _Francisella tularensis_. The causative bacterium is a Gram-negative coccoid rod, 0.2-0.5 micrometre x 0.7-1.0 micrometre, non-motile and non-spore-forming organism that is an obligate aerobe with optimal growth at 37 degrees C. It occurs naturally in lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), and in rodents, especially microtine rodents (such as voles, vole rats and muskrats), and beavers. A wide range of other mammals and several species of birds have also been reported to be infected. Among domestic animals, the cat seems to be able to act as a carrier of the bacterium.\n\nTwo types of _F. tularensis_ are recognised on the basis of cultural characteristics, epidemiology, and virulence in some hosts. Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits, and most of the isolates ferment glycerol. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _palaearctica_ (Type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers, muskrats) in northern North America, and in hares and small rodents in Eurasia.\n\nThe disease is characterised by fever, depression and septicaemia. In humans, there may be ulcers or abscesses at the site of inoculation (this is rarely seen in animals), and swelling of the regional lymph nodes.\n\nIt is important to understand that there is a high risk of direct infection of humans by direct contact with this organism. For the above and additional background information, including diagnostic methods, please refer to OIE Terrestrial Manual 2012, Chapter 2.1.18 \"Tularemia\" at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf\n(adopted by the World Assembly of Delegates of the OIE in May 2012).\n\nOIE's internationally agreed requirements pertaining to tularemia are spelled out in chapter 8.15 of OIE's Terrestrial Animal Health Code, available at http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=169&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.8.15.htm.\n\nAccording to the most recent 6-month OIE report, tularemia was reported as present in 6 countries (Czech Republic, Denmark, Sweden, France, Germany, and Switzerland). In addition, Spain and the United States have reported the disease limited to certain zones. In 82 countries the disease has never been reported, and in 40 the disease was reported absent in this period. On the other hand, most countries have not specified surveillance for tularemia, some maintain \"general surveillance\" and very few maintain \"targeted surveillance\" countries (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist).\n\nA map showing the distribution of disease in domestic and/or wild species can be obtained at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/Diseasedistributionmap. (Note: at both WAHID links, to view the information on tularemia, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease).\n\nAlthough Tularemia had not been reported in the Netherlands since 1953, this event should not come as a surprise since the disease is present in the surrounding countries such as Germany, France and Belgium. The Dutch province of Limburg is situated in south Netherlands, bordering Germany and Belgium. The Dutch source \"Groene Ruimte\", cited at the end of the commentary, says: \"The bacterium has been recently demonstrated in 3 percent of hares found dead in northern Germany. It is spread over France. The last case in Belgium, a hare, was reported in 2011\" (http://www.groeneruimte.nl/nieuws/artikel.html?id=151747). - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/8l5l.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nTularemia, wildlife - Denmark: east, hare, OIE 20121129.1431026\n2011\n----\nTularemia, wildlife - France: (PC) hare 20110715.2142\nTularemia - Norway: (central) 20110225.0622\n2008\n----\nTularemia, human, hare, 2007 - Germany: (Baden-Wuerttemberg) 20080218.0640\n2007\n----\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02) 20070813.2646\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir 20070811.2615\n.................................................crd/arn/mpp/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-09-05 00:00:00", "1953-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-09-04 00:00:00", "2012-05-16 00:00:00", "1953-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - The causative bacterium is a Gram-negative coccoid rod, 0.2-0.5 micrometre x 0.7-1.0 micrometre, non-motile and non-spore-forming organism that is an obligate aerobe with optimal growth at 37 degrees C. It occurs naturally in lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), and in rodents, especially microtine rodents (such as voles, vole rats and muskrats), and beavers. A wide range of other mammals and several species of birds have also been reported to be infected. Among domestic animals, the cat seems to be able to act as a carrier of the bacterium.\n\nTwo types of _F. tularensis_ are recognised on the basis of cultural characteristics, epidemiology, and virulence in some hosts. Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits, and most of the isolates ferment glycerol. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _palaearctica_ (Type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers, muskrats) in northern North America, and in hares and small rodents in Eurasia.\n\nThe disease is characterised by fever, depression and septicaemia. In humans, there may be ulcers or abscesses at the site of inoculation (this is rarely seen in animals), and swelling of the regional lymph nodes.\n\nIt is important to understand that there is a high risk of direct infection of humans by direct contact with this organism. For the above and additional background information, including diagnostic methods, please refer to OIE Terrestrial Manual 2012, Chapter 2.1.18 \"Tularemia\" at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf\n(adopted by the World Assembly of Delegates of the OIE in May 2012).\n\nOIE's internationally agreed requirements pertaining to tularemia are spelled out in chapter 8.15 of OIE's Terrestrial Animal Health Code, available at http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=169&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.8.15.htm.\n\nAccording to the most recent 6-month OIE report, tularemia was reported as present in 6 countries (Czech Republic, Denmark, Sweden, France, Germany, and Switzerland). In addition, Spain and the United States have reported the disease limited to certain zones. In 82 countries the disease has never been reported, and in 40 the disease was reported absent in this period. On the other hand, most countries have not specified surveillance for tularemia, some maintain \"general surveillance\" and very few maintain \"targeted surveillance\" countries (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist).\n\nA map showing the distribution of disease in domestic and/or wild species can be obtained at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/Diseasedistributionmap. Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Limburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baden - Wuerttemberg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Hague", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Czech Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1926007", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (07): (MA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1926007", "date": "2013-03-22 20:38:04", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DIE-OFF, BEAVER - USA: (ILLINOIS) TULAREMIA SUSPECTED\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 17 Mar 2012\nSource: The News-Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.news-gazette.com/news/environment/2013-03-17/environmental-almanac-tularemia-suspected-beaver-deaths.html?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+wdinNewsDigestGeoRSS+%28Wildlife+Disease+News+Digest+GeoRSS+Feed%29&utm_term=wdinNewsDigestGeoRSS\n\n\nA beaver die-off at Urbana's Meadowbrook Park, thought to have been caused by tularemia, has emphasized the importance of keeping pets indoors or on a leash, for their own safety and that of wildlife. It also has raised questions about the impact of drought, overpopulation and habitat destruction on wildlife. Officials say there are no reports of human illness.\n\nWhat is known for sure is that 7 of the beavers that thrived in and along McCullough Creek in the park died in the last year [2012]. The cause is less certain.\n\n\"There is no conclusive evidence,\" researcher Nohra Mateus-Pinilla said, \"but it appears that the only thing that could have caused the die-off is an outbreak of tularemia.\" She emphasized that tularemia bacteria are common. \"They are present in rabbits and squirrels,\" she said. \"They are part of the natural ecosystem.\"\n\nMateus-Pinilla, a wildlife veterinary epidemiologist at the Illinois Natural History Survey, said it is possible that severe drought exacerbated the outbreak, with low water levels forcing beavers and other animals to live in closer quarters. Continuing destruction of wildlife habitat has a similar effect, she said.\n\nDerek Liebert, project manager at the Urbana Park District, said a wildlife biologist suggested to him that if tularemia is in fact the cause, the die-off may be a corrective measure for a population that grew too large.\n\nThe Champaign-Urbana Public Health District issued an alert notifying residents of tularemia in the area. The alert cited a Meadowbrook beaver diagnosed with clinical symptoms of tularemia and an unrelated 2011 outbreak among 5 pet cats in Champaign, Urbana and Savoy.\n\nHealth district planning director Awais Vaid said people should not let their pets roam and should take them to a veterinarian if they exhibit symptoms such as loss of appetite or difficulty with movement. People who see sick animals in the wild or along trails should not approach them, Vaid said, not only because of the risk of tularemia but of rabies.\n\nThe park district warns Meadowbrook users to keep pets leashed and to stay on trails in the park. Mateus-Pinilla reinforced local government warnings about allowing domestic animals to roam or run unleashed.\n\n\"Then you are bringing them into your house, where there is direct contact. That is more serious,\" she said.\n\nAccording to the National Institutes of Health, tularemia is common among wild rodents and can be transmitted to other animals and humans through direct contact and by ticks, biting flies and other insects. In humans, tularemia bacteria can cause illness ranging from asymptomatic to life-threatening.\n\nLiebert said the 1st dead beaver was found in January 2012. It was taken to the University of Illinois veterinary diagnostic laboratory, where tests were conducted, with inconclusive results. Then in June and September, 2 adult beavers were found dead but were too decomposed to be necropsied, he said.\n\nThe biggest spate of deaths occurred in October [2012], when 3 beavers were found, 2 of which were necropsied. In November, a 7th beaver was found. Liebert said the most recent sighting of a live beaver, a single individual, occurred 19 Dec 2012.\n\nThe effort to isolate the cause of the deaths was hampered by several circumstances, Mateus-Pinilla said. One is that decomposition sets in rapidly, and sometimes there is not much a pathologist can do because of the condition of the body. The \"gold standard\" for a confirmed diagnosis, Mateus-Pinilla said, is the ability to grow a culture of the suspect bacteria. The Meadowbrook beavers were tested for several pathogens, including tularemia, salmonella, leptospira and canine distemper. No tests resulted positive.\n\nHowever, investigators were able to rule out toxins, such as from run-off, and also found evidence pointing to tularemia, even if it did not amount to a confirmed diagnosis.\n\nMateus-Pinilla said salmonella and leptospira were eliminated, for example, because salmonella would not have caused a die-off, and leptospira is associated with lesions not found in the necropsies. But investigators did find certain changes in the lungs typical of tularemia. In the end, Mateus-Pinilla said, what signs there were pointed to tularemia.\n\nMateus-Pinilla said it is unlikely that the habitat provided by the park itself was to blame. Indeed, she said, the fact that beavers were thriving there \"tells us it was a suitable habitat.\" Unfortunately, she said, the die-off \"also tells us that natural habitats are more and more disturbed, forcing the beavers to be in a more dense population.\"\n\nHuman attraction to nature puts people in closer contact with wildlife diseases, she added. \"We want to put our house in the woods,\" and as a result \"we are getting closer to diseases that we wouldn't find in the middle of New York City.\"\n\nMateus-Pinilla sees an opportunity for independent research through close monitoring of future colonies at Meadowbrook.\n\n\"I would love to see it happening,\" she said. The Meadowbrook beavers are \"close to one of the biggest wildlife research institutions in the United States. We have the resources, and we have the students.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is caused by the gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere.\n\n_Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits. _Francisella tularensis subsp. palaearctica_ (Type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers, muskrats) in northern North America. It may be water- or arthropod-borne, and is less virulent to humans and rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread by contact with infected animals or environmental fomites, by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/5*UN - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\n2012\n---\nTularemia, wildlife - Denmark: east, hare, OIE 20121129.1431026\nTularemia, rabbits - USA: (AZ) 20120731.1223191\n2005\n----\nTularemia, rabbit contact - USA (AZ) 20050609.1604\n2000\n----\nTularemia, zoo animals - USA (Arizona) 20000619.0993\n.................................................sb/pmb/ejp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rabies", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-01-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Champaign", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "McCullough Creek", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1898671", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Russia: (KM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1898671", "date": "2013-03-22 20:38:04", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DIE-OFF, BEAVER - USA: (ILLINOIS) TULAREMIA SUSPECTED\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 17 Mar 2012\nSource: The News-Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.news-gazette.com/news/environment/2013-03-17/environmental-almanac-tularemia-suspected-beaver-deaths.html?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+wdinNewsDigestGeoRSS+%28Wildlife+Disease+News+Digest+GeoRSS+Feed%29&utm_term=wdinNewsDigestGeoRSS\n\n\nA beaver die-off at Urbana's Meadowbrook Park, thought to have been caused by tularemia, has emphasized the importance of keeping pets indoors or on a leash, for their own safety and that of wildlife. It also has raised questions about the impact of drought, overpopulation and habitat destruction on wildlife. Officials say there are no reports of human illness.\n\nWhat is known for sure is that 7 of the beavers that thrived in and along McCullough Creek in the park died in the last year [2012]. The cause is less certain.\n\n\"There is no conclusive evidence,\" researcher Nohra Mateus-Pinilla said, \"but it appears that the only thing that could have caused the die-off is an outbreak of tularemia.\" She emphasized that tularemia bacteria are common. \"They are present in rabbits and squirrels,\" she said. \"They are part of the natural ecosystem.\"\n\nMateus-Pinilla, a wildlife veterinary epidemiologist at the Illinois Natural History Survey, said it is possible that severe drought exacerbated the outbreak, with low water levels forcing beavers and other animals to live in closer quarters. Continuing destruction of wildlife habitat has a similar effect, she said.\n\nDerek Liebert, project manager at the Urbana Park District, said a wildlife biologist suggested to him that if tularemia is in fact the cause, the die-off may be a corrective measure for a population that grew too large.\n\nThe Champaign-Urbana Public Health District issued an alert notifying residents of tularemia in the area. The alert cited a Meadowbrook beaver diagnosed with clinical symptoms of tularemia and an unrelated 2011 outbreak among 5 pet cats in Champaign, Urbana and Savoy.\n\nHealth district planning director Awais Vaid said people should not let their pets roam and should take them to a veterinarian if they exhibit symptoms such as loss of appetite or difficulty with movement. People who see sick animals in the wild or along trails should not approach them, Vaid said, not only because of the risk of tularemia but of rabies.\n\nThe park district warns Meadowbrook users to keep pets leashed and to stay on trails in the park. Mateus-Pinilla reinforced local government warnings about allowing domestic animals to roam or run unleashed.\n\n\"Then you are bringing them into your house, where there is direct contact. That is more serious,\" she said.\n\nAccording to the National Institutes of Health, tularemia is common among wild rodents and can be transmitted to other animals and humans through direct contact and by ticks, biting flies and other insects. In humans, tularemia bacteria can cause illness ranging from asymptomatic to life-threatening.\n\nLiebert said the 1st dead beaver was found in January 2012. It was taken to the University of Illinois veterinary diagnostic laboratory, where tests were conducted, with inconclusive results. Then in June and September, 2 adult beavers were found dead but were too decomposed to be necropsied, he said.\n\nThe biggest spate of deaths occurred in October [2012], when 3 beavers were found, 2 of which were necropsied. In November, a 7th beaver was found. Liebert said the most recent sighting of a live beaver, a single individual, occurred 19 Dec 2012.\n\nThe effort to isolate the cause of the deaths was hampered by several circumstances, Mateus-Pinilla said. One is that decomposition sets in rapidly, and sometimes there is not much a pathologist can do because of the condition of the body. The \"gold standard\" for a confirmed diagnosis, Mateus-Pinilla said, is the ability to grow a culture of the suspect bacteria. The Meadowbrook beavers were tested for several pathogens, including tularemia, salmonella, leptospira and canine distemper. No tests resulted positive.\n\nHowever, investigators were able to rule out toxins, such as from run-off, and also found evidence pointing to tularemia, even if it did not amount to a confirmed diagnosis.\n\nMateus-Pinilla said salmonella and leptospira were eliminated, for example, because salmonella would not have caused a die-off, and leptospira is associated with lesions not found in the necropsies. But investigators did find certain changes in the lungs typical of tularemia. In the end, Mateus-Pinilla said, what signs there were pointed to tularemia.\n\nMateus-Pinilla said it is unlikely that the habitat provided by the park itself was to blame. Indeed, she said, the fact that beavers were thriving there \"tells us it was a suitable habitat.\" Unfortunately, she said, the die-off \"also tells us that natural habitats are more and more disturbed, forcing the beavers to be in a more dense population.\"\n\nHuman attraction to nature puts people in closer contact with wildlife diseases, she added. \"We want to put our house in the woods,\" and as a result \"we are getting closer to diseases that we wouldn't find in the middle of New York City.\"\n\nMateus-Pinilla sees an opportunity for independent research through close monitoring of future colonies at Meadowbrook.\n\n\"I would love to see it happening,\" she said. The Meadowbrook beavers are \"close to one of the biggest wildlife research institutions in the United States. We have the resources, and we have the students.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is caused by the gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere.\n\n_Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits. _Francisella tularensis subsp. palaearctica_ (Type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers, muskrats) in northern North America. It may be water- or arthropod-borne, and is less virulent to humans and rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread by contact with infected animals or environmental fomites, by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/5*UN - USA (06): (CO) rabbit", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1886594", "date": "2013-03-22 20:38:04", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DIE-OFF, BEAVER - USA: (ILLINOIS) TULAREMIA SUSPECTED\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 17 Mar 2012\nSource: The News-Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.news-gazette.com/news/environment/2013-03-17/environmental-almanac-tularemia-suspected-beaver-deaths.html?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+wdinNewsDigestGeoRSS+%28Wildlife+Disease+News+Digest+GeoRSS+Feed%29&utm_term=wdinNewsDigestGeoRSS\n\n\nA beaver die-off at Urbana's Meadowbrook Park, thought to have been caused by tularemia, has emphasized the importance of keeping pets indoors or on a leash, for their own safety and that of wildlife. It also has raised questions about the impact of drought, overpopulation and habitat destruction on wildlife. Officials say there are no reports of human illness.\n\nWhat is known for sure is that 7 of the beavers that thrived in and along McCullough Creek in the park died in the last year [2012]. The cause is less certain.\n\n\"There is no conclusive evidence,\" researcher Nohra Mateus-Pinilla said, \"but it appears that the only thing that could have caused the die-off is an outbreak of tularemia.\" She emphasized that tularemia bacteria are common. \"They are present in rabbits and squirrels,\" she said. \"They are part of the natural ecosystem.\"\n\nMateus-Pinilla, a wildlife veterinary epidemiologist at the Illinois Natural History Survey, said it is possible that severe drought exacerbated the outbreak, with low water levels forcing beavers and other animals to live in closer quarters. Continuing destruction of wildlife habitat has a similar effect, she said.\n\nDerek Liebert, project manager at the Urbana Park District, said a wildlife biologist suggested to him that if tularemia is in fact the cause, the die-off may be a corrective measure for a population that grew too large.\n\nThe Champaign-Urbana Public Health District issued an alert notifying residents of tularemia in the area. The alert cited a Meadowbrook beaver diagnosed with clinical symptoms of tularemia and an unrelated 2011 outbreak among 5 pet cats in Champaign, Urbana and Savoy.\n\nHealth district planning director Awais Vaid said people should not let their pets roam and should take them to a veterinarian if they exhibit symptoms such as loss of appetite or difficulty with movement. People who see sick animals in the wild or along trails should not approach them, Vaid said, not only because of the risk of tularemia but of rabies.\n\nThe park district warns Meadowbrook users to keep pets leashed and to stay on trails in the park. Mateus-Pinilla reinforced local government warnings about allowing domestic animals to roam or run unleashed.\n\n\"Then you are bringing them into your house, where there is direct contact. That is more serious,\" she said.\n\nAccording to the National Institutes of Health, tularemia is common among wild rodents and can be transmitted to other animals and humans through direct contact and by ticks, biting flies and other insects. In humans, tularemia bacteria can cause illness ranging from asymptomatic to life-threatening.\n\nLiebert said the 1st dead beaver was found in January 2012. It was taken to the University of Illinois veterinary diagnostic laboratory, where tests were conducted, with inconclusive results. Then in June and September, 2 adult beavers were found dead but were too decomposed to be necropsied, he said.\n\nThe biggest spate of deaths occurred in October [2012], when 3 beavers were found, 2 of which were necropsied. In November, a 7th beaver was found. Liebert said the most recent sighting of a live beaver, a single individual, occurred 19 Dec 2012.\n\nThe effort to isolate the cause of the deaths was hampered by several circumstances, Mateus-Pinilla said. One is that decomposition sets in rapidly, and sometimes there is not much a pathologist can do because of the condition of the body. The \"gold standard\" for a confirmed diagnosis, Mateus-Pinilla said, is the ability to grow a culture of the suspect bacteria. The Meadowbrook beavers were tested for several pathogens, including tularemia, salmonella, leptospira and canine distemper. No tests resulted positive.\n\nHowever, investigators were able to rule out toxins, such as from run-off, and also found evidence pointing to tularemia, even if it did not amount to a confirmed diagnosis.\n\nMateus-Pinilla said salmonella and leptospira were eliminated, for example, because salmonella would not have caused a die-off, and leptospira is associated with lesions not found in the necropsies. But investigators did find certain changes in the lungs typical of tularemia. In the end, Mateus-Pinilla said, what signs there were pointed to tularemia.\n\nMateus-Pinilla said it is unlikely that the habitat provided by the park itself was to blame. Indeed, she said, the fact that beavers were thriving there \"tells us it was a suitable habitat.\" Unfortunately, she said, the die-off \"also tells us that natural habitats are more and more disturbed, forcing the beavers to be in a more dense population.\"\n\nHuman attraction to nature puts people in closer contact with wildlife diseases, she added. \"We want to put our house in the woods,\" and as a result \"we are getting closer to diseases that we wouldn't find in the middle of New York City.\"\n\nMateus-Pinilla sees an opportunity for independent research through close monitoring of future colonies at Meadowbrook.\n\n\"I would love to see it happening,\" she said. The Meadowbrook beavers are \"close to one of the biggest wildlife research institutions in the United States. We have the resources, and we have the students.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is caused by the gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere.\n\n_Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits. _Francisella tularensis subsp. palaearctica_ (Type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers, muskrats) in northern North America. USA (Arizona) 20000619.0993\n.................................................sb/pmb/ejp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rabies", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-01-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Champaign", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "McCullough Creek", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1802498", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (05): (AK) snowshoe hare", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1802498", "date": "2013-03-22 20:38:04", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DIE-OFF, BEAVER - USA: (ILLINOIS) TULAREMIA SUSPECTED\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 17 Mar 2012\nSource: The News-Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.news-gazette.com/news/environment/2013-03-17/environmental-almanac-tularemia-suspected-beaver-deaths.html?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+wdinNewsDigestGeoRSS+%28Wildlife+Disease+News+Digest+GeoRSS+Feed%29&utm_term=wdinNewsDigestGeoRSS\n\n\nA beaver die-off at Urbana's Meadowbrook Park, thought to have been caused by tularemia, has emphasized the importance of keeping pets indoors or on a leash, for their own safety and that of wildlife. It also has raised questions about the impact of drought, overpopulation and habitat destruction on wildlife. Officials say there are no reports of human illness.\n\nWhat is known for sure is that 7 of the beavers that thrived in and along McCullough Creek in the park died in the last year [2012]. The cause is less certain.\n\n\"There is no conclusive evidence,\" researcher Nohra Mateus-Pinilla said, \"but it appears that the only thing that could have caused the die-off is an outbreak of tularemia.\" She emphasized that tularemia bacteria are common. \"They are present in rabbits and squirrels,\" she said. \"They are part of the natural ecosystem.\"\n\nMateus-Pinilla, a wildlife veterinary epidemiologist at the Illinois Natural History Survey, said it is possible that severe drought exacerbated the outbreak, with low water levels forcing beavers and other animals to live in closer quarters. Continuing destruction of wildlife habitat has a similar effect, she said.\n\nDerek Liebert, project manager at the Urbana Park District, said a wildlife biologist suggested to him that if tularemia is in fact the cause, the die-off may be a corrective measure for a population that grew too large.\n\nThe Champaign-Urbana Public Health District issued an alert notifying residents of tularemia in the area. The alert cited a Meadowbrook beaver diagnosed with clinical symptoms of tularemia and an unrelated 2011 outbreak among 5 pet cats in Champaign, Urbana and Savoy.\n\nHealth district planning director Awais Vaid said people should not let their pets roam and should take them to a veterinarian if they exhibit symptoms such as loss of appetite or difficulty with movement. People who see sick animals in the wild or along trails should not approach them, Vaid said, not only because of the risk of tularemia but of rabies.\n\nThe park district warns Meadowbrook users to keep pets leashed and to stay on trails in the park. Mateus-Pinilla reinforced local government warnings about allowing domestic animals to roam or run unleashed.\n\n\"Then you are bringing them into your house, where there is direct contact. That is more serious,\" she said.\n\nAccording to the National Institutes of Health, tularemia is common among wild rodents and can be transmitted to other animals and humans through direct contact and by ticks, biting flies and other insects. In humans, tularemia bacteria can cause illness ranging from asymptomatic to life-threatening.\n\nLiebert said the 1st dead beaver was found in January 2012. It was taken to the University of Illinois veterinary diagnostic laboratory, where tests were conducted, with inconclusive results. Then in June and September, 2 adult beavers were found dead but were too decomposed to be necropsied, he said.\n\nThe biggest spate of deaths occurred in October [2012], when 3 beavers were found, 2 of which were necropsied. In November, a 7th beaver was found. Liebert said the most recent sighting of a live beaver, a single individual, occurred 19 Dec 2012.\n\nThe effort to isolate the cause of the deaths was hampered by several circumstances, Mateus-Pinilla said. One is that decomposition sets in rapidly, and sometimes there is not much a pathologist can do because of the condition of the body. The \"gold standard\" for a confirmed diagnosis, Mateus-Pinilla said, is the ability to grow a culture of the suspect bacteria. The Meadowbrook beavers were tested for several pathogens, including tularemia, salmonella, leptospira and canine distemper. No tests resulted positive.\n\nHowever, investigators were able to rule out toxins, such as from run-off, and also found evidence pointing to tularemia, even if it did not amount to a confirmed diagnosis.\n\nMateus-Pinilla said salmonella and leptospira were eliminated, for example, because salmonella would not have caused a die-off, and leptospira is associated with lesions not found in the necropsies. But investigators did find certain changes in the lungs typical of tularemia. In the end, Mateus-Pinilla said, what signs there were pointed to tularemia.\n\nMateus-Pinilla said it is unlikely that the habitat provided by the park itself was to blame. Indeed, she said, the fact that beavers were thriving there \"tells us it was a suitable habitat.\" Unfortunately, she said, the die-off \"also tells us that natural habitats are more and more disturbed, forcing the beavers to be in a more dense population.\"\n\nHuman attraction to nature puts people in closer contact with wildlife diseases, she added. \"We want to put our house in the woods,\" and as a result \"we are getting closer to diseases that we wouldn't find in the middle of New York City.\"\n\nMateus-Pinilla sees an opportunity for independent research through close monitoring of future colonies at Meadowbrook.\n\n\"I would love to see it happening,\" she said. The Meadowbrook beavers are \"close to one of the biggest wildlife research institutions in the United States. We have the resources, and we have the students.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is caused by the gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere.\n\n_Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits. _Francisella tularensis subsp. palaearctica_ (Type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers, muskrats) in northern North America. It may be water- or arthropod-borne, and is less virulent to humans and rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread by contact with infected animals or environmental fomites, by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/5*UN - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\n2012\n---\nTularemia, wildlife - Denmark: east, hare, OIE 20121129.1431026\nTularemia, rabbits - USA: (AZ) 20120731.1223191\n2005\n----\nTularemia, rabbit contact - USA (AZ) 20050609.1604\n2000\n----\nTularemia, zoo animals - USA (Arizona) 20000619.0993\n.................................................sb/pmb/ejp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rabies", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-01-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Champaign", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "McCullough Creek", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1798960", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (04): (NE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1798960", "date": "2013-03-22 20:38:04", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DIE-OFF, BEAVER - USA: (ILLINOIS) TULAREMIA SUSPECTED\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 17 Mar 2012\nSource: The News-Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.news-gazette.com/news/environment/2013-03-17/environmental-almanac-tularemia-suspected-beaver-deaths.html?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+wdinNewsDigestGeoRSS+%28Wildlife+Disease+News+Digest+GeoRSS+Feed%29&utm_term=wdinNewsDigestGeoRSS\n\n\nA beaver die-off at Urbana's Meadowbrook Park, thought to have been caused by tularemia, has emphasized the importance of keeping pets indoors or on a leash, for their own safety and that of wildlife. It also has raised questions about the impact of drought, overpopulation and habitat destruction on wildlife. Officials say there are no reports of human illness.\n\nWhat is known for sure is that 7 of the beavers that thrived in and along McCullough Creek in the park died in the last year [2012]. The cause is less certain.\n\n\"There is no conclusive evidence,\" researcher Nohra Mateus-Pinilla said, \"but it appears that the only thing that could have caused the die-off is an outbreak of tularemia.\" She emphasized that tularemia bacteria are common. \"They are present in rabbits and squirrels,\" she said. \"They are part of the natural ecosystem.\"\n\nMateus-Pinilla, a wildlife veterinary epidemiologist at the Illinois Natural History Survey, said it is possible that severe drought exacerbated the outbreak, with low water levels forcing beavers and other animals to live in closer quarters. Continuing destruction of wildlife habitat has a similar effect, she said.\n\nDerek Liebert, project manager at the Urbana Park District, said a wildlife biologist suggested to him that if tularemia is in fact the cause, the die-off may be a corrective measure for a population that grew too large.\n\nThe Champaign-Urbana Public Health District issued an alert notifying residents of tularemia in the area. The alert cited a Meadowbrook beaver diagnosed with clinical symptoms of tularemia and an unrelated 2011 outbreak among 5 pet cats in Champaign, Urbana and Savoy.\n\nHealth district planning director Awais Vaid said people should not let their pets roam and should take them to a veterinarian if they exhibit symptoms such as loss of appetite or difficulty with movement. People who see sick animals in the wild or along trails should not approach them, Vaid said, not only because of the risk of tularemia but of rabies.\n\nThe park district warns Meadowbrook users to keep pets leashed and to stay on trails in the park. Mateus-Pinilla reinforced local government warnings about allowing domestic animals to roam or run unleashed.\n\n\"Then you are bringing them into your house, where there is direct contact. That is more serious,\" she said.\n\nAccording to the National Institutes of Health, tularemia is common among wild rodents and can be transmitted to other animals and humans through direct contact and by ticks, biting flies and other insects. In humans, tularemia bacteria can cause illness ranging from asymptomatic to life-threatening.\n\nLiebert said the 1st dead beaver was found in January 2012. It was taken to the University of Illinois veterinary diagnostic laboratory, where tests were conducted, with inconclusive results. Then in June and September, 2 adult beavers were found dead but were too decomposed to be necropsied, he said.\n\nThe biggest spate of deaths occurred in October [2012], when 3 beavers were found, 2 of which were necropsied. In November, a 7th beaver was found. Liebert said the most recent sighting of a live beaver, a single individual, occurred 19 Dec 2012.\n\nThe effort to isolate the cause of the deaths was hampered by several circumstances, Mateus-Pinilla said. One is that decomposition sets in rapidly, and sometimes there is not much a pathologist can do because of the condition of the body. The \"gold standard\" for a confirmed diagnosis, Mateus-Pinilla said, is the ability to grow a culture of the suspect bacteria. The Meadowbrook beavers were tested for several pathogens, including tularemia, salmonella, leptospira and canine distemper. No tests resulted positive.\n\nHowever, investigators were able to rule out toxins, such as from run-off, and also found evidence pointing to tularemia, even if it did not amount to a confirmed diagnosis.\n\nMateus-Pinilla said salmonella and leptospira were eliminated, for example, because salmonella would not have caused a die-off, and leptospira is associated with lesions not found in the necropsies. But investigators did find certain changes in the lungs typical of tularemia. In the end, Mateus-Pinilla said, what signs there were pointed to tularemia.\n\nMateus-Pinilla said it is unlikely that the habitat provided by the park itself was to blame. Indeed, she said, the fact that beavers were thriving there \"tells us it was a suitable habitat.\" Unfortunately, she said, the die-off \"also tells us that natural habitats are more and more disturbed, forcing the beavers to be in a more dense population.\"\n\nHuman attraction to nature puts people in closer contact with wildlife diseases, she added. \"We want to put our house in the woods,\" and as a result \"we are getting closer to diseases that we wouldn't find in the middle of New York City.\"\n\nMateus-Pinilla sees an opportunity for independent research through close monitoring of future colonies at Meadowbrook.\n\n\"I would love to see it happening,\" she said. The Meadowbrook beavers are \"close to one of the biggest wildlife research institutions in the United States. We have the resources, and we have the students.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is caused by the gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere.\n\n_Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits. _Francisella tularensis subsp. palaearctica_ (Type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers, muskrats) in northern North America. It may be water- or arthropod-borne, and is less virulent to humans and rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread by contact with infected animals or environmental fomites, by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/5*UN - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\n2012\n---\nTularemia, wildlife - Denmark: east, hare, OIE 20121129.1431026\nTularemia, rabbits - USA: (AZ) 20120731.1223191\n2005\n----\nTularemia, rabbit contact - USA (AZ) 20050609.1604\n2000\n----\nTularemia, zoo animals - That is more serious,\" she said.\n\nAccording to the National Institutes of Health, tularemia is common among wild rodents and can be transmitted to other animals and humans through direct contact and by ticks, biting flies and other insects. In November, a 7th beaver was found. No tests resulted positive.\n\nHowever, investigators were able to rule out toxins, such as from run-off, and also found evidence pointing to tularemia, even if it did not amount to a confirmed diagnosis.\n\nMateus-Pinilla said salmonella and leptospira were eliminated, for example, because salmonella would not have caused a die-off, and leptospira is associated with lesions not found in the necropsies. But investigators did find certain changes in the lungs typical of tularemia. In the end, Mateus-Pinilla said, what signs there were pointed to tularemia.\n\nMateus-Pinilla said it is unlikely that the habitat provided by the park itself was to blame. Indeed, she said, the fact that beavers were thriving there \"tells us it was a suitable habitat.\" Unfortunately, she said, the die-off \"also tells us that natural habitats are more and more disturbed, forcing the beavers to be in a more dense population.\"\n\nHuman attraction to nature puts people in closer contact with wildlife diseases, she added. \"We want to put our house in the woods,\" and as a result \"we are getting closer to diseases that we wouldn't find in the middle of New York City.\"\n\nMateus-Pinilla sees an opportunity for independent research through close monitoring of future colonies at Meadowbrook.\n\n\"I would love to see it happening,\" she said. The Meadowbrook beavers are \"close to one of the biggest wildlife research institutions in the United States. We have the resources, and we have the students.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is caused by the gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. USA: (IL) tularemia susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1599239", "date": "2013-03-22 20:38:04", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DIE-OFF, BEAVER - USA: (ILLINOIS) TULAREMIA SUSPECTED\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 17 Mar 2012\nSource: The News-Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.news-gazette.com/news/environment/2013-03-17/environmental-almanac-tularemia-suspected-beaver-deaths.html?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+wdinNewsDigestGeoRSS+%28Wildlife+Disease+News+Digest+GeoRSS+Feed%29&utm_term=wdinNewsDigestGeoRSS\n\n\nA beaver die-off at Urbana's Meadowbrook Park, thought to have been caused by tularemia, has emphasized the importance of keeping pets indoors or on a leash, for their own safety and that of wildlife. Officials say there are no reports of human illness.\n\nWhat is known for sure is that 7 of the beavers that thrived in and along McCullough Creek in the park died in the last year [2012]. The cause is less certain.\n\n\"There is no conclusive evidence,\" researcher Nohra Mateus-Pinilla said, \"but it appears that the only thing that could have caused the die-off is an outbreak of tularemia.\" She emphasized that tularemia bacteria are common. \"They are present in rabbits and squirrels,\" she said. \"They are part of the natural ecosystem.\"\n\nMateus-Pinilla, a wildlife veterinary epidemiologist at the Illinois Natural History Survey, said it is possible that severe drought exacerbated the outbreak, with low water levels forcing beavers and other animals to live in closer quarters. Continuing destruction of wildlife habitat has a similar effect, she said.\n\nDerek Liebert, project manager at the Urbana Park District, said a wildlife biologist suggested to him that if tularemia is in fact the cause, the die-off may be a corrective measure for a population that grew too large.\n\nThe Champaign-Urbana Public Health District issued an alert notifying residents of tularemia in the area. The alert cited a Meadowbrook beaver diagnosed with clinical symptoms of tularemia and an unrelated 2011 outbreak among 5 pet cats in Champaign, Urbana and Savoy.\n\nHealth district planning director Awais Vaid said people should not let their pets roam and should take them to a veterinarian if they exhibit symptoms such as loss of appetite or difficulty with movement. People who see sick animals in the wild or along trails should not approach them, Vaid said, not only because of the risk of tularemia but of rabies.\n\nThe park district warns Meadowbrook users to keep pets leashed and to stay on trails in the park. Mateus-Pinilla reinforced local government warnings about allowing domestic animals to roam or run unleashed.\n\n\"Then you are bringing them into your house, where there is direct contact. That is more serious,\" she said.\n\nAccording to the National Institutes of Health, tularemia is common among wild rodents and can be transmitted to other animals and humans through direct contact and by ticks, biting flies and other insects. In humans, tularemia bacteria can cause illness ranging from asymptomatic to life-threatening.\n\nLiebert said the 1st dead beaver was found in January 2012. It was taken to the University of Illinois veterinary diagnostic laboratory, where tests were conducted, with inconclusive results. Then in June and September, 2 adult beavers were found dead but were too decomposed to be necropsied, he said.\n\nThe biggest spate of deaths occurred in October [2012], when 3 beavers were found, 2 of which were necropsied. In November, a 7th beaver was found. Liebert said the most recent sighting of a live beaver, a single individual, occurred 19 Dec 2012.\n\nThe effort to isolate the cause of the deaths was hampered by several circumstances, Mateus-Pinilla said. One is that decomposition sets in rapidly, and sometimes there is not much a pathologist can do because of the condition of the body. The \"gold standard\" for a confirmed diagnosis, Mateus-Pinilla said, is the ability to grow a culture of the suspect bacteria. The Meadowbrook beavers were tested for several pathogens, including tularemia, salmonella, leptospira and canine distemper. No tests resulted positive.\n\nHowever, investigators were able to rule out toxins, such as from run-off, and also found evidence pointing to tularemia, even if it did not amount to a confirmed diagnosis.\n\nMateus-Pinilla said salmonella and leptospira were eliminated, for example, because salmonella would not have caused a die-off, and leptospira is associated with lesions not found in the necropsies. But investigators did find certain changes in the lungs typical of tularemia. In the end, Mateus-Pinilla said, what signs there were pointed to tularemia.\n\nMateus-Pinilla said it is unlikely that the habitat provided by the park itself was to blame. Indeed, she said, the fact that beavers were thriving there \"tells us it was a suitable habitat.\" Unfortunately, she said, the die-off \"also tells us that natural habitats are more and more disturbed, forcing the beavers to be in a more dense population.\"\n\nHuman attraction to nature puts people in closer contact with wildlife diseases, she added. \"We want to put our house in the woods,\" and as a result \"we are getting closer to diseases that we wouldn't find in the middle of New York City.\"\n\nMateus-Pinilla sees an opportunity for independent research through close monitoring of future colonies at Meadowbrook.\n\n\"I would love to see it happening,\" she said. The Meadowbrook beavers are \"close to one of the biggest wildlife research institutions in the United States. We have the resources, and we have the students.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is caused by the gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere.\n\n_Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits. _Francisella tularensis subsp. palaearctica_ (Type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers, muskrats) in northern North America. It may be water- or arthropod-borne, and is less virulent to humans and rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread by contact with infected animals or environmental fomites, by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/5*UN - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\n2012\n---\nTularemia, wildlife - Denmark: east, hare, OIE 20121129.1431026\nTularemia, rabbits - USA: (AZ) 20120731.1223191\n2005\n----\nTularemia, rabbit contact - USA (AZ) 20050609.1604\n2000\n----\nTularemia, zoo animals - USA (Arizona) 20000619.0993\n.................................................sb/pmb/ejp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rabies", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-01-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Champaign", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "McCullough Creek", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1560910", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA: (NC) hunters", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1560910", "date": "2011-11-22 16:01:41", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN, POSSUM - AUSTRALIA (03): (TASMANIA)\n*****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 22 Nov 2011\nFrom: Mark Veitch <mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au> and Louise Cooley\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au> [edited]\n\n\nThere have now been 2 human cases of tularemia diagnosed in Tasmania\nin 2011, 1 in June, the other in October. Both cases were women in\ntheir 40s, each bitten and/or scratched by separate possums (probably\njuvenile and probably ill) at points only a few kilometers apart along\na remote road in western Tasmania. Both developed the ulcero-glandular\nform of tularemia, with ulceration at the site of the injury and\nprominent lymphadenitis. The 1st case recovered after a complicated\ncourse, the 2nd is improving on treatment.\n\nThe microbiological collaboration between the Royal Hobart Hospital\nand Westmead Hospital laboratories has been crucial. Both diagnoses\nwere supported by positive DFA [direct fluorescent-antibody assay] on\nexcised or aspirated tissues. PCR-based characterization of genetic\nmaterial from the 1st case suggested the strain of _Francisella\ntularensis_ involved was _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_\nbiovar _japonica_.\n\nTherefore, the clinical and microbiological evidence to date points to\nthese zoonotic infections (and possible epizootic) being due to one of\nthe relatively less virulent strains of _F. tularensis_, that is, not\nthe type A or subspecies _tularensis_ strain more often associated\nwith serious sepsis such as pneumonia and septicemia in parts of the\nnorthern hemisphere. The recent Tasmanian cases also appear to be\ndifferent from the case acquired in the NT a decade ago (_F.\nnovicida_).\n\nPublic health actions so far have included information to animal\nhandlers who might work in the area of the 1st case, wider public\nadvice around wild animal contact via the media, and alerts to\nclinicians and laboratories. The extent of the risk-area for this\ninfection within Tasmania is unclear, but based on these recent cases,\nmay be relatively restricted. We will also address the possibility of\nrisk from water, by reiterating existing guidance around protecting\nprivate water supplies from microbial hazards, and rendering raw water\nsafe by boiling it. We are engaging with our Department of Primary\nIndustry, Parks, Wildlife and the Environment around further\ninvestigations. These have begun.\n\nWe would like to pass the following points on to infectious disease\nphysicians, microbiologists, and their colleagues who may not\npreviously have considered the possibility of tularemia acquired in\nthe Southern Hemisphere.\n\nClinical features that raise the possibility of Tasmanian-acquired _F.\ntularensis_ infection include\n- an animal bite or scratch or close exposure to wild animals or their\nenvironment, particularly in the region of the West Coast of Tasmania;\n- persistent local soft tissue infection at the inoculation site and\nregional lymphadenitis, which may suppurate;\n- disease progression, or a poor response, with beta-lactam antibiotic\ntherapy.\n\n_F. tularensis_ is a major laboratory hazard; clinical specimens must\nbe managed by a laboratory with PC3 [physical containment level 3]\nfacilities.\n\n--\nDr Mark Veitch\nTasmanian Department of Health and Human Services\nTasmania, Australia\n<mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\nand\nDr Louise Cooley\nRoyal Hobart Hospital\nTasmania, Australia\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\n\n[ProMED-mail sincerely thanks Dr Veitch and Dr Cooley for supplying\nvital information regarding the clinical circumstances and\nmicrobiological data regarding these 2 separate cases of\nulceroglandular tularemia acquired from possums in Tasmania. The\norganism _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_ biovar _japonica_ is\ndistinct from other _holarctica_ strains that are found in Europe,\nAsia, and the USA (1). These _holarctica_ strains, also referred to as\ntype B tularemia tend to produce significantly milder disease in man\nthan the subspecies _tularensis_.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Champion MD, Zeng Q, Nix EB, et al: Comparative genomic\ncharacterization of _Francisella tularensis_ strains belonging to low\nand high virulence subspecies. PLoS Pathogens 2009; 5(5): e1000459.\nAvailable at\nhttp://www.plospathogens.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.ppat.1000459.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia, human, possum - Australia (02): (TS), RFI 20111108.3324\nTularemia, human, possum - USA (UT, NJ) 20070716.2283\nUndiagnosed fatal illness - Iran (Sistan-Baluchestan) (02): tularemia?\n20070423.1329\nTularemia, water-borne - Norway (North) 20070329.1081\n.................................................ll/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:40", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - AUSTRALIA (03): (TASMANIA)\n*****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 22 Nov 2011\nFrom: Mark Veitch <mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au> and Louise Cooley\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au> [edited]\n\n\nThere have now been 2 human cases of tularemia diagnosed in Tasmania\nin 2011, 1 in June, the other in October. Both cases were women in\ntheir 40s, each bitten and/or scratched by separate possums (probably\njuvenile and probably ill) at points only a few kilometers apart along\na remote road in western Tasmania. Both developed the ulcero-glandular\nform of tularemia, with ulceration at the site of the injury and\nprominent lymphadenitis. The 1st case recovered after a complicated\ncourse, the 2nd is improving on treatment.\n\nThe microbiological collaboration between the Royal Hobart Hospital\nand Westmead Hospital laboratories has been crucial. Both diagnoses\nwere supported by positive DFA [direct fluorescent-antibody assay] on\nexcised or aspirated tissues. PCR-based characterization of genetic\nmaterial from the 1st case suggested the strain of _Francisella\ntularensis_ involved was _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_\nbiovar _japonica_.\n\nTherefore, the clinical and microbiological evidence to date points to\nthese zoonotic infections (and possible epizootic) being due to one of\nthe relatively less virulent strains of _F. tularensis_, that is, not\nthe type A or subspecies _tularensis_ strain more often associated\nwith serious sepsis such as pneumonia and septicemia in parts of the\nnorthern hemisphere. The recent Tasmanian cases also appear to be\ndifferent from the case acquired in the NT a decade ago (_F.\nnovicida_).\n\nPublic health actions so far have included information to animal\nhandlers who might work in the area of the 1st case, wider public\nadvice around wild animal contact via the media, and alerts to\nclinicians and laboratories. The extent of the risk-area for this\ninfection within Tasmania is unclear, but based on these recent cases,\nmay be relatively restricted. We will also address the possibility of\nrisk from water, by reiterating existing guidance around protecting\nprivate water supplies from microbial hazards, and rendering raw water\nsafe by boiling it. We are engaging with our Department of Primary\nIndustry, Parks, Wildlife and the Environment around further\ninvestigations. These have begun.\n\nWe would like to pass the following points on to infectious disease\nphysicians, microbiologists, and their colleagues who may not\npreviously have considered the possibility of tularemia acquired in\nthe Southern Hemisphere.\n\nClinical features that raise the possibility of Tasmanian-acquired _F.\ntularensis_ infection include\n- an animal bite or scratch or close exposure to wild animals or their\nenvironment, particularly in the region of the West Coast of Tasmania;\n- persistent local soft tissue infection at the inoculation site and\nregional lymphadenitis, which may suppurate;\n- disease progression, or a poor response, with beta-lactam antibiotic\ntherapy.\n\n_F. tularensis_ is a major laboratory hazard; clinical specimens must\nbe managed by a laboratory with PC3 [physical containment level 3]\nfacilities.\n\n--\nDr Mark Veitch\nTasmanian Department of Health and Human Services\nTasmania, Australia\n<mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\nand\nDr Louise Cooley\nRoyal Hobart Hospital\nTasmania, Australia\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\n\n[ProMED-mail sincerely thanks Dr Veitch and Dr Cooley for supplying\nvital information regarding the clinical circumstances and\nmicrobiological data regarding these 2 separate cases of\nulceroglandular tularemia acquired from possums in Tasmania. The\norganism _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_ biovar _japonica_ is\ndistinct from other _holarctica_ strains that are found in Europe,\nAsia, and the USA (1). These _holarctica_ strains, also referred to as\ntype B tularemia tend to produce significantly milder disease in man\nthan the subspecies _tularensis_.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. USA (UT, NJ) 20070716.2283\nUndiagnosed fatal illness - Iran (Sistan-Baluchestan) (02): tularemia?\n20070423.1329\nTularemia, water-borne - Norway (North) 20070329.1081\n.................................................ll/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:40", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia -
