Wuerttemberg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1415382", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, pneumonic - Canada: (AB) biologic immunomodulator", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1415382", "date": "2011-11-22 16:01:41", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN, POSSUM - AUSTRALIA (03): (TASMANIA)\n*****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 22 Nov 2011\nFrom: Mark Veitch <mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au> and Louise Cooley\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au> [edited]\n\n\nThere have now been 2 human cases of tularemia diagnosed in Tasmania\nin 2011, 1 in June, the other in October. Both cases were women in\ntheir 40s, each bitten and/or scratched by separate possums (probably\njuvenile and probably ill) at points only a few kilometers apart along\na remote road in western Tasmania. Both developed the ulcero-glandular\nform of tularemia, with ulceration at the site of the injury and\nprominent lymphadenitis. The 1st case recovered after a complicated\ncourse, the 2nd is improving on treatment.\n\nThe microbiological collaboration between the Royal Hobart Hospital\nand Westmead Hospital laboratories has been crucial. Both diagnoses\nwere supported by positive DFA [direct fluorescent-antibody assay] on\nexcised or aspirated tissues. PCR-based characterization of genetic\nmaterial from the 1st case suggested the strain of _Francisella\ntularensis_ involved was _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_\nbiovar _japonica_.\n\nTherefore, the clinical and microbiological evidence to date points to\nthese zoonotic infections (and possible epizootic) being due to one of\nthe relatively less virulent strains of _F. tularensis_, that is, not\nthe type A or subspecies _tularensis_ strain more often associated\nwith serious sepsis such as pneumonia and septicemia in parts of the\nnorthern hemisphere. The recent Tasmanian cases also appear to be\ndifferent from the case acquired in the NT a decade ago (_F.\nnovicida_).\n\nPublic health actions so far have included information to animal\nhandlers who might work in the area of the 1st case, wider public\nadvice around wild animal contact via the media, and alerts to\nclinicians and laboratories. The extent of the risk-area for this\ninfection within Tasmania is unclear, but based on these recent cases,\nmay be relatively restricted. We will also address the possibility of\nrisk from water, by reiterating existing guidance around protecting\nprivate water supplies from microbial hazards, and rendering raw water\nsafe by boiling it. We are engaging with our Department of Primary\nIndustry, Parks, Wildlife and the Environment around further\ninvestigations. These have begun.\n\nWe would like to pass the following points on to infectious disease\nphysicians, microbiologists, and their colleagues who may not\npreviously have considered the possibility of tularemia acquired in\nthe Southern Hemisphere.\n\nClinical features that raise the possibility of Tasmanian-acquired _F.\ntularensis_ infection include\n- an animal bite or scratch or close exposure to wild animals or their\nenvironment, particularly in the region of the West Coast of Tasmania;\n- persistent local soft tissue infection at the inoculation site and\nregional lymphadenitis, which may suppurate;\n- disease progression, or a poor response, with beta-lactam antibiotic\ntherapy.\n\n_F. tularensis_ is a major laboratory hazard; clinical specimens must\nbe managed by a laboratory with PC3 [physical containment level 3]\nfacilities.\n\n--\nDr Mark Veitch\nTasmanian Department of Health and Human Services\nTasmania, Australia\n<mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\nand\nDr Louise Cooley\nRoyal Hobart Hospital\nTasmania, Australia\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\n\n[ProMED-mail sincerely thanks Dr Veitch and Dr Cooley for supplying\nvital information regarding the clinical circumstances and\nmicrobiological data regarding these 2 separate cases of\nulceroglandular tularemia acquired from possums in Tasmania. The\norganism _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_ biovar _japonica_ is\ndistinct from other _holarctica_ strains that are found in Europe,\nAsia, and the USA (1). These _holarctica_ strains, also referred to as\ntype B tularemia tend to produce significantly milder disease in man\nthan the subspecies _tularensis_.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Champion MD, Zeng Q, Nix EB, et al: Comparative genomic\ncharacterization of _Francisella tularensis_ strains belonging to low\nand high virulence subspecies. PLoS Pathogens 2009; 5(5): e1000459.\nAvailable at\nhttp://www.plospathogens.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.ppat.1000459.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia, human, possum - Australia (02): (TS), RFI 20111108.3324\nTularemia, human, possum - Australia: (TS), RFI 20111105.3299\nTularemia - USA: (DE) 20111011.3043\nTularemia, pneumonic - Taiwan: (Taipei) ex USA 20110812.2445\nTularemia, imported - Germany: (Berlin) ex Turkey, alert\n20110510.1441\nTularemia - Norway (02): (central) 20110401.1007\nTularemia - Norway: (central) 20110225.0622\n2009\n----\nTularemia, laboratory-acquired - USA: (MD) 20091207.4167\nTularemia, human - USA: (AK), RFI 20090810.2845\n2008\n----\nTularemia, human, feline - USA: (NV) 20080825.2652\nTularemia - Spain: (northern) 2007 20080815.2538\nTularemia - Russia: (Moscow) 20080722.2227\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA: (NYC) 20080612.1863\nTularemia - Thailand: (Prachuap Khiri Khan), RFI 20080318.1049\nTularemia, human, hare, 2007 - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky) 20070826.2804\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02) 20070813.2646\nTularemia - USA (UT,NJ) (05): UT 20070809.2590\nTularemia - USA (WY) 20070803.2525\nTularemia - USA (UT, NJ) 20070716.2283\nUndiagnosed fatal illness - Iran (Sistan-Baluchestan) (02): tularemia?\n20070423.1329\nTularemia, water-borne - Norway (North) 20070329.1081\n.................................................ll/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:40", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Berlin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taipei", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Tasmania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baden - Wuerttemberg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1366708", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Russia (02): (KX) susp. NOT anthrax", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1366708", "date": "2011-11-22 16:01:41", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN, POSSUM - AUSTRALIA (03): (TASMANIA)\n*****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 22 Nov 2011\nFrom: Mark Veitch <mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au> and Louise Cooley\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au> [edited]\n\n\nThere have now been 2 human cases of tularemia diagnosed in Tasmania\nin 2011, 1 in June, the other in October. Both cases were women in\ntheir 40s, each bitten and/or scratched by separate possums (probably\njuvenile and probably ill) at points only a few kilometers apart along\na remote road in western Tasmania. Both developed the ulcero-glandular\nform of tularemia, with ulceration at the site of the injury and\nprominent lymphadenitis. The 1st case recovered after a complicated\ncourse, the 2nd is improving on treatment.\n\nThe microbiological collaboration between the Royal Hobart Hospital\nand Westmead Hospital laboratories has been crucial. Both diagnoses\nwere supported by positive DFA [direct fluorescent-antibody assay] on\nexcised or aspirated tissues. PCR-based characterization of genetic\nmaterial from the 1st case suggested the strain of _Francisella\ntularensis_ involved was _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_\nbiovar _japonica_.\n\nTherefore, the clinical and microbiological evidence to date points to\nthese zoonotic infections (and possible epizootic) being due to one of\nthe relatively less virulent strains of _F. tularensis_, that is, not\nthe type A or subspecies _tularensis_ strain more often associated\nwith serious sepsis such as pneumonia and septicemia in parts of the\nnorthern hemisphere. The recent Tasmanian cases also appear to be\ndifferent from the case acquired in the NT a decade ago (_F.\nnovicida_).\n\nPublic health actions so far have included information to animal\nhandlers who might work in the area of the 1st case, wider public\nadvice around wild animal contact via the media, and alerts to\nclinicians and laboratories. The extent of the risk-area for this\ninfection within Tasmania is unclear, but based on these recent cases,\nmay be relatively restricted. We will also address the possibility of\nrisk from water, by reiterating existing guidance around protecting\nprivate water supplies from microbial hazards, and rendering raw water\nsafe by boiling it. We are engaging with our Department of Primary\nIndustry, Parks, Wildlife and the Environment around further\ninvestigations. These have begun.\n\nWe would like to pass the following points on to infectious disease\nphysicians, microbiologists, and their colleagues who may not\npreviously have considered the possibility of tularemia acquired in\nthe Southern Hemisphere.\n\nClinical features that raise the possibility of Tasmanian-acquired _F.\ntularensis_ infection include\n- an animal bite or scratch or close exposure to wild animals or their\nenvironment, particularly in the region of the West Coast of Tasmania;\n- persistent local soft tissue infection at the inoculation site and\nregional lymphadenitis, which may suppurate;\n- disease progression, or a poor response, with beta-lactam antibiotic\ntherapy.\n\n_F. tularensis_ is a major laboratory hazard; clinical specimens must\nbe managed by a laboratory with PC3 [physical containment level 3]\nfacilities.\n\n--\nDr Mark Veitch\nTasmanian Department of Health and Human Services\nTasmania, Australia\n<mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\nand\nDr Louise Cooley\nRoyal Hobart Hospital\nTasmania, Australia\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\n\n[ProMED-mail sincerely thanks Dr Veitch and Dr Cooley for supplying\nvital information regarding the clinical circumstances and\nmicrobiological data regarding these 2 separate cases of\nulceroglandular tularemia acquired from possums in Tasmania. The\norganism _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_ biovar _japonica_ is\ndistinct from other _holarctica_ strains that are found in Europe,\nAsia, and the USA (1). These _holarctica_ strains, also referred to as\ntype B tularemia tend to produce significantly milder disease in man\nthan the subspecies _tularensis_.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Champion MD, Zeng Q, Nix EB, et al: Comparative genomic\ncharacterization of _Francisella tularensis_ strains belonging to low\nand high virulence subspecies. PLoS Pathogens 2009; 5(5): e1000459.\nAvailable at\nhttp://www.plospathogens.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.ppat.1000459.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia, human, possum - Australia (02): (TS), RFI 20111108.3324\nTularemia, human, possum - Australia: (TS), RFI 20111105.3299\nTularemia - USA: (DE) 20111011.3043\nTularemia, pneumonic - Taiwan: (Taipei) ex USA 20110812.2445\nTularemia, imported - Germany: (Berlin) ex Turkey, alert\n20110510.1441\nTularemia - Norway (02): (central) 20110401.1007\nTularemia - Norway: (central) 20110225.0622\n2009\n----\nTularemia, laboratory-acquired - USA: (MD) 20091207.4167\nTularemia, human - USA: (AK), RFI 20090810.2845\n2008\n----\nTularemia, human, feline - USA: (NV) 20080825.2652\nTularemia - Spain: (northern) 2007 20080815.2538\nTularemia - Russia: (Moscow) 20080722.2227\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA: (NYC) 20080612.1863\nTularemia - Thailand: (Prachuap Khiri Khan), RFI 20080318.1049\nTularemia, human, hare, 2007 - Germany: (Baden-Wuerttemberg)\n20080218.0640\n2007\n----\nTularemia, hunter - Russia: (Amur) 20071207.3946\nTularemia - Spain (03): (northern) 20071108.3626\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky) (03) 20070910.2988\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky) 20070826.2804\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02) 20070813.2646\nTularemia - USA (UT,NJ) (05): UT 20070809.2590\nTularemia - USA (WY) 20070803.2525\nTularemia - USA (UT, NJ) 20070716.2283\nUndiagnosed fatal illness - Iran (Sistan-Baluchestan) (02): tularemia?\n20070423.1329\nTularemia, water-borne - Norway (North) 20070329.1081\n.................................................ll/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:40", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - Wuerttemberg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1290255", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, human, possum, 2011 - Australia: (TS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1290255", "date": "2011-11-22 16:01:41", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN, POSSUM - AUSTRALIA (03): (TASMANIA)\n*****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 22 Nov 2011\nFrom: Mark Veitch <mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au> and Louise Cooley\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au> [edited]\n\n\nThere have now been 2 human cases of tularemia diagnosed in Tasmania\nin 2011, 1 in June, the other in October. Both cases were women in\ntheir 40s, each bitten and/or scratched by separate possums (probably\njuvenile and probably ill) at points only a few kilometers apart along\na remote road in western Tasmania. Both developed the ulcero-glandular\nform of tularemia, with ulceration at the site of the injury and\nprominent lymphadenitis. The 1st case recovered after a complicated\ncourse, the 2nd is improving on treatment.\n\nThe microbiological collaboration between the Royal Hobart Hospital\nand Westmead Hospital laboratories has been crucial. Both diagnoses\nwere supported by positive DFA [direct fluorescent-antibody assay] on\nexcised or aspirated tissues. PCR-based characterization of genetic\nmaterial from the 1st case suggested the strain of _Francisella\ntularensis_ involved was _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_\nbiovar _japonica_.\n\nTherefore, the clinical and microbiological evidence to date points to\nthese zoonotic infections (and possible epizootic) being due to one of\nthe relatively less virulent strains of _F. tularensis_, that is, not\nthe type A or subspecies _tularensis_ strain more often associated\nwith serious sepsis such as pneumonia and septicemia in parts of the\nnorthern hemisphere. The recent Tasmanian cases also appear to be\ndifferent from the case acquired in the NT a decade ago (_F.\nnovicida_).\n\nPublic health actions so far have included information to animal\nhandlers who might work in the area of the 1st case, wider public\nadvice around wild animal contact via the media, and alerts to\nclinicians and laboratories. The extent of the risk-area for this\ninfection within Tasmania is unclear, but based on these recent cases,\nmay be relatively restricted. We will also address the possibility of\nrisk from water, by reiterating existing guidance around protecting\nprivate water supplies from microbial hazards, and rendering raw water\nsafe by boiling it. We are engaging with our Department of Primary\nIndustry, Parks, Wildlife and the Environment around further\ninvestigations. These have begun.\n\nWe would like to pass the following points on to infectious disease\nphysicians, microbiologists, and their colleagues who may not\npreviously have considered the possibility of tularemia acquired in\nthe Southern Hemisphere.\n\nClinical features that raise the possibility of Tasmanian-acquired _F.\ntularensis_ infection include\n- an animal bite or scratch or close exposure to wild animals or their\nenvironment, particularly in the region of the West Coast of Tasmania;\n- persistent local soft tissue infection at the inoculation site and\nregional lymphadenitis, which may suppurate;\n- disease progression, or a poor response, with beta-lactam antibiotic\ntherapy.\n\n_F. tularensis_ is a major laboratory hazard; clinical specimens must\nbe managed by a laboratory with PC3 [physical containment level 3]\nfacilities.\n\n--\nDr Mark Veitch\nTasmanian Department of Health and Human Services\nTasmania, Australia\n<mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\nand\nDr Louise Cooley\nRoyal Hobart Hospital\nTasmania, Australia\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\n\n[ProMED-mail sincerely thanks Dr Veitch and Dr Cooley for supplying\nvital information regarding the clinical circumstances and\nmicrobiological data regarding these 2 separate cases of\nulceroglandular tularemia acquired from possums in Tasmania. The\norganism _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_ biovar _japonica_ is\ndistinct from other _holarctica_ strains that are found in Europe,\nAsia, and the USA (1). These _holarctica_ strains, also referred to as\ntype B tularemia tend to produce significantly milder disease in man\nthan the subspecies _tularensis_.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. AUSTRALIA (03): (TASMANIA)\n*****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 22 Nov 2011\nFrom: Mark Veitch <mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au> and Louise Cooley\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au> [edited]\n\n\nThere have now been 2 human cases of tularemia diagnosed in Tasmania\nin 2011, 1 in June, the other in October. Both cases were women in\ntheir 40s, each bitten and/or scratched by separate possums (probably\njuvenile and probably ill) at points only a few kilometers apart along\na remote road in western Tasmania. Both developed the ulcero-glandular\nform of tularemia, with ulceration at the site of the injury and\nprominent lymphadenitis. The 1st case recovered after a complicated\ncourse, the 2nd is improving on treatment.\n\nThe microbiological collaboration between the Royal Hobart Hospital\nand Westmead Hospital laboratories has been crucial. Both diagnoses\nwere supported by positive DFA [direct fluorescent-antibody assay] on\nexcised or aspirated tissues. PCR-based characterization of genetic\nmaterial from the 1st case suggested the strain of _Francisella\ntularensis_ involved was _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_\nbiovar _japonica_.\n\nTherefore, the clinical and microbiological evidence to date points to\nthese zoonotic infections (and possible epizootic) being due to one of\nthe relatively less virulent strains of _F. tularensis_, that is, not\nthe type A or subspecies _tularensis_ strain more often associated\nwith serious sepsis such as pneumonia and septicemia in parts of the\nnorthern hemisphere. The recent Tasmanian cases also appear to be\ndifferent from the case acquired in the NT a decade ago (_F.\nnovicida_).\n\nPublic health actions so far have included information to animal\nhandlers who might work in the area of the 1st case, wider public\nadvice around wild animal contact via the media, and alerts to\nclinicians and laboratories. The extent of the risk-area for this\ninfection within Tasmania is unclear, but based on these recent cases,\nmay be relatively restricted. We will also address the possibility of\nrisk from water, by reiterating existing guidance around protecting\nprivate water supplies from microbial hazards, and rendering raw water\nsafe by boiling it. We are engaging with our Department of Primary\nIndustry, Parks, Wildlife and the Environment around further\ninvestigations. These have begun.\n\nWe would like to pass the following points on to infectious disease\nphysicians, microbiologists, and their colleagues who may not\npreviously have considered the possibility of tularemia acquired in\nthe Southern Hemisphere.\n\nClinical features that raise the possibility of Tasmanian-acquired _F.\ntularensis_ infection include\n- an animal bite or scratch or close exposure to wild animals or their\nenvironment, particularly in the region of the West Coast of Tasmania;\n- persistent local soft tissue infection at the inoculation site and\nregional lymphadenitis, which may suppurate;\n- disease progression, or a poor response, with beta-lactam antibiotic\ntherapy.\n\n_F. tularensis_ is a major laboratory hazard; clinical specimens must\nbe managed by a laboratory with PC3 [physical containment level 3]\nfacilities.\n\n--\nDr Mark Veitch\nTasmanian Department of Health and Human Services\nTasmania, Australia\n<mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\nand\nDr Louise Cooley\nRoyal Hobart Hospital\nTasmania, Australia\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\n\n[ProMED-mail sincerely thanks Dr Veitch and Dr Cooley for supplying\nvital information regarding the clinical circumstances and\nmicrobiological data regarding these 2 separate cases of\nulceroglandular tularemia acquired from possums in Tasmania. The\norganism _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_ biovar _japonica_ is\ndistinct from other _holarctica_ strains that are found in Europe,\nAsia, and the USA (1). These _holarctica_ strains, also referred to as\ntype B tularemia tend to produce significantly milder disease in man\nthan the subspecies _tularensis_.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Wuerttemberg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1223191", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, rabbits - USA: (AZ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1223191", "date": "2011-11-22 16:01:41", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN, POSSUM - AUSTRALIA (03): (TASMANIA)\n*****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 22 Nov 2011\nFrom: Mark Veitch <mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au> and Louise Cooley\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au> [edited]\n\n\nThere have now been 2 human cases of tularemia diagnosed in Tasmania\nin 2011, 1 in June, the other in October. Both cases were women in\ntheir 40s, each bitten and/or scratched by separate possums (probably\njuvenile and probably ill) at points only a few kilometers apart along\na remote road in western Tasmania. Both developed the ulcero-glandular\nform of tularemia, with ulceration at the site of the injury and\nprominent lymphadenitis. The 1st case recovered after a complicated\ncourse, the 2nd is improving on treatment.\n\nThe microbiological collaboration between the Royal Hobart Hospital\nand Westmead Hospital laboratories has been crucial. Both diagnoses\nwere supported by positive DFA [direct fluorescent-antibody assay] on\nexcised or aspirated tissues. PCR-based characterization of genetic\nmaterial from the 1st case suggested the strain of _Francisella\ntularensis_ involved was _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_\nbiovar _japonica_.\n\nTherefore, the clinical and microbiological evidence to date points to\nthese zoonotic infections (and possible epizootic) being due to one of\nthe relatively less virulent strains of _F. tularensis_, that is, not\nthe type A or subspecies _tularensis_ strain more often associated\nwith serious sepsis such as pneumonia and septicemia in parts of the\nnorthern hemisphere. The recent Tasmanian cases also appear to be\ndifferent from the case acquired in the NT a decade ago (_F.\nnovicida_).\n\nPublic health actions so far have included information to animal\nhandlers who might work in the area of the 1st case, wider public\nadvice around wild animal contact via the media, and alerts to\nclinicians and laboratories. The extent of the risk-area for this\ninfection within Tasmania is unclear, but based on these recent cases,\nmay be relatively restricted. We will also address the possibility of\nrisk from water, by reiterating existing guidance around protecting\nprivate water supplies from microbial hazards, and rendering raw water\nsafe by boiling it. We are engaging with our Department of Primary\nIndustry, Parks, Wildlife and the Environment around further\ninvestigations. These have begun.\n\nWe would like to pass the following points on to infectious disease\nphysicians, microbiologists, and their colleagues who may not\npreviously have considered the possibility of tularemia acquired in\nthe Southern Hemisphere.\n\nClinical features that raise the possibility of Tasmanian-acquired _F.\ntularensis_ infection include\n- an animal bite or scratch or close exposure to wild animals or their\nenvironment, particularly in the region of the West Coast of Tasmania;\n- persistent local soft tissue infection at the inoculation site and\nregional lymphadenitis, which may suppurate;\n- disease progression, or a poor response, with beta-lactam antibiotic\ntherapy.\n\n_F. tularensis_ is a major laboratory hazard; clinical specimens must\nbe managed by a laboratory with PC3 [physical containment level 3]\nfacilities.\n\n--\nDr Mark Veitch\nTasmanian Department of Health and Human Services\nTasmania, Australia\n<mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\nand\nDr Louise Cooley\nRoyal Hobart Hospital\nTasmania, Australia\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\n\n[ProMED-mail sincerely thanks Dr Veitch and Dr Cooley for supplying\nvital information regarding the clinical circumstances and\nmicrobiological data regarding these 2 separate cases of\nulceroglandular tularemia acquired from possums in Tasmania. The\norganism _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_ biovar _japonica_ is\ndistinct from other _holarctica_ strains that are found in Europe,\nAsia, and the USA (1). These _holarctica_ strains, also referred to as\ntype B tularemia tend to produce significantly milder disease in man\nthan the subspecies _tularensis_.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Champion MD, Zeng Q, Nix EB, et al: Comparative genomic\ncharacterization of _Francisella tularensis_ strains belonging to low\nand high virulence subspecies. PLoS Pathogens 2009; 5(5): e1000459.\nAvailable at\nhttp://www.plospathogens.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.ppat.1000459.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia, human, possum - Australia (02): (TS), RFI 20111108.3324\nTularemia, human, possum - Australia: (TS), RFI 20111105.3299\nTularemia - USA: (DE) 20111011.3043\nTularemia, pneumonic - Taiwan: (Taipei) ex USA 20110812.2445\nTularemia, imported - Germany: (Berlin) ex Turkey, alert\n20110510.1441\nTularemia - Norway (02): (central) 20110401.1007\nTularemia - Norway: (central) 20110225.0622\n2009\n----\nTularemia, laboratory-acquired - USA: (MD) 20091207.4167\nTularemia, human - USA: (AK), RFI 20090810.2845\n2008\n----\nTularemia, human, feline - USA: (NV) 20080825.2652\nTularemia - Spain: (northern) 2007 20080815.2538\nTularemia - Russia: (Moscow) 20080722.2227\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA: (NYC) 20080612.1863\nTularemia - Thailand: (Prachuap Khiri Khan), RFI 20080318.1049\nTularemia, human, hare, 2007 - Germany: (Baden-Wuerttemberg)\n20080218.0640\n2007\n----\nTularemia, hunter - Russia: (Amur) 20071207.3946\nTularemia - Spain (03): (northern) 20071108.3626\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky) (03) 20070910.2988\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky) 20070826.2804\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02) 20070813.2646\nTularemia - USA (UT,NJ) (05): UT 20070809.2590\nTularemia - USA (WY) 20070803.2525\nTularemia - USA (UT, NJ) 20070716.2283\nUndiagnosed fatal illness - Iran (Sistan-Baluchestan) (02): tularemia?\n20070423.1329\nTularemia, water-borne - Norway (North) 20070329.1081\n.................................................ll/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:40", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - AUSTRALIA (03): (TASMANIA)\n*****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 22 Nov 2011\nFrom: Mark Veitch <mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au> and Louise Cooley\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au> [edited]\n\n\nThere have now been 2 human cases of tularemia diagnosed in Tasmania\nin 2011, 1 in June, the other in October. Both cases were women in\ntheir 40s, each bitten and/or scratched by separate possums (probably\njuvenile and probably ill) at points only a few kilometers apart along\na remote road in western Tasmania. Both developed the ulcero-glandular\nform of tularemia, with ulceration at the site of the injury and\nprominent lymphadenitis. The 1st case recovered after a complicated\ncourse, the 2nd is improving on treatment.\n\nThe microbiological collaboration between the Royal Hobart Hospital\nand Westmead Hospital laboratories has been crucial. Both diagnoses\nwere supported by positive DFA [direct fluorescent-antibody assay] on\nexcised or aspirated tissues. PCR-based characterization of genetic\nmaterial from the 1st case suggested the strain of _Francisella\ntularensis_ involved was _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_\nbiovar _japonica_.\n\nTherefore, the clinical and microbiological evidence to date points to\nthese zoonotic infections (and possible epizootic) being due to one of\nthe relatively less virulent strains of _F. tularensis_, that is, not\nthe type A or subspecies _tularensis_ strain more often associated\nwith serious sepsis such as pneumonia and septicemia in parts of the\nnorthern hemisphere. The recent Tasmanian cases also appear to be\ndifferent from the case acquired in the NT a decade ago (_F.\nnovicida_).\n\nPublic health actions so far have included information to animal\nhandlers who might work in the area of the 1st case, wider public\nadvice around wild animal contact via the media, and alerts to\nclinicians and laboratories. The extent of the risk-area for this\ninfection within Tasmania is unclear, but based on these recent cases,\nmay be relatively restricted. We will also address the possibility of\nrisk from water, by reiterating existing guidance around protecting\nprivate water supplies from microbial hazards, and rendering raw water\nsafe by boiling it. We are engaging with our Department of Primary\nIndustry, Parks, Wildlife and the Environment around further\ninvestigations. These have begun.\n\nWe would like to pass the following points on to infectious disease\nphysicians, microbiologists, and their colleagues who may not\npreviously have considered the possibility of tularemia acquired in\nthe Southern Hemisphere.\n\nClinical features that raise the possibility of Tasmanian-acquired _F.\ntularensis_ infection include\n- an animal bite or scratch or close exposure to wild animals or their\nenvironment, particularly in the region of the West Coast of Tasmania;\n- persistent local soft tissue infection at the inoculation site and\nregional lymphadenitis, which may suppurate;\n- disease progression, or a poor response, with beta-lactam antibiotic\ntherapy.\n\n_F. tularensis_ is a major laboratory hazard; clinical specimens must\nbe managed by a laboratory with PC3 [physical containment level 3]\nfacilities.\n\n--\nDr Mark Veitch\nTasmanian Department of Health and Human Services\nTasmania, Australia\n<mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\nand\nDr Louise Cooley\nRoyal Hobart Hospital\nTasmania, Australia\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\n\n[ProMED-mail sincerely thanks Dr Veitch and Dr Cooley for supplying\nvital information regarding the clinical circumstances and\nmicrobiological data regarding these 2 separate cases of\nulceroglandular tularemia acquired from possums in Tasmania. The\norganism _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_ biovar _japonica_ is\ndistinct from other _holarctica_ strains that are found in Europe,\nAsia, and the USA (1). These _holarctica_ strains, also referred to as\ntype B tularemia tend to produce significantly milder disease in man\nthan the subspecies _tularensis_.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. USA (UT, NJ) 20070716.2283\nUndiagnosed fatal illness - Iran (Sistan-Baluchestan) (02): tularemia?\n20070423.1329\nTularemia, water-borne - Norway (North) 20070329.1081\n.................................................ll/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:40", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Berlin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taipei", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Tasmania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baden - Wuerttemberg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "941706", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia, human, possum - Australia (02): (TS), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=941706", "date": "2011-04-01 10:21:33", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - NORWAY (02): (CENTRAL)\n**********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Mar 2011\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2011; 16(13) [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19828\n\n\nOutbreak of tularemia in central Norway, January to March 2011\n--------------------------------------------------------------\n>From January to March 2011, 39 cases of tularemia were diagnosed in 3\ncounties in central Norway: 21 cases of oropharyngeal type, 10 cases\nof glandular/ulceroglandular type, 2 of respiratory, and 2 of typhoid\ntype. 3 cases were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case. The mean age was 40.3 years (range 2-89\nyears). 34 reported use of drinking water from private wells. An\nincreased rodent (lemming) population and snow melting may have led to\ncontamination of the wells with infected rodents or rodent excreta.\n\nOutbreak description\n--------------------\n>From 1 Jan to 25 Mar 2011, 39 confirmed cases (16 female and 23 male)\nof tularemia were reported from the counties of Sor-Trondelag (28\ncases), More og Romsdal (5 cases), and Nord-Trondelag (6 cases) in\ncentral Norway. A confirmed case was defined as a person who had\nclinical symptoms compatible with tularemia or had used drinking water\nfrom the same source as a previous case, and in whom _Francisella\ntularensis_ infection was confirmed by a laboratory test as described\nbelow. The cases were geographically scattered within each county,\ninvolving 13 different municipalities, and were not linked to one\ncommon source. In comparison, 7 cases were reported in total from\nother parts of the country in the same period. In 2009 and 2010 4 and\n8 cases respectively were reported from central Norway.\n\nTularemia is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium _F.\ntularensis_. 4 _F. tularensis_ subspecies are recognized:\n_tularensis_, _holarctica_, _mediasiatica_ and _novicida_. In Europe,\nthe infection is due to subspecies _holarctica_, which causes in\ngeneral less severe disease than subspecies _tularensis_, which is\ncommon in North America. Several vectors may be involved in\ntransmitting the disease to humans, commonly rodents and hares, but\ninfection may also be transmitted via insect bites (1).\n\nSeveral clinical forms are recognised, with oropharyngeal and\nulceroglandular disease being the most common clinical presentations\nin Norway (2). Oropharyngeal disease is commonly associated with\ncontaminated food and water, while ulceroglandular forms are more\noften seen when there has been skin contact with infected animals or\nafter insect bites (3).\n\nOutbreaks of oropharyngeal tularemia have previously been reported\nfrom several European countries (3,4). Tularemia is a notifiable\ndisease in Norway and during the past 10 years, 3 outbreaks were\nreported in Norway (5-7) and all were associated with water sources in\nareas where dead lemmings (_Lemmus lemmus_) had been observed\npreviously. From 2001 to 2010, between 3 and 66 cases of tularemia\nwere reported annually in the whole country, with an increase from 16\nto 32 cases on average (data available from http://www.msis.no).\nThis increase may in part be explained by the outbreaks mentioned\nabove.\n\nDiagnosis and clinical presentation\n-----------------------------------\nIn the outbreak described here, the most common clinical presentation\nwas fever and pharyngitis (oropharyngeal type, 21 cases) and cervical\nlymphadenopathy (glandular/ulceroglandular type, 10 cases). Among the\nremaining 8 tularemia cases, 2 were classified as respiratory and 2 as\ntyphoid type, while 3 were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case.\n\nThe diagnosis was primarily established by serology\n(microagglutination and an in-house IgG/IgM Elisa) in 30 patients (8),\nby _F. tularensis_ specific PCR analysis in seven patients (9) and by\nblood culture (BactAlert, BioMerieux) in 2 patients. The 2 bacterial\nisolates were verified as _F. tularensis_ by PCR and sequencing of the\n16S rDNA gene, and confirmed as non-subspecies _tularensis_ by pdpA\nPCR (10).\n\nOf the 39 diagnosed cases, 34 had been drinking water from a private\nwell or a stream. _F. tularensis_ DNA was detected by PCR in filtered\nwater from 5 different wells tested in Sor-Trondelag. 7 cases in 1\nmunicipality were linked to the same water source. Apart from that,\nonly 2 cases have been confirmed to share a common well so far.\nFollow-up serology has been recommended for several of the persons\nexposed to some of the putative water sources.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe current outbreak involves a large number of municipalities in 3\ncounties in central Norway. The clinical presentation with\noropharyngeal tularemia and cervical lymphadenopathy linked to the use\nof private wells in the winter season makes contaminated water the\nmost likely source of infection in this outbreak. Detection of _F.\ntularensis_ DNA by PCR analyses in some of the wells supports this\nassumption for some of the cases. Use of private wells is relatively\ncommon in rural areas of Norway although exact data on such use are\nnot available.\n\nThe precise mechanism of contamination of the wells with _F.\ntularensis_ is as yet unknown. However, November and December 2010\nwere unusually cold months, while in January 2011 temperatures\nincreased leading to melting of snow and possible contamination of\nprivate wells by surface water contaminated with bacteria from rodent\ncadavers or rodent excreta. Since the incubation period for tularemia\nmay be up to 3 weeks, and time from symptoms until seroconversion\nmight be up to 6 weeks, more cases may follow.\n\nTularemia has traditionally been called both 'lemming fever' and\n'hare plague' and this clearly indicates rodents and hares as\ntransmitters of disease. Years with a great increase in the rodent\npopulation are seen with intervals of about 3 to 4 years (11) and in\nthe summer and autumn of 2010, a high density of lemmings could be\nobserved in the southern and central parts of Norway. Simultaneously,\nthe Norwegian Veterinary Institute observed a wide geographical\ndistribution of fatal cases of tularemia in the mountain hare (_Lepus\ntimidus_) in these regions (12). The mountain hare is very susceptible\nto this infection and normally dies from septicemia within a few days\nafter exposure.\n\nThe use of small streams and private wells as a source of drinking\nwater and for other purposes in rural areas of Norway is a matter of\nconcern. In existing guidelines issued by the National Institute of\nPublic Health the population is advised to boil drinking water and\ninspect the wells for dead rodents in case of suspected or confirmed\ncases of waterborne tularemia. Every well owner should make the\nnecessary effort to prevent small rodents from entering the well water\nby carefully covering every opening and plugging every small hole\nwhere the rodents can enter. It is also important to secure the well\nfrom contamination by surface water after snow melting. In case of\nproven or suspected contaminated wells, the water should be\ndisinfected before further use. However, this may not be feasible for\npersons who use drinking water from a stream. The Norwegian Food\nSafety Authority has recently released information to the media and to\nthe general public with similar advice and information in relation to\nthe current outbreak. The local health authority in each municipality\nis responsible for instituting infection control measures including\nadvice to the public and investigations of the putative drinking water\nsources.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. World Health Organization (WHO) Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and\nResponse: WHO guidelines on tularaemia. Geneva: WHO; 2007. Available\nfrom\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/WHO_CDS_EPR_2007_7.pdf.\n2. Brantsaeter AB: Twenty-five years of tularaemia in Norway,\n1978-2002. Abstract number: 10.1111/j.1198-743X.2004.902_o142.x.\nEuropean Society of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases.\n14th European Congress of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious\nDiseases. Prague; 1-4 May 2004. [Available from\nhttp://www.blackwellpublishing.com/eccmid14/abstract.asp?id=13879].\n3. Tarnvik A, Priebe HS, Grunow R: Tularaemia in Europe: an\nepidemiological overview. Scand J Infect Dis. 2004; 36(5): 350-5.\n[Abstract available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15287379].\n4. Willke A, Meric M, Grunow R, et al: An outbreak of oropharyngeal\ntularaemia linked to natural spring water. J Med Microbiol. 2009;\n58(Pt 1): 112-6. [Available from\nhttp://jmm.sgmjournals.org/cgi/content/full/58/1/112].\n5. Rike HF, Vigerust A, Bergh K: Vannbarent utbrudd av tularemia\n(harepest) i Midtre Gauldal. [A waterborne outbreak of tularaemia in\nMidtre-Gauldal]. Norwegian Institute of Public Health. 27 Oct 2003.\nNorwegian. Available from\nhttp://www.fhi.no/eway/default.aspx?pid=233&trg=MainLeft_5669&MainLeft_5669=5544:27208::0:5667:1:::0:0.\n6. Brantsaeter AB, Krogh T, Radtke A, Nygard K: Tularaemia outbreak\nin northern Norway. Euro Surveill. 2007; 12(13): pii=3165. Available\nfrom\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=3165.\n7. Melien P, Holsdal RE. Tularemi i Meldal -- en vanskelig diagnose?\n[Tularaemia in Meldal- a difficult diagnosis?]. Norwegian Institute of\nPublic Health. 18 Mar 2008. Norwegian. Available from\nhttp://www.fhi.no/eway/default.aspx?pid=233&trg=Area_5626&MainArea_5661=5619:0:15,4427:1:0:0:::0:0&MainLeft_5619=5626:68396::1:5625:1:::0:0&Area_5626=5544:68400::1:5628:1:::0:0.\n8. Bevanger L, Maeland JA, Naess AI: Competitive enzyme immunoassay\nfor antibodies to a 43 000-molecular-weight _Francisella tularensis_\nouter membrane protein in the diagnosis of tularemia. J Clin\nMicrobiol. 1989; 27(5): 922-6. [Available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC267455].\n9. Sjostedt A, Erikson U, Berglund L, Tarnvik A: Detection of\n_Francisella tularensis_ in ulcers of patients with tularaemia by PCR.\nJ Clin Microbiol. 1997; 35(5): 1045-8. [Available from\nhttp://jcm.asm.org/cgi/content/abstract/35/5/1045].\n10. Tomaso H, Scholz HC, Neubauer H, et al: Real-time PCR using\nhybridization probes for the rapid and specific identification of\n_Francisella tularensis_ subspecies tularensis. Mol Cell Probes. 2007;\n21(1): 12-6. [Available from\nhttp://www.researchgate.net/publication/7281056_Development_of_a_real-time_PCR_assay_for_detection_and_quantification_of_Francisella_tularensis].\n11. Semb-Johaansson A, Ims RA: Smagnagerne [Rodents]. Semb-Johansson\nA, Frislid R, editors. Oslo; 1990. 121-71. Norwegian.\n12. Norwegian Veterinary Institute: Flere tilfeller av harepest i\nSor-Norge [Several cases of tularaemia in South-Norway]. Norwegian\nVeterinary Institute. 25 Nov 2010. Norwegian. Available from\nhttp://www.vetinst.no/index.php/nor/Nyheter/Flere-tilfeller-av-harepest-i-Soer-Norge.\n\nReported by: Larssen KW 1/, Afset JE 1/2/, Heier BT 3/, Krogh T 4/,\nHandeland K 5/, Vik\u00f8ren T 5/, Bergh 1/,2/\n\n1/ Department of Microbiology, St Olavs Hospital, Trondheim\nUniversity Hospital,Trondheim, Norway\n2/ Department of Laboratory Medicine, Children\u2019s and Women\u2019s\nHealth, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim,\nNorway\n3/ Division of Infectious Disease Control, Norwegian Institute of\nPublic Health, Oslo, Norway\n4/ Division of Environmental Medicine, Norwegian Institute of Public\nHealth, Oslo, Norway\n5/Norwegian Veterinary Institute, Oslo, Norway\n\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Norway can be seen at\nhttp://www.questconnect.org/images/map_of_norway.png and\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0fRO. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Regarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nand an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Tikhenko NI, Efremenko VI, Omarieva E, et al: Outbreak of\ntularemia in the Republic of Dagestan. Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol\nImmunobiol. 2001; (6 Suppl): 68-72 (in Russian, abstract in English\navailable from http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12718181).\n2. Greco D, Allegrini G, Tizzi T, et al: A waterborne tularemia\noutbreak. Eur J Epidemiol. 1987; 3(1): 35-8 (abstract available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3582597).\n3. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al: An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol Immunobiol 1997; (2): 33-7 (in\nRussian, abstract in English available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9245138). - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia - Norway: (central) 20110225.0622\n2007\n----\nTularemia - Spain (03): (northern) 20071108.3626\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02) 20070813.2646\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir 20070811.2615\nTularemia, water-borne - Norway (North) 20070329.1081\n2006\n----\nTularemia - Sweden (Varmland) 20060927.2763\n2005\n----\nTularemia, hare hunters - Germany (Hessen) (02) 20051209.3548\nTularemia, hare hunters - Germany (Hessen) 20051203.3490\nTularemia - Russia (European) (02) 20050905.2621\n.................................................mpp/ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-01-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-04 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1045-08-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South - Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oslo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "- Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tuscany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Erikson U", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Smolensk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Trondheim", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prague", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "938795", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, human, possum - Australia: (TS), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=938795", "date": "2011-04-01 10:21:33", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - NORWAY (02): (CENTRAL)\n**********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Mar 2011\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2011; 16(13) [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19828\n\n\nOutbreak of tularemia in central Norway, January to March 2011\n--------------------------------------------------------------\n>From January to March 2011, 39 cases of tularemia were diagnosed in 3\ncounties in central Norway: 21 cases of oropharyngeal type, 10 cases\nof glandular/ulceroglandular type, 2 of respiratory, and 2 of typhoid\ntype. 3 cases were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case. The mean age was 40.3 years (range 2-89\nyears). 34 reported use of drinking water from private wells. An\nincreased rodent (lemming) population and snow melting may have led to\ncontamination of the wells with infected rodents or rodent excreta.\n\nOutbreak description\n--------------------\n>From 1 Jan to 25 Mar 2011, 39 confirmed cases (16 female and 23 male)\nof tularemia were reported from the counties of Sor-Trondelag (28\ncases), More og Romsdal (5 cases), and Nord-Trondelag (6 cases) in\ncentral Norway. A confirmed case was defined as a person who had\nclinical symptoms compatible with tularemia or had used drinking water\nfrom the same source as a previous case, and in whom _Francisella\ntularensis_ infection was confirmed by a laboratory test as described\nbelow. The cases were geographically scattered within each county,\ninvolving 13 different municipalities, and were not linked to one\ncommon source. In comparison, 7 cases were reported in total from\nother parts of the country in the same period. In 2009 and 2010 4 and\n8 cases respectively were reported from central Norway.\n\nTularemia is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium _F.\ntularensis_. 4 _F. tularensis_ subspecies are recognized:\n_tularensis_, _holarctica_, _mediasiatica_ and _novicida_. In Europe,\nthe infection is due to subspecies _holarctica_, which causes in\ngeneral less severe disease than subspecies _tularensis_, which is\ncommon in North America. Several vectors may be involved in\ntransmitting the disease to humans, commonly rodents and hares, but\ninfection may also be transmitted via insect bites (1).\n\nSeveral clinical forms are recognised, with oropharyngeal and\nulceroglandular disease being the most common clinical presentations\nin Norway (2). Oropharyngeal disease is commonly associated with\ncontaminated food and water, while ulceroglandular forms are more\noften seen when there has been skin contact with infected animals or\nafter insect bites (3).\n\nOutbreaks of oropharyngeal tularemia have previously been reported\nfrom several European countries (3,4). Tularemia is a notifiable\ndisease in Norway and during the past 10 years, 3 outbreaks were\nreported in Norway (5-7) and all were associated with water sources in\nareas where dead lemmings (_Lemmus lemmus_) had been observed\npreviously. From 2001 to 2010, between 3 and 66 cases of tularemia\nwere reported annually in the whole country, with an increase from 16\nto 32 cases on average (data available from http://www.msis.no).\nThis increase may in part be explained by the outbreaks mentioned\nabove.\n\nDiagnosis and clinical presentation\n-----------------------------------\nIn the outbreak described here, the most common clinical presentation\nwas fever and pharyngitis (oropharyngeal type, 21 cases) and cervical\nlymphadenopathy (glandular/ulceroglandular type, 10 cases). Among the\nremaining 8 tularemia cases, 2 were classified as respiratory and 2 as\ntyphoid type, while 3 were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case.\n\nThe diagnosis was primarily established by serology\n(microagglutination and an in-house IgG/IgM Elisa) in 30 patients (8),\nby _F. tularensis_ specific PCR analysis in seven patients (9) and by\nblood culture (BactAlert, BioMerieux) in 2 patients. The 2 bacterial\nisolates were verified as _F. tularensis_ by PCR and sequencing of the\n16S rDNA gene, and confirmed as non-subspecies _tularensis_ by pdpA\nPCR (10).\n\nOf the 39 diagnosed cases, 34 had been drinking water from a private\nwell or a stream. _F. tularensis_ DNA was detected by PCR in filtered\nwater from 5 different wells tested in Sor-Trondelag. 7 cases in 1\nmunicipality were linked to the same water source. Apart from that,\nonly 2 cases have been confirmed to share a common well so far.\nFollow-up serology has been recommended for several of the persons\nexposed to some of the putative water sources.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe current outbreak involves a large number of municipalities in 3\ncounties in central Norway. The clinical presentation with\noropharyngeal tularemia and cervical lymphadenopathy linked to the use\nof private wells in the winter season makes contaminated water the\nmost likely source of infection in this outbreak. Detection of _F.\ntularensis_ DNA by PCR analyses in some of the wells supports this\nassumption for some of the cases. Use of private wells is relatively\ncommon in rural areas of Norway although exact data on such use are\nnot available.\n\nThe precise mechanism of contamination of the wells with _F.\ntularensis_ is as yet unknown. However, November and December 2010\nwere unusually cold months, while in January 2011 temperatures\nincreased leading to melting of snow and possible contamination of\nprivate wells by surface water contaminated with bacteria from rodent\ncadavers or rodent excreta. Since the incubation period for tularemia\nmay be up to 3 weeks, and time from symptoms until seroconversion\nmight be up to 6 weeks, more cases may follow.\n\nTularemia has traditionally been called both 'lemming fever' and\n'hare plague' and this clearly indicates rodents and hares as\ntransmitters of disease. Years with a great increase in the rodent\npopulation are seen with intervals of about 3 to 4 years (11) and in\nthe summer and autumn of 2010, a high density of lemmings could be\nobserved in the southern and central parts of Norway. Simultaneously,\nthe Norwegian Veterinary Institute observed a wide geographical\ndistribution of fatal cases of tularemia in the mountain hare (_Lepus\ntimidus_) in these regions (12). The mountain hare is very susceptible\nto this infection and normally dies from septicemia within a few days\nafter exposure.\n\nThe use of small streams and private wells as a source of drinking\nwater and for other purposes in rural areas of Norway is a matter of\nconcern. In existing guidelines issued by the National Institute of\nPublic Health the population is advised to boil drinking water and\ninspect the wells for dead rodents in case of suspected or confirmed\ncases of waterborne tularemia. Every well owner should make the\nnecessary effort to prevent small rodents from entering the well water\nby carefully covering every opening and plugging every small hole\nwhere the rodents can enter. It is also important to secure the well\nfrom contamination by surface water after snow melting. In case of\nproven or suspected contaminated wells, the water should be\ndisinfected before further use. However, this may not be feasible for\npersons who use drinking water from a stream. The Norwegian Food\nSafety Authority has recently released information to the media and to\nthe general public with similar advice and information in relation to\nthe current outbreak. The local health authority in each municipality\nis responsible for instituting infection control measures including\nadvice to the public and investigations of the putative drinking water\nsources.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. World Health Organization (WHO) Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and\nResponse: WHO guidelines on tularaemia. Geneva: WHO; 2007. Available\nfrom\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/WHO_CDS_EPR_2007_7.pdf.\n2. Brantsaeter AB: Twenty-five years of tularaemia in Norway,\n1978-2002. Abstract number: 10.1111/j.1198-743X.2004.902_o142.x.\nEuropean Society of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases.\n14th European Congress of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious\nDiseases. Prague; 1-4 May 2004. [Available from\nhttp://www.blackwellpublishing.com/eccmid14/abstract.asp?id=13879].\n3. Tarnvik A, Priebe HS, Grunow R: Tularaemia in Europe: an\nepidemiological overview. Scand J Infect Dis. 2004; 36(5): 350-5.\n[Abstract available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15287379].\n4. Willke A, Meric M, Grunow R, et al: An outbreak of oropharyngeal\ntularaemia linked to natural spring water. J Med Microbiol. 2009;\n58(Pt 1): 112-6. [Available from\nhttp://jmm.sgmjournals.org/cgi/content/full/58/1/112].\n5. Rike HF, Vigerust A, Bergh K: Vannbarent utbrudd av tularemia\n(harepest) i Midtre Gauldal. [A waterborne outbreak of tularaemia in\nMidtre-Gauldal]. Norwegian Institute of Public Health. 27 Oct 2003.\nNorwegian. Available\nfrom\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=3165.\n7. Melien P, Holsdal RE. Tularemi i Meldal -- en vanskelig diagnose?\n[Tularaemia in Meldal- a difficult diagnosis?]. Norwegian Institute of\nPublic Health. 18 Mar 2008. Norwegian. Available from\nhttp://www.fhi.no/eway/default.aspx?pid=233&trg=Area_5626&MainArea_5661=5619:0:15,4427:1:0:0:::0:0&MainLeft_5619=5626:68396::1:5625:1:::0:0&Area_5626=5544:68400::1:5628:1:::0:0.\n8. Bevanger L, Maeland JA, Naess AI: Competitive enzyme immunoassay\nfor antibodies to a 43 000-molecular-weight _Francisella tularensis_\nouter membrane protein in the diagnosis of tularemia. J Clin\nMicrobiol. 1989; 27(5): 922-6. [Available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC267455].\n9. Sjostedt A, Erikson U, Berglund L, Tarnvik A: Detection of\n_Francisella tularensis_ in ulcers of patients with tularaemia by PCR.\nJ Clin Microbiol. 1997; 35(5): 1045-8. [Available from\nhttp://jcm.asm.org/cgi/content/abstract/35/5/1045].\n10. Tomaso H, Scholz HC, Neubauer H, et al: Real-time PCR using\nhybridization probes for the rapid and specific identification of\n_Francisella tularensis_ subspecies tularensis. Mol Cell Probes. 2007;\n21(1): 12-6. [Available from\nhttp://www.researchgate.net/publication/7281056_Development_of_a_real-time_PCR_assay_for_detection_and_quantification_of_Francisella_tularensis].\n11. Available from\nhttp://www.vetinst.no/index.php/nor/Nyheter/Flere-tilfeller-av-harepest-i-Soer-Norge.\n\nReported by: Larssen KW 1/, Afset JE 1/2/, Heier BT 3/, Krogh T 4/,\nHandeland K 5/, Vik\u00f8ren T 5/, Bergh 1/,2/\n\n1/ Department of Microbiology, St Olavs Hospital, Trondheim\nUniversity Hospital,Trondheim, Norway\n2/ Department of Laboratory Medicine, Children\u2019s and Women\u2019s\nHealth, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim,\nNorway\n3/ Division of Infectious Disease Control, Norwegian Institute of\nPublic Health, Oslo, Norway\n4/ Division of Environmental Medicine, Norwegian Institute of Public\nHealth, Oslo, Norway\n5/Norwegian Veterinary Institute, Oslo, Norway\n\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Norway can be seen at\nhttp://www.questconnect.org/images/map_of_norway.png and\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0fRO. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Regarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nand an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Spain (03): (northern) 20071108.3626\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02) 20070813.2646\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir 20070811.2615\nTularemia, water-borne - Norway (North) 20070329.1081\n2006\n----\nTularemia - Sweden (Varmland) 20060927.2763\n2005\n----\nTularemia, hare hunters - Germany (Hessen) (02) 20051209.3548\nTularemia, hare hunters - Germany (Hessen) 20051203.3490\nTularemia - Russia (European) (02) 20050905.2621\n.................................................mpp/ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-01-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-04 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1045-08-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South - Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oslo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "- Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tuscany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Erikson U", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Smolensk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Trondheim", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prague", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "905396", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA: (DE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=905396", "date": "2011-04-01 10:21:33", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - NORWAY (02): (CENTRAL)\n**********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Mar 2011\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2011; 16(13) [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19828\n\n\nOutbreak of tularemia in central Norway, January to March 2011\n--------------------------------------------------------------\n>From January to March 2011, 39 cases of tularemia were diagnosed in 3\ncounties in central Norway: 21 cases of oropharyngeal type, 10 cases\nof glandular/ulceroglandular type, 2 of respiratory, and 2 of typhoid\ntype. 3 cases were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case. The mean age was 40.3 years (range 2-89\nyears). 34 reported use of drinking water from private wells. An\nincreased rodent (lemming) population and snow melting may have led to\ncontamination of the wells with infected rodents or rodent excreta.\n\nOutbreak description\n--------------------\n>From 1 Jan to 25 Mar 2011, 39 confirmed cases (16 female and 23 male)\nof tularemia were reported from the counties of Sor-Trondelag (28\ncases), More og Romsdal (5 cases), and Nord-Trondelag (6 cases) in\ncentral Norway. A confirmed case was defined as a person who had\nclinical symptoms compatible with tularemia or had used drinking water\nfrom the same source as a previous case, and in whom _Francisella\ntularensis_ infection was confirmed by a laboratory test as described\nbelow. The cases were geographically scattered within each county,\ninvolving 13 different municipalities, and were not linked to one\ncommon source. In comparison, 7 cases were reported in total from\nother parts of the country in the same period. In 2009 and 2010 4 and\n8 cases respectively were reported from central Norway.\n\nTularemia is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium _F.\ntularensis_. 4 _F. tularensis_ subspecies are recognized:\n_tularensis_, _holarctica_, _mediasiatica_ and _novicida_. In Europe,\nthe infection is due to subspecies _holarctica_, which causes in\ngeneral less severe disease than subspecies _tularensis_, which is\ncommon in North America. Several vectors may be involved in\ntransmitting the disease to humans, commonly rodents and hares, but\ninfection may also be transmitted via insect bites (1).\n\nSeveral clinical forms are recognised, with oropharyngeal and\nulceroglandular disease being the most common clinical presentations\nin Norway (2). Oropharyngeal disease is commonly associated with\ncontaminated food and water, while ulceroglandular forms are more\noften seen when there has been skin contact with infected animals or\nafter insect bites (3).\n\nOutbreaks of oropharyngeal tularemia have previously been reported\nfrom several European countries (3,4). Tularemia is a notifiable\ndisease in Norway and during the past 10 years, 3 outbreaks were\nreported in Norway (5-7) and all were associated with water sources in\nareas where dead lemmings (_Lemmus lemmus_) had been observed\npreviously. From 2001 to 2010, between 3 and 66 cases of tularemia\nwere reported annually in the whole country, with an increase from 16\nto 32 cases on average (data available from http://www.msis.no).\nThis increase may in part be explained by the outbreaks mentioned\nabove.\n\nDiagnosis and clinical presentation\n-----------------------------------\nIn the outbreak described here, the most common clinical presentation\nwas fever and pharyngitis (oropharyngeal type, 21 cases) and cervical\nlymphadenopathy (glandular/ulceroglandular type, 10 cases). Among the\nremaining 8 tularemia cases, 2 were classified as respiratory and 2 as\ntyphoid type, while 3 were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case.\n\nThe diagnosis was primarily established by serology\n(microagglutination and an in-house IgG/IgM Elisa) in 30 patients (8),\nby _F. tularensis_ specific PCR analysis in seven patients (9) and by\nblood culture (BactAlert, BioMerieux) in 2 patients. The 2 bacterial\nisolates were verified as _F. tularensis_ by PCR and sequencing of the\n16S rDNA gene, and confirmed as non-subspecies _tularensis_ by pdpA\nPCR (10).\n\nOf the 39 diagnosed cases, 34 had been drinking water from a private\nwell or a stream. _F. tularensis_ DNA was detected by PCR in filtered\nwater from 5 different wells tested in Sor-Trondelag. 7 cases in 1\nmunicipality were linked to the same water source. Apart from that,\nonly 2 cases have been confirmed to share a common well so far.\nFollow-up serology has been recommended for several of the persons\nexposed to some of the putative water sources.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe current outbreak involves a large number of municipalities in 3\ncounties in central Norway. The clinical presentation with\noropharyngeal tularemia and cervical lymphadenopathy linked to the use\nof private wells in the winter season makes contaminated water the\nmost likely source of infection in this outbreak. Detection of _F.\ntularensis_ DNA by PCR analyses in some of the wells supports this\nassumption for some of the cases. Use of private wells is relatively\ncommon in rural areas of Norway although exact data on such use are\nnot available.\n\nThe precise mechanism of contamination of the wells with _F.\ntularensis_ is as yet unknown. However, November and December 2010\nwere unusually cold months, while in January 2011 temperatures\nincreased leading to melting of snow and possible contamination of\nprivate wells by surface water contaminated with bacteria from rodent\ncadavers or rodent excreta. Since the incubation period for tularemia\nmay be up to 3 weeks, and time from symptoms until seroconversion\nmight be up to 6 weeks, more cases may follow.\n\nTularemia has traditionally been called both 'lemming fever' and\n'hare plague' and this clearly indicates rodents and hares as\ntransmitters of disease. Years with a great increase in the rodent\npopulation are seen with intervals of about 3 to 4 years (11) and in\nthe summer and autumn of 2010, a high density of lemmings could be\nobserved in the southern and central parts of Norway. Simultaneously,\nthe Norwegian Veterinary Institute observed a wide geographical\ndistribution of fatal cases of tularemia in the mountain hare (_Lepus\ntimidus_) in these regions (12). The mountain hare is very susceptible\nto this infection and normally dies from septicemia within a few days\nafter exposure.\n\nThe use of small streams and private wells as a source of drinking\nwater and for other purposes in rural areas of Norway is a matter of\nconcern. In existing guidelines issued by the National Institute of\nPublic Health the population is advised to boil drinking water and\ninspect the wells for dead rodents in case of suspected or confirmed\ncases of waterborne tularemia. Every well owner should make the\nnecessary effort to prevent small rodents from entering the well water\nby carefully covering every opening and plugging every small hole\nwhere the rodents can enter. It is also important to secure the well\nfrom contamination by surface water after snow melting. In case of\nproven or suspected contaminated wells, the water should be\ndisinfected before further use. However, this may not be feasible for\npersons who use drinking water from a stream. The Norwegian Food\nSafety Authority has recently released information to the media and to\nthe general public with similar advice and information in relation to\nthe current outbreak. The local health authority in each municipality\nis responsible for instituting infection control measures including\nadvice to the public and investigations of the putative drinking water\nsources.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Available from\nhttp://www.vetinst.no/index.php/nor/Nyheter/Flere-tilfeller-av-harepest-i-Soer-Norge.\n\nReported by: Larssen KW 1/, Afset JE 1/2/, Heier BT 3/, Krogh T 4/,\nHandeland K 5/, Vik\u00f8ren T 5/, Bergh 1/,2/\n\n1/ Department of Microbiology, St Olavs Hospital, Trondheim\nUniversity Hospital,Trondheim, Norway\n2/ Department of Laboratory Medicine, Children\u2019s and Women\u2019s\nHealth, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim,\nNorway\n3/ Division of Infectious Disease Control, Norwegian Institute of\nPublic Health, Oslo, Norway\n4/ Division of Environmental Medicine, Norwegian Institute of Public\nHealth, Oslo, Norway\n5/Norwegian Veterinary Institute, Oslo, Norway\n\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Norway can be seen at\nhttp://www.questconnect.org/images/map_of_norway.png and\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0fRO. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Regarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nand an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1.
