Greco D, Allegrini G, Tizzi T, et al: A waterborne tularemia\noutbreak. Eur J Epidemiol. 1987; 3(1): 35-8 (abstract available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3582597).\n3. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al: An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol Immunobiol 1997; (2): 33-7 (in\nRussian, abstract in English available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9245138). - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia - Norway: (central) 20110225.0622\n2007\n----\nTularemia - Spain (03): (northern) 20071108.3626\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02) 20070813.2646\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir 20070811.2615\nTularemia, water-borne - Norway (North) 20070329.1081\n2006\n----\nTularemia - Sweden (Varmland) 20060927.2763\n2005\n----\nTularemia, hare hunters - Germany (Hessen) (02) 20051209.3548\nTularemia, hare hunters - Germany (Hessen) 20051203.3490\nTularemia - Russia (European) (02) 20050905.2621\n.................................................mpp/ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-01-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-04 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1045-08-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South - Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oslo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "- Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tuscany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Erikson U", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Smolensk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Trondheim", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prague", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "873932", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, feline - USA: (IL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=873932", "date": "2011-04-01 10:21:33", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - NORWAY (02): (CENTRAL)\n**********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Mar 2011\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2011; 16(13) [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19828\n\n\nOutbreak of tularemia in central Norway, January to March 2011\n--------------------------------------------------------------\n>From January to March 2011, 39 cases of tularemia were diagnosed in 3\ncounties in central Norway: 21 cases of oropharyngeal type, 10 cases\nof glandular/ulceroglandular type, 2 of respiratory, and 2 of typhoid\ntype. 3 cases were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case. The mean age was 40.3 years (range 2-89\nyears). 34 reported use of drinking water from private wells. An\nincreased rodent (lemming) population and snow melting may have led to\ncontamination of the wells with infected rodents or rodent excreta.\n\nOutbreak description\n--------------------\n>From 1 Jan to 25 Mar 2011, 39 confirmed cases (16 female and 23 male)\nof tularemia were reported from the counties of Sor-Trondelag (28\ncases), More og Romsdal (5 cases), and Nord-Trondelag (6 cases) in\ncentral Norway. A confirmed case was defined as a person who had\nclinical symptoms compatible with tularemia or had used drinking water\nfrom the same source as a previous case, and in whom _Francisella\ntularensis_ infection was confirmed by a laboratory test as described\nbelow. The cases were geographically scattered within each county,\ninvolving 13 different municipalities, and were not linked to one\ncommon source. In comparison, 7 cases were reported in total from\nother parts of the country in the same period. In 2009 and 2010 4 and\n8 cases respectively were reported from central Norway.\n\nTularemia is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium _F.\ntularensis_. 4 _F. tularensis_ subspecies are recognized:\n_tularensis_, _holarctica_, _mediasiatica_ and _novicida_. In Europe,\nthe infection is due to subspecies _holarctica_, which causes in\ngeneral less severe disease than subspecies _tularensis_, which is\ncommon in North America. Several vectors may be involved in\ntransmitting the disease to humans, commonly rodents and hares, but\ninfection may also be transmitted via insect bites (1).\n\nSeveral clinical forms are recognised, with oropharyngeal and\nulceroglandular disease being the most common clinical presentations\nin Norway (2). Oropharyngeal disease is commonly associated with\ncontaminated food and water, while ulceroglandular forms are more\noften seen when there has been skin contact with infected animals or\nafter insect bites (3).\n\nOutbreaks of oropharyngeal tularemia have previously been reported\nfrom several European countries (3,4). Tularemia is a notifiable\ndisease in Norway and during the past 10 years, 3 outbreaks were\nreported in Norway (5-7) and all were associated with water sources in\nareas where dead lemmings (_Lemmus lemmus_) had been observed\npreviously. From 2001 to 2010, between 3 and 66 cases of tularemia\nwere reported annually in the whole country, with an increase from 16\nto 32 cases on average (data available from http://www.msis.no).\nThis increase may in part be explained by the outbreaks mentioned\nabove.\n\nDiagnosis and clinical presentation\n-----------------------------------\nIn the outbreak described here, the most common clinical presentation\nwas fever and pharyngitis (oropharyngeal type, 21 cases) and cervical\nlymphadenopathy (glandular/ulceroglandular type, 10 cases). Among the\nremaining 8 tularemia cases, 2 were classified as respiratory and 2 as\ntyphoid type, while 3 were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case.\n\nThe diagnosis was primarily established by serology\n(microagglutination and an in-house IgG/IgM Elisa) in 30 patients (8),\nby _F. tularensis_ specific PCR analysis in seven patients (9) and by\nblood culture (BactAlert, BioMerieux) in 2 patients. The 2 bacterial\nisolates were verified as _F. tularensis_ by PCR and sequencing of the\n16S rDNA gene, and confirmed as non-subspecies _tularensis_ by pdpA\nPCR (10).\n\nOf the 39 diagnosed cases, 34 had been drinking water from a private\nwell or a stream. _F. tularensis_ DNA was detected by PCR in filtered\nwater from 5 different wells tested in Sor-Trondelag. 7 cases in 1\nmunicipality were linked to the same water source. Apart from that,\nonly 2 cases have been confirmed to share a common well so far.\nFollow-up serology has been recommended for several of the persons\nexposed to some of the putative water sources.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe current outbreak involves a large number of municipalities in 3\ncounties in central Norway. The clinical presentation with\noropharyngeal tularemia and cervical lymphadenopathy linked to the use\nof private wells in the winter season makes contaminated water the\nmost likely source of infection in this outbreak. Detection of _F.\ntularensis_ DNA by PCR analyses in some of the wells supports this\nassumption for some of the cases. Use of private wells is relatively\ncommon in rural areas of Norway although exact data on such use are\nnot available.\n\nThe precise mechanism of contamination of the wells with _F.\ntularensis_ is as yet unknown. However, November and December 2010\nwere unusually cold months, while in January 2011 temperatures\nincreased leading to melting of snow and possible contamination of\nprivate wells by surface water contaminated with bacteria from rodent\ncadavers or rodent excreta. Since the incubation period for tularemia\nmay be up to 3 weeks, and time from symptoms until seroconversion\nmight be up to 6 weeks, more cases may follow.\n\nTularemia has traditionally been called both 'lemming fever' and\n'hare plague' and this clearly indicates rodents and hares as\ntransmitters of disease. Years with a great increase in the rodent\npopulation are seen with intervals of about 3 to 4 years (11) and in\nthe summer and autumn of 2010, a high density of lemmings could be\nobserved in the southern and central parts of Norway. Simultaneously,\nthe Norwegian Veterinary Institute observed a wide geographical\ndistribution of fatal cases of tularemia in the mountain hare (_Lepus\ntimidus_) in these regions (12). The mountain hare is very susceptible\nto this infection and normally dies from septicemia within a few days\nafter exposure.\n\nThe use of small streams and private wells as a source of drinking\nwater and for other purposes in rural areas of Norway is a matter of\nconcern. In existing guidelines issued by the National Institute of\nPublic Health the population is advised to boil drinking water and\ninspect the wells for dead rodents in case of suspected or confirmed\ncases of waterborne tularemia. Every well owner should make the\nnecessary effort to prevent small rodents from entering the well water\nby carefully covering every opening and plugging every small hole\nwhere the rodents can enter. It is also important to secure the well\nfrom contamination by surface water after snow melting. In case of\nproven or suspected contaminated wells, the water should be\ndisinfected before further use. However, this may not be feasible for\npersons who use drinking water from a stream. The Norwegian Food\nSafety Authority has recently released information to the media and to\nthe general public with similar advice and information in relation to\nthe current outbreak. The local health authority in each municipality\nis responsible for instituting infection control measures including\nadvice to the public and investigations of the putative drinking water\nsources.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. World Health Organization (WHO) Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and\nResponse: WHO guidelines on tularaemia. Geneva: WHO; 2007. Available\nfrom\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/WHO_CDS_EPR_2007_7.pdf.\n2. Brantsaeter AB: Twenty-five years of tularaemia in Norway,\n1978-2002. Abstract number: 10.1111/j.1198-743X.2004.902_o142.x.\nEuropean Society of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases.\n14th European Congress of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious\nDiseases. Prague; 1-4 May 2004. [Available from\nhttp://www.blackwellpublishing.com/eccmid14/abstract.asp?id=13879].\n3. Tarnvik A, Priebe HS, Grunow R: Tularaemia in Europe: an\nepidemiological overview. Scand J Infect Dis. 2004; 36(5): 350-5.\n[Abstract available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15287379].\n4. [Available from\nhttp://jmm.sgmjournals.org/cgi/content/full/58/1/112].\n5. Rike HF, Vigerust A, Bergh K: Vannbarent utbrudd av tularemia\n(harepest) i Midtre Gauldal. [Available from\nhttp://jcm.asm.org/cgi/content/abstract/35/5/1045].\n10. Sweden (Varmland) 20060927.2763\n2005\n----\nTularemia, hare hunters - Germany (Hessen) (02) 20051209.3548\nTularemia, hare hunters - Germany (Hessen) 20051203.3490\nTularemia - Russia (European) (02) 20050905.2621\n.................................................mpp/ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-01-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-04 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1045-08-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - Taiwan: (Taipei) ex USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=817486", "date": "2011-04-01 10:21:33", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - NORWAY (02): (CENTRAL)\n**********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Mar 2011\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2011; 16(13) [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19828\n\n\nOutbreak of tularemia in central Norway, January to March 2011\n--------------------------------------------------------------\n>From January to March 2011, 39 cases of tularemia were diagnosed in 3\ncounties in central Norway: 21 cases of oropharyngeal type, 10 cases\nof glandular/ulceroglandular type, 2 of respiratory, and 2 of typhoid\ntype. 3 cases were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case. The mean age was 40.3 years (range 2-89\nyears). 34 reported use of drinking water from private wells. An\nincreased rodent (lemming) population and snow melting may have led to\ncontamination of the wells with infected rodents or rodent excreta.\n\nOutbreak description\n--------------------\n>From 1 Jan to 25 Mar 2011, 39 confirmed cases (16 female and 23 male)\nof tularemia were reported from the counties of Sor-Trondelag (28\ncases), More og Romsdal (5 cases), and Nord-Trondelag (6 cases) in\ncentral Norway. A confirmed case was defined as a person who had\nclinical symptoms compatible with tularemia or had used drinking water\nfrom the same source as a previous case, and in whom _Francisella\ntularensis_ infection was confirmed by a laboratory test as described\nbelow. The cases were geographically scattered within each county,\ninvolving 13 different municipalities, and were not linked to one\ncommon source. In comparison, 7 cases were reported in total from\nother parts of the country in the same period. In 2009 and 2010 4 and\n8 cases respectively were reported from central Norway.\n\nTularemia is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium _F.\ntularensis_. 4 _F. tularensis_ subspecies are recognized:\n_tularensis_, _holarctica_, _mediasiatica_ and _novicida_. In Europe,\nthe infection is due to subspecies _holarctica_, which causes in\ngeneral less severe disease than subspecies _tularensis_, which is\ncommon in North America. Several vectors may be involved in\ntransmitting the disease to humans, commonly rodents and hares, but\ninfection may also be transmitted via insect bites (1).\n\nSeveral clinical forms are recognised, with oropharyngeal and\nulceroglandular disease being the most common clinical presentations\nin Norway (2). Oropharyngeal disease is commonly associated with\ncontaminated food and water, while ulceroglandular forms are more\noften seen when there has been skin contact with infected animals or\nafter insect bites (3).\n\nOutbreaks of oropharyngeal tularemia have previously been reported\nfrom several European countries (3,4). Tularemia is a notifiable\ndisease in Norway and during the past 10 years, 3 outbreaks were\nreported in Norway (5-7) and all were associated with water sources in\nareas where dead lemmings (_Lemmus lemmus_) had been observed\npreviously. From 2001 to 2010, between 3 and 66 cases of tularemia\nwere reported annually in the whole country, with an increase from 16\nto 32 cases on average (data available from http://www.msis.no).\nThis increase may in part be explained by the outbreaks mentioned\nabove.\n\nDiagnosis and clinical presentation\n-----------------------------------\nIn the outbreak described here, the most common clinical presentation\nwas fever and pharyngitis (oropharyngeal type, 21 cases) and cervical\nlymphadenopathy (glandular/ulceroglandular type, 10 cases). Among the\nremaining 8 tularemia cases, 2 were classified as respiratory and 2 as\ntyphoid type, while 3 were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case.\n\nThe diagnosis was primarily established by serology\n(microagglutination and an in-house IgG/IgM Elisa) in 30 patients (8),\nby _F. tularensis_ specific PCR analysis in seven patients (9) and by\nblood culture (BactAlert, BioMerieux) in 2 patients. The 2 bacterial\nisolates were verified as _F. tularensis_ by PCR and sequencing of the\n16S rDNA gene, and confirmed as non-subspecies _tularensis_ by pdpA\nPCR (10).\n\nOf the 39 diagnosed cases, 34 had been drinking water from a private\nwell or a stream. _F. tularensis_ DNA was detected by PCR in filtered\nwater from 5 different wells tested in Sor-Trondelag. 7 cases in 1\nmunicipality were linked to the same water source. Apart from that,\nonly 2 cases have been confirmed to share a common well so far.\nFollow-up serology has been recommended for several of the persons\nexposed to some of the putative water sources.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe current outbreak involves a large number of municipalities in 3\ncounties in central Norway. The clinical presentation with\noropharyngeal tularemia and cervical lymphadenopathy linked to the use\nof private wells in the winter season makes contaminated water the\nmost likely source of infection in this outbreak. Detection of _F.\ntularensis_ DNA by PCR analyses in some of the wells supports this\nassumption for some of the cases. Use of private wells is relatively\ncommon in rural areas of Norway although exact data on such use are\nnot available.\n\nThe precise mechanism of contamination of the wells with _F.\ntularensis_ is as yet unknown. However, November and December 2010\nwere unusually cold months, while in January 2011 temperatures\nincreased leading to melting of snow and possible contamination of\nprivate wells by surface water contaminated with bacteria from rodent\ncadavers or rodent excreta. Since the incubation period for tularemia\nmay be up to 3 weeks, and time from symptoms until seroconversion\nmight be up to 6 weeks, more cases may follow.\n\nTularemia has traditionally been called both 'lemming fever' and\n'hare plague' and this clearly indicates rodents and hares as\ntransmitters of disease. Years with a great increase in the rodent\npopulation are seen with intervals of about 3 to 4 years (11) and in\nthe summer and autumn of 2010, a high density of lemmings could be\nobserved in the southern and central parts of Norway. Simultaneously,\nthe Norwegian Veterinary Institute observed a wide geographical\ndistribution of fatal cases of tularemia in the mountain hare (_Lepus\ntimidus_) in these regions (12). The mountain hare is very susceptible\nto this infection and normally dies from septicemia within a few days\nafter exposure.\n\nThe use of small streams and private wells as a source of drinking\nwater and for other purposes in rural areas of Norway is a matter of\nconcern. In existing guidelines issued by the National Institute of\nPublic Health the population is advised to boil drinking water and\ninspect the wells for dead rodents in case of suspected or confirmed\ncases of waterborne tularemia. Every well owner should make the\nnecessary effort to prevent small rodents from entering the well water\nby carefully covering every opening and plugging every small hole\nwhere the rodents can enter. It is also important to secure the well\nfrom contamination by surface water after snow melting. In case of\nproven or suspected contaminated wells, the water should be\ndisinfected before further use. However, this may not be feasible for\npersons who use drinking water from a stream. The Norwegian Food\nSafety Authority has recently released information to the media and to\nthe general public with similar advice and information in relation to\nthe current outbreak. The local health authority in each municipality\nis responsible for instituting infection control measures including\nadvice to the public and investigations of the putative drinking water\nsources.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. World Health Organization (WHO) Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and\nResponse: WHO guidelines on tularaemia. Geneva: WHO; 2007. Available\nfrom\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/WHO_CDS_EPR_2007_7.pdf.\n2. Brantsaeter AB: Twenty-five years of tularaemia in Norway,\n1978-2002. Abstract number: 10.1111/j.1198-743X.2004.902_o142.x.\nEuropean Society of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases.\n14th European Congress of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious\nDiseases. Prague; 1-4 May 2004. [Available from\nhttp://www.blackwellpublishing.com/eccmid14/abstract.asp?id=13879].\n3. Tarnvik A, Priebe HS, Grunow R: Tularaemia in Europe: an\nepidemiological overview. Scand J Infect Dis. 2004; 36(5): 350-5.\n[Abstract available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15287379].\n4. Willke A, Meric M, Grunow R, et al: An outbreak of oropharyngeal\ntularaemia linked to natural spring water. J Med Microbiol. 2009;\n58(Pt 1): 112-6. [Available from\nhttp://jmm.sgmjournals.org/cgi/content/full/58/1/112].\n5. Rike HF, Vigerust A, Bergh K: Vannbarent utbrudd av tularemia\n(harepest) i Midtre Gauldal. [A waterborne outbreak of tularaemia in\nMidtre-Gauldal]. Norwegian Institute of Public Health. 27 Oct 2003.\nNorwegian. Available\nfrom\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=3165.\n7. Melien P, Holsdal RE. Tularemi i Meldal -- en vanskelig diagnose?\n[Tularaemia in Meldal- a difficult diagnosis?]. Norwegian Institute of\nPublic Health. 18 Mar 2008. Norwegian. Available from\nhttp://www.fhi.no/eway/default.aspx?pid=233&trg=Area_5626&MainArea_5661=5619:0:15,4427:1:0:0:::0:0&MainLeft_5619=5626:68396::1:5625:1:::0:0&Area_5626=5544:68400::1:5628:1:::0:0.\n8. Bevanger L, Maeland JA, Naess AI: Competitive enzyme immunoassay\nfor antibodies to a 43 000-molecular-weight _Francisella tularensis_\nouter membrane protein in the diagnosis of tularemia. J Clin\nMicrobiol. 1989; 27(5): 922-6. [Available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC267455].\n9. [Available from\nhttp://jcm.asm.org/cgi/content/abstract/35/5/1045].\n10. Tomaso H, Scholz HC, Neubauer H, et al: Real-time PCR using\nhybridization probes for the rapid and specific identification of\n_Francisella tularensis_ subspecies tularensis. Mol Cell Probes. 2007;\n21(1): 12-6. [Available from\nhttp://www.researchgate.net/publication/7281056_Development_of_a_real-time_PCR_assay_for_detection_and_quantification_of_Francisella_tularensis].\n11. Available from\nhttp://www.vetinst.no/index.php/nor/Nyheter/Flere-tilfeller-av-harepest-i-Soer-Norge.\n\nReported by: Larssen KW 1/, Afset JE 1/2/, Heier BT 3/, Krogh T 4/,\nHandeland K 5/, Vik\u00f8ren T 5/, Bergh 1/,2/\n\n1/ Department of Microbiology, St Olavs Hospital, Trondheim\nUniversity Hospital,Trondheim, Norway\n2/ Department of Laboratory Medicine, Children\u2019s and Women\u2019s\nHealth, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim,\nNorway\n3/ Division of Infectious Disease Control, Norwegian Institute of\nPublic Health, Oslo, Norway\n4/ Division of Environmental Medicine, Norwegian Institute of Public\nHealth, Oslo, Norway\n5/Norwegian Veterinary Institute, Oslo, Norway\n\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Norway can be seen at\nhttp://www.questconnect.org/images/map_of_norway.png and\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0fRO. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Regarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nand an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Tikhenko NI, Efremenko VI, Omarieva E, et al: Outbreak of\ntularemia in the Republic of Dagestan. Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol\nImmunobiol. 2001; (6 Suppl): 68-72 (in Russian, abstract in English\navailable from http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12718181).\n2. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al: An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol Immunobiol 1997; (2): 33-7 (in\nRussian, abstract in English available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9245138). - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia - Norway: (central) 20110225.0622\n2007\n----\nTularemia - Spain (03): (northern) 20071108.3626\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02) 20070813.2646\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir 20070811.2615\nTularemia, water-borne - Norway (North) 20070329.1081\n2006\n----\nTularemia - Sweden (Varmland) 20060927.2763\n2005\n----\nTularemia, hare hunters - Germany (Hessen) (02) 20051209.3548\nTularemia, hare hunters - Germany (Hessen) 20051203.3490\nTularemia - Russia (European) (02) 20050905.2621\n.................................................mpp/ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-01-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-04 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1045-08-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - France: (PC) hare", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=788199", "date": "2011-04-01 10:21:33", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - NORWAY (02): (CENTRAL)\n**********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Mar 2011\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2011; 16(13) [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19828\n\n\nOutbreak of tularemia in central Norway, January to March 2011\n--------------------------------------------------------------\n>From January to March 2011, 39 cases of tularemia were diagnosed in 3\ncounties in central Norway: 21 cases of oropharyngeal type, 10 cases\nof glandular/ulceroglandular type, 2 of respiratory, and 2 of typhoid\ntype. 3 cases were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case. The mean age was 40.3 years (range 2-89\nyears). 34 reported use of drinking water from private wells. An\nincreased rodent (lemming) population and snow melting may have led to\ncontamination of the wells with infected rodents or rodent excreta.\n\nOutbreak description\n--------------------\n>From 1 Jan to 25 Mar 2011, 39 confirmed cases (16 female and 23 male)\nof tularemia were reported from the counties of Sor-Trondelag (28\ncases), More og Romsdal (5 cases), and Nord-Trondelag (6 cases) in\ncentral Norway. A confirmed case was defined as a person who had\nclinical symptoms compatible with tularemia or had used drinking water\nfrom the same source as a previous case, and in whom _Francisella\ntularensis_ infection was confirmed by a laboratory test as described\nbelow. The cases were geographically scattered within each county,\ninvolving 13 different municipalities, and were not linked to one\ncommon source. In comparison, 7 cases were reported in total from\nother parts of the country in the same period. In 2009 and 2010 4 and\n8 cases respectively were reported from central Norway.\n\nTularemia is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium _F.\ntularensis_. 4 _F. tularensis_ subspecies are recognized:\n_tularensis_, _holarctica_, _mediasiatica_ and _novicida_. In Europe,\nthe infection is due to subspecies _holarctica_, which causes in\ngeneral less severe disease than subspecies _tularensis_, which is\ncommon in North America. Several vectors may be involved in\ntransmitting the disease to humans, commonly rodents and hares, but\ninfection may also be transmitted via insect bites (1).\n\nSeveral clinical forms are recognised, with oropharyngeal and\nulceroglandular disease being the most common clinical presentations\nin Norway (2). Oropharyngeal disease is commonly associated with\ncontaminated food and water, while ulceroglandular forms are more\noften seen when there has been skin contact with infected animals or\nafter insect bites (3).\n\nOutbreaks of oropharyngeal tularemia have previously been reported\nfrom several European countries (3,4). Tularemia is a notifiable\ndisease in Norway and during the past 10 years, 3 outbreaks were\nreported in Norway (5-7) and all were associated with water sources in\nareas where dead lemmings (_Lemmus lemmus_) had been observed\npreviously. From 2001 to 2010, between 3 and 66 cases of tularemia\nwere reported annually in the whole country, with an increase from 16\nto 32 cases on average (data available from http://www.msis.no).\nThis increase may in part be explained by the outbreaks mentioned\nabove.\n\nDiagnosis and clinical presentation\n-----------------------------------\nIn the outbreak described here, the most common clinical presentation\nwas fever and pharyngitis (oropharyngeal type, 21 cases) and cervical\nlymphadenopathy (glandular/ulceroglandular type, 10 cases). Among the\nremaining 8 tularemia cases, 2 were classified as respiratory and 2 as\ntyphoid type, while 3 were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case.\n\nThe diagnosis was primarily established by serology\n(microagglutination and an in-house IgG/IgM Elisa) in 30 patients (8),\nby _F. tularensis_ specific PCR analysis in seven patients (9) and by\nblood culture (BactAlert, BioMerieux) in 2 patients. The 2 bacterial\nisolates were verified as _F. tularensis_ by PCR and sequencing of the\n16S rDNA gene, and confirmed as non-subspecies _tularensis_ by pdpA\nPCR (10).\n\nOf the 39 diagnosed cases, 34 had been drinking water from a private\nwell or a stream. _F. tularensis_ DNA was detected by PCR in filtered\nwater from 5 different wells tested in Sor-Trondelag. 7 cases in 1\nmunicipality were linked to the same water source. Apart from that,\nonly 2 cases have been confirmed to share a common well so far.\nFollow-up serology has been recommended for several of the persons\nexposed to some of the putative water sources.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe current outbreak involves a large number of municipalities in 3\ncounties in central Norway. The clinical presentation with\noropharyngeal tularemia and cervical lymphadenopathy linked to the use\nof private wells in the winter season makes contaminated water the\nmost likely source of infection in this outbreak. Detection of _F.\ntularensis_ DNA by PCR analyses in some of the wells supports this\nassumption for some of the cases. Use of private wells is relatively\ncommon in rural areas of Norway although exact data on such use are\nnot available.\n\nThe precise mechanism of contamination of the wells with _F.\ntularensis_ is as yet unknown. However, November and December 2010\nwere unusually cold months, while in January 2011 temperatures\nincreased leading to melting of snow and possible contamination of\nprivate wells by surface water contaminated with bacteria from rodent\ncadavers or rodent excreta. Since the incubation period for tularemia\nmay be up to 3 weeks, and time from symptoms until seroconversion\nmight be up to 6 weeks, more cases may follow.\n\nTularemia has traditionally been called both 'lemming fever' and\n'hare plague' and this clearly indicates rodents and hares as\ntransmitters of disease. Years with a great increase in the rodent\npopulation are seen with intervals of about 3 to 4 years (11) and in\nthe summer and autumn of 2010, a high density of lemmings could be\nobserved in the southern and central parts of Norway. Simultaneously,\nthe Norwegian Veterinary Institute observed a wide geographical\ndistribution of fatal cases of tularemia in the mountain hare (_Lepus\ntimidus_) in these regions (12). The mountain hare is very susceptible\nto this infection and normally dies from septicemia within a few days\nafter exposure.\n\nThe use of small streams and private wells as a source of drinking\nwater and for other purposes in rural areas of Norway is a matter of\nconcern. In existing guidelines issued by the National Institute of\nPublic Health the population is advised to boil drinking water and\ninspect the wells for dead rodents in case of suspected or confirmed\ncases of waterborne tularemia. Every well owner should make the\nnecessary effort to prevent small rodents from entering the well water\nby carefully covering every opening and plugging every small hole\nwhere the rodents can enter. It is also important to secure the well\nfrom contamination by surface water after snow melting. In case of\nproven or suspected contaminated wells, the water should be\ndisinfected before further use. However, this may not be feasible for\npersons who use drinking water from a stream. The Norwegian Food\nSafety Authority has recently released information to the media and to\nthe general public with similar advice and information in relation to\nthe current outbreak. The local health authority in each municipality\nis responsible for instituting infection control measures including\nadvice to the public and investigations of the putative drinking water\nsources.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Available from\nhttp://www.vetinst.no/index.php/nor/Nyheter/Flere-tilfeller-av-harepest-i-Soer-Norge.\n\nReported by: Larssen KW 1/, Afset JE 1/2/, Heier BT 3/, Krogh T 4/,\nHandeland K 5/, Vik\u00f8ren T 5/, Bergh 1/,2/\n\n1/ Department of Microbiology, St Olavs Hospital, Trondheim\nUniversity Hospital,Trondheim, Norway\n2/ Department of Laboratory Medicine, Children\u2019s and Women\u2019s\nHealth, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim,\nNorway\n3/ Division of Infectious Disease Control, Norwegian Institute of\nPublic Health, Oslo, Norway\n4/ Division of Environmental Medicine, Norwegian Institute of Public\nHealth, Oslo, Norway\n5/Norwegian Veterinary Institute, Oslo, Norway\n\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Norway can be seen at\nhttp://www.questconnect.org/images/map_of_norway.png and\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0fRO. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Regarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nand an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Tikhenko NI, Efremenko VI, Omarieva E, et al: Outbreak of\ntularemia in the Republic of Dagestan. Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol\nImmunobiol. 2001; (6 Suppl): 68-72 (in Russian, abstract in English\navailable from http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12718181).\n2. Greco D, Allegrini G, Tizzi T, et al: A waterborne tularemia\noutbreak. Eur J Epidemiol. 1987; 3(1): 35-8 (abstract available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3582597).\n3. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al: An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol Immunobiol 1997; (2): 33-7 (in\nRussian, abstract in English available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9245138). - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia - Norway: (central) 20110225.0622\n2007\n----\nTularemia - Spain (03): (northern) 20071108.3626\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02) 20070813.2646\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir 20070811.2615\nTularemia, water-borne - Norway (North) 20070329.1081\n2006\n----\nTularemia - Sweden (Varmland) 20060927.2763\n2005\n----\nTularemia, hare hunters - Germany (Hessen) (02) 20051209.3548\nTularemia, hare hunters - Germany (Hessen) 20051203.3490\nTularemia - Russia (European) (02) 20050905.2621\n.................................................mpp/ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-01-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-04 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1045-08-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South - Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oslo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "- Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tuscany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Erikson U", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Smolensk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Trondheim", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prague", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "718029", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, imported - Germany: (Berlin) ex Turkey, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=718029", "date": "2011-04-01 10:21:33", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - NORWAY (02): (CENTRAL)\n**********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Mar 2011\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2011; 16(13) [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19828\n\n\nOutbreak of tularemia in central Norway, January to March 2011\n--------------------------------------------------------------\n>From January to March 2011, 39 cases of tularemia were diagnosed in 3\ncounties in central Norway: 21 cases of oropharyngeal type, 10 cases\nof glandular/ulceroglandular type, 2 of respiratory, and 2 of typhoid\ntype. 3 cases were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case. The mean age was 40.3 years (range 2-89\nyears). 34 reported use of drinking water from private wells. An\nincreased rodent (lemming) population and snow melting may have led to\ncontamination of the wells with infected rodents or rodent excreta.\n\nOutbreak description\n--------------------\n>From 1 Jan to 25 Mar 2011, 39 confirmed cases (16 female and 23 male)\nof tularemia were reported from the counties of Sor-Trondelag (28\ncases), More og Romsdal (5 cases), and Nord-Trondelag (6 cases) in\ncentral Norway. A confirmed case was defined as a person who had\nclinical symptoms compatible with tularemia or had used drinking water\nfrom the same source as a previous case, and in whom _Francisella\ntularensis_ infection was confirmed by a laboratory test as described\nbelow. The cases were geographically scattered within each county,\ninvolving 13 different municipalities, and were not linked to one\ncommon source. In comparison, 7 cases were reported in total from\nother parts of the country in the same period. In 2009 and 2010 4 and\n8 cases respectively were reported from central Norway.\n\nTularemia is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium _F.\ntularensis_. 4 _F. tularensis_ subspecies are recognized:\n_tularensis_, _holarctica_, _mediasiatica_ and _novicida_. In Europe,\nthe infection is due to subspecies _holarctica_, which causes in\ngeneral less severe disease than subspecies _tularensis_, which is\ncommon in North America. Several vectors may be involved in\ntransmitting the disease to humans, commonly rodents and hares, but\ninfection may also be transmitted via insect bites (1).\n\nSeveral clinical forms are recognised, with oropharyngeal and\nulceroglandular disease being the most common clinical presentations\nin Norway (2). Oropharyngeal disease is commonly associated with\ncontaminated food and water, while ulceroglandular forms are more\noften seen when there has been skin contact with infected animals or\nafter insect bites (3).\n\nOutbreaks of oropharyngeal tularemia have previously been reported\nfrom several European countries (3,4). Tularemia is a notifiable\ndisease in Norway and during the past 10 years, 3 outbreaks were\nreported in Norway (5-7) and all were associated with water sources in\nareas where dead lemmings (_Lemmus lemmus_) had been observed\npreviously. From 2001 to 2010, between 3 and 66 cases of tularemia\nwere reported annually in the whole country, with an increase from 16\nto 32 cases on average (data available from http://www.msis.no).\nThis increase may in part be explained by the outbreaks mentioned\nabove.\n\nDiagnosis and clinical presentation\n-----------------------------------\nIn the outbreak described here, the most common clinical presentation\nwas fever and pharyngitis (oropharyngeal type, 21 cases) and cervical\nlymphadenopathy (glandular/ulceroglandular type, 10 cases). Among the\nremaining 8 tularemia cases, 2 were classified as respiratory and 2 as\ntyphoid type, while 3 were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case.\n\nThe diagnosis was primarily established by serology\n(microagglutination and an in-house IgG/IgM Elisa) in 30 patients (8),\nby _F. tularensis_ specific PCR analysis in seven patients (9) and by\nblood culture (BactAlert, BioMerieux) in 2 patients. The 2 bacterial\nisolates were verified as _F. tularensis_ by PCR and sequencing of the\n16S rDNA gene, and confirmed as non-subspecies _tularensis_ by pdpA\nPCR (10).\n\nOf the 39 diagnosed cases, 34 had been drinking water from a private\nwell or a stream. _F. tularensis_ DNA was detected by PCR in filtered\nwater from 5 different wells tested in Sor-Trondelag. 7 cases in 1\nmunicipality were linked to the same water source. Apart from that,\nonly 2 cases have been confirmed to share a common well so far.\nFollow-up serology has been recommended for several of the persons\nexposed to some of the putative water sources.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe current outbreak involves a large number of municipalities in 3\ncounties in central Norway. The clinical presentation with\noropharyngeal tularemia and cervical lymphadenopathy linked to the use\nof private wells in the winter season makes contaminated water the\nmost likely source of infection in this outbreak. Detection of _F.\ntularensis_ DNA by PCR analyses in some of the wells supports this\nassumption for some of the cases. Use of private wells is relatively\ncommon in rural areas of Norway although exact data on such use are\nnot available.\n\nThe precise mechanism of contamination of the wells with _F.\ntularensis_ is as yet unknown. However, November and December 2010\nwere unusually cold months, while in January 2011 temperatures\nincreased leading to melting of snow and possible contamination of\nprivate wells by surface water contaminated with bacteria from rodent\ncadavers or rodent excreta. Since the incubation period for tularemia\nmay be up to 3 weeks, and time from symptoms until seroconversion\nmight be up to 6 weeks, more cases may follow.\n\nTularemia has traditionally been called both 'lemming fever' and\n'hare plague' and this clearly indicates rodents and hares as\ntransmitters of disease. Years with a great increase in the rodent\npopulation are seen with intervals of about 3 to 4 years (11) and in\nthe summer and autumn of 2010, a high density of lemmings could be\nobserved in the southern and central parts of Norway. Simultaneously,\nthe Norwegian Veterinary Institute observed a wide geographical\ndistribution of fatal cases of tularemia in the mountain hare (_Lepus\ntimidus_) in these regions (12). The mountain hare is very susceptible\nto this infection and normally dies from septicemia within a few days\nafter exposure.\n\nThe use of small streams and private wells as a source of drinking\nwater and for other purposes in rural areas of Norway is a matter of\nconcern. In existing guidelines issued by the National Institute of\nPublic Health the population is advised to boil drinking water and\ninspect the wells for dead rodents in case of suspected or confirmed\ncases of waterborne tularemia. Every well owner should make the\nnecessary effort to prevent small rodents from entering the well water\nby carefully covering every opening and plugging every small hole\nwhere the rodents can enter. It is also important to secure the well\nfrom contamination by surface water after snow melting. In case of\nproven or suspected contaminated wells, the water should be\ndisinfected before further use. However, this may not be feasible for\npersons who use drinking water from a stream. The Norwegian Food\nSafety Authority has recently released information to the media and to\nthe general public with similar advice and information in relation to\nthe current outbreak. The local health authority in each municipality\nis responsible for instituting infection control measures including\nadvice to the public and investigations of the putative drinking water\nsources.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. World Health Organization (WHO) Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and\nResponse: WHO guidelines on tularaemia. Geneva: WHO; 2007. Available\nfrom\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/WHO_CDS_EPR_2007_7.pdf.\n2. Brantsaeter AB: Twenty-five years of tularaemia in Norway,\n1978-2002. Abstract number: 10.1111/j.1198-743X.2004.902_o142.x.\nEuropean Society of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases.\n14th European Congress of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious\nDiseases. Prague; 1-4 May 2004. [Available from\nhttp://www.blackwellpublishing.com/eccmid14/abstract.asp?id=13879].\n3. Tarnvik A, Priebe HS, Grunow R: Tularaemia in Europe: an\nepidemiological overview. Scand J Infect Dis. 2004; 36(5): 350-5.\n[Abstract available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15287379].\n4. Willke A, Meric M, Grunow R, et al: An outbreak of oropharyngeal\ntularaemia linked to natural spring water. J Med Microbiol. 2009;\n58(Pt 1): 112-6. [Available from\nhttp://jmm.sgmjournals.org/cgi/content/full/58/1/112].\n5. Rike HF, Vigerust A, Bergh K: Vannbarent utbrudd av tularemia\n(harepest) i Midtre Gauldal. [A waterborne outbreak of tularaemia in\nMidtre-Gauldal]. Norwegian Institute of Public Health. 27 Oct 2003.\nNorwegian. Available\nfrom\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=3165.\n7. Melien P, Holsdal RE. Tularemi i Meldal -- en vanskelig diagnose?\n[Tularaemia in Meldal- a difficult diagnosis?]. Norwegian Institute of\nPublic Health. 18 Mar 2008. Norwegian. Available from\nhttp://www.fhi.no/eway/default.aspx?pid=233&trg=Area_5626&MainArea_5661=5619:0:15,4427:1:0:0:::0:0&MainLeft_5619=5626:68396::1:5625:1:::0:0&Area_5626=5544:68400::1:5628:1:::0:0.\n8. Bevanger L, Maeland JA, Naess AI: Competitive enzyme immunoassay\nfor antibodies to a 43 000-molecular-weight _Francisella tularensis_\nouter membrane protein in the diagnosis of tularemia. J Clin\nMicrobiol. 1989; 27(5): 922-6. [Available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC267455].\n9. Sjostedt A, Erikson U, Berglund L, Tarnvik A: Detection of\n_Francisella tularensis_ in ulcers of patients with tularaemia by PCR.\nJ Clin Microbiol. 1997; 35(5): 1045-8. [Available from\nhttp://jcm.asm.org/cgi/content/abstract/35/5/1045].\n10. Tomaso H, Scholz HC, Neubauer H, et al: Real-time PCR using\nhybridization probes for the rapid and specific identification of\n_Francisella tularensis_ subspecies tularensis. Mol Cell Probes. 2007;\n21(1): 12-6. [Available from\nhttp://www.researchgate.net/publication/7281056_Development_of_a_real-time_PCR_assay_for_detection_and_quantification_of_Francisella_tularensis].\n11. Available from\nhttp://www.vetinst.no/index.php/nor/Nyheter/Flere-tilfeller-av-harepest-i-Soer-Norge.\n\nReported by: Larssen KW 1/, Afset JE 1/2/, Heier BT 3/, Krogh T 4/,\nHandeland K 5/, Vik\u00f8ren T 5/, Bergh 1/,2/\n\n1/ Department of Microbiology, St Olavs Hospital, Trondheim\nUniversity Hospital,Trondheim, Norway\n2/ Department of Laboratory Medicine, Children\u2019s and Women\u2019s\nHealth, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim,\nNorway\n3/ Division of Infectious Disease Control, Norwegian Institute of\nPublic Health, Oslo, Norway\n4/ Division of Environmental Medicine, Norwegian Institute of Public\nHealth, Oslo, Norway\n5/Norwegian Veterinary Institute, Oslo, Norway\n\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Norway can be seen at\nhttp://www.questconnect.org/images/map_of_norway.png and\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0fRO. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Regarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nand an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Spain (03): (northern) 20071108.3626\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02) 20070813.2646\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir 20070811.2615\nTularemia, water-borne - Norway (North) 20070329.1081\n2006\n----\nTularemia - Sweden (Varmland) 20060927.2763\n2005\n----\nTularemia, hare hunters - Germany (Hessen) (02) 20051209.3548\nTularemia, hare hunters - Germany (Hessen) 20051203.3490\nTularemia - Russia (European) (02) 20050905.2621\n.................................................mpp/ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-01-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-04 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1045-08-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South - Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oslo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "- Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tuscany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Erikson U", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Smolensk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Trondheim", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prague", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "689111", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Norway (02): (central)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=689111", "date": "2011-04-01 10:21:33", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - NORWAY (02): (CENTRAL)\n**********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Mar 2011\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2011; 16(13) [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19828\n\n\nOutbreak of tularemia in central Norway, January to March 2011\n--------------------------------------------------------------\n>From January to March 2011, 39 cases of tularemia were diagnosed in 3\ncounties in central Norway: 21 cases of oropharyngeal type, 10 cases\nof glandular/ulceroglandular type, 2 of respiratory, and 2 of typhoid\ntype. 3 cases were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case. The mean age was 40.3 years (range 2-89\nyears). 34 reported use of drinking water from private wells. An\nincreased rodent (lemming) population and snow melting may have led to\ncontamination of the wells with infected rodents or rodent excreta.\n\nOutbreak description\n--------------------\n>From 1 Jan to 25 Mar 2011, 39 confirmed cases (16 female and 23 male)\nof tularemia were reported from the counties of Sor-Trondelag (28\ncases), More og Romsdal (5 cases), and Nord-Trondelag (6 cases) in\ncentral Norway. A confirmed case was defined as a person who had\nclinical symptoms compatible with tularemia or had used drinking water\nfrom the same source as a previous case, and in whom _Francisella\ntularensis_ infection was confirmed by a laboratory test as described\nbelow. The cases were geographically scattered within each county,\ninvolving 13 different municipalities, and were not linked to one\ncommon source. In comparison, 7 cases were reported in total from\nother parts of the country in the same period. In 2009 and 2010 4 and\n8 cases respectively were reported from central Norway.\n\nTularemia is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium _F.\ntularensis_. 4 _F. tularensis_ subspecies are recognized:\n_tularensis_, _holarctica_, _mediasiatica_ and _novicida_. In Europe,\nthe infection is due to subspecies _holarctica_, which causes in\ngeneral less severe disease than subspecies _tularensis_, which is\ncommon in North America. Several vectors may be involved in\ntransmitting the disease to humans, commonly rodents and hares, but\ninfection may also be transmitted via insect bites (1).\n\nSeveral clinical forms are recognised, with oropharyngeal and\nulceroglandular disease being the most common clinical presentations\nin Norway (2). Oropharyngeal disease is commonly associated with\ncontaminated food and water, while ulceroglandular forms are more\noften seen when there has been skin contact with infected animals or\nafter insect bites (3).\n\nOutbreaks of oropharyngeal tularemia have previously been reported\nfrom several European countries (3,4). Tularemia is a notifiable\ndisease in Norway and during the past 10 years, 3 outbreaks were\nreported in Norway (5-7) and all were associated with water sources in\nareas where dead lemmings (_Lemmus lemmus_) had been observed\npreviously. From 2001 to 2010, between 3 and 66 cases of tularemia\nwere reported annually in the whole country, with an increase from 16\nto 32 cases on average (data available from http://www.msis.no).\nThis increase may in part be explained by the outbreaks mentioned\nabove.\n\nDiagnosis and clinical presentation\n-----------------------------------\nIn the outbreak described here, the most common clinical presentation\nwas fever and pharyngitis (oropharyngeal type, 21 cases) and cervical\nlymphadenopathy (glandular/ulceroglandular type, 10 cases). Among the\nremaining 8 tularemia cases, 2 were classified as respiratory and 2 as\ntyphoid type, while 3 were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case.\n\nThe diagnosis was primarily established by serology\n(microagglutination and an in-house IgG/IgM Elisa) in 30 patients (8),\nby _F. tularensis_ specific PCR analysis in seven patients (9) and by\nblood culture (BactAlert, BioMerieux) in 2 patients. The 2 bacterial\nisolates were verified as _F. tularensis_ by PCR and sequencing of the\n16S rDNA gene, and confirmed as non-subspecies _tularensis_ by pdpA\nPCR (10).\n\nOf the 39 diagnosed cases, 34 had been drinking water from a private\nwell or a stream. _F. tularensis_ DNA was detected by PCR in filtered\nwater from 5 different wells tested in Sor-Trondelag. 7 cases in 1\nmunicipality were linked to the same water source. Apart from that,\nonly 2 cases have been confirmed to share a common well so far.\nFollow-up serology has been recommended for several of the persons\nexposed to some of the putative water sources.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe current outbreak involves a large number of municipalities in 3\ncounties in central Norway. The clinical presentation with\noropharyngeal tularemia and cervical lymphadenopathy linked to the use\nof private wells in the winter season makes contaminated water the\nmost likely source of infection in this outbreak. Detection of _F.\ntularensis_ DNA by PCR analyses in some of the wells supports this\nassumption for some of the cases. Use of private wells is relatively\ncommon in rural areas of Norway although exact data on such use are\nnot available.\n\nThe precise mechanism of contamination of the wells with _F.\ntularensis_ is as yet unknown. However, November and December 2010\nwere unusually cold months, while in January 2011 temperatures\nincreased leading to melting of snow and possible contamination of\nprivate wells by surface water contaminated with bacteria from rodent\ncadavers or rodent excreta. Since the incubation period for tularemia\nmay be up to 3 weeks, and time from symptoms until seroconversion\nmight be up to 6 weeks, more cases may follow.\n\nTularemia has traditionally been called both 'lemming fever' and\n'hare plague' and this clearly indicates rodents and hares as\ntransmitters of disease. Years with a great increase in the rodent\npopulation are seen with intervals of about 3 to 4 years (11) and in\nthe summer and autumn of 2010, a high density of lemmings could be\nobserved in the southern and central parts of Norway. Simultaneously,\nthe Norwegian Veterinary Institute observed a wide geographical\ndistribution of fatal cases of tularemia in the mountain hare (_Lepus\ntimidus_) in these regions (12). The mountain hare is very susceptible\nto this infection and normally dies from septicemia within a few days\nafter exposure.\n\nThe use of small streams and private wells as a source of drinking\nwater and for other purposes in rural areas of Norway is a matter of\nconcern. In existing guidelines issued by the National Institute of\nPublic Health the population is advised to boil drinking water and\ninspect the wells for dead rodents in case of suspected or confirmed\ncases of waterborne tularemia. Every well owner should make the\nnecessary effort to prevent small rodents from entering the well water\nby carefully covering every opening and plugging every small hole\nwhere the rodents can enter. It is also important to secure the well\nfrom contamination by surface water after snow melting. In case of\nproven or suspected contaminated wells, the water should be\ndisinfected before further use. However, this may not be feasible for\npersons who use drinking water from a stream. The Norwegian Food\nSafety Authority has recently released information to the media and to\nthe general public with similar advice and information in relation to\nthe current outbreak. The local health authority in each municipality\nis responsible for instituting infection control measures including\nadvice to the public and investigations of the putative drinking water\nsources.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. World Health Organization (WHO) Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and\nResponse: WHO guidelines on tularaemia. Geneva: WHO; 2007. Available\nfrom\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/WHO_CDS_EPR_2007_7.pdf.\n2. Brantsaeter AB: Twenty-five years of tularaemia in Norway,\n1978-2002. Abstract number: 10.1111/j.1198-743X.2004.902_o142.x.\nEuropean Society of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases.\n14th European Congress of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious\nDiseases. Prague; 1-4 May 2004. [Available from\nhttp://www.blackwellpublishing.com/eccmid14/abstract.asp?id=13879].\n3. Tarnvik A, Priebe HS, Grunow R: Tularaemia in Europe: an\nepidemiological overview. Scand J Infect Dis. 2004; 36(5): 350-5.\n[Abstract available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15287379].\n4. [A waterborne outbreak of tularaemia in\nMidtre-Gauldal]. Norwegian Institute of Public Health. 27 Oct 2003.\nNorwegian. Available from\nhttp://www.vetinst.no/index.php/nor/Nyheter/Flere-tilfeller-av-harepest-i-Soer-Norge.\n\nReported by: Larssen KW 1/, Afset JE 1/2/, Heier BT 3/, Krogh T 4/,\nHandeland K 5/, Vik\u00f8ren T 5/, Bergh 1/,2/\n\n1/ Department of Microbiology, St Olavs Hospital, Trondheim\nUniversity Hospital,Trondheim, Norway\n2/ Department of Laboratory Medicine, Children\u2019s and Women\u2019s\nHealth, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim,\nNorway\n3/ Division of Infectious Disease Control, Norwegian Institute of\nPublic Health, Oslo, Norway\n4/ Division of Environmental Medicine, Norwegian Institute of Public\nHealth, Oslo, Norway\n5/Norwegian Veterinary Institute, Oslo, Norway\n\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Norway can be seen at\nhttp://www.questconnect.org/images/map_of_norway.png and\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0fRO. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Regarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nand an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol\nImmunobiol. 2001; (6 Suppl): 68-72 (in Russian, abstract in English\navailable from http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12718181).\n2. Greco D, Allegrini G, Tizzi T, et al: A waterborne tularemia\noutbreak. Eur J Epidemiol. 1987; 3(1): 35-8 (abstract available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3582597).\n3. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al: An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol Immunobiol 1997; (2): 33-7 (in\nRussian, abstract in English available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9245138). - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia - Norway: (central) 20110225.0622\n2007\n----\nTularemia - Spain (03): (northern) 20071108.3626\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02) 20070813.2646\nTularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir 20070811.2615\nTularemia, water-borne - Norway (North) 20070329.1081\n2006\n----\nTularemia - Sweden (Varmland) 20060927.2763\n2005\n----\nTularemia, hare hunters - Germany (Hessen) (02) 20051209.3548\nTularemia, hare hunters - Germany (Hessen) 20051203.3490\nTularemia - Russia (European) (02) 20050905.2621\n.................................................mpp/ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-01-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-04 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1045-08-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South - Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oslo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "- Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tuscany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Erikson U", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Smolensk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Trondheim", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prague", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "662587", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Norway: (central)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=662587", "date": "2009-08-10 18:00:25", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN - USA: (ALASKA), REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 Aug 2009\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\n<http://www.ktuu.com/Global/story.asp?S=10861604>\n\n\nTwo residents of Fairbanks, Alaska have been diagnosed with tularemia, a\npotentially fatal bacterial infection more commonly found in animals.\nAlaska Department of Fish and Game veterinarian Kimberlee Beckmen learned\nof the outbreak from state public health authorities late last week.\n\nThe disease can be transmitted to humans from snowshoe hares, and the hare\npopulation has been high in the interior. It's unclear how the Fairbanks\nresidents contracted it.\n\nBeckmen says people are usually infected through the skin by handling sick\nhares, but they can also get it when bitten by ticks, flies, or mosquitoes\nthat fed on sick hares.\n\nA Fish and Game spokeswoman says the Fairbanks patients were treated with\nantibiotics and are doing well.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as\nvoles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found\nin a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at\nlow temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter.\nAlthough hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be\ninfected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are\nimportant in its ecology. Humans become infected through a variety of\nmechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks,\ndeerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food\nor water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type of exposure will\ndictate the form of the disease manifestation with cutaneous exposures\nusually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms. The type of\ndisease in these Alaskan cases is not stated.\n\nProMED-mail posted an alert (20041008.2760, see below) in October 2004\nregarding hamsters from a Canadian pet distributor that were found to be\ninfected with type B tularemia as well. No human cases were reported.\n\nTularemia in humans is generally a rural disease and occurs naturally\nthroughout much of North America and Eurasia. The type B strain (_F.\ntularensis_ biogroup palearctica) is the dominant strain in Eurasia,\nwhereas both biogroups (type A is biogroup tularensis) are found in the\nUSA. Type A is said to be more virulent than type B.\n\nAlthough not generally transferable from person to person, the infectious\ndose of _F. tularensis_ is quite low, and the organism is listed among the\ncategory A bioterrorism agents.\n\nAccording to statistics from the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, during the period 2000-2006, a total of 873 cases of human\ntularemia were reported in the USA. In the same period, there were a total\nof only 3 cases reported in Alaska, with annual reports of no more than one\nper year, although the disease is likely underreported. See\n<http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/Surveillance/Tul_CasesbyState.html> for the\nfull table of number of cases reported each year by state, 2000-2006. The\nlargest numbers were from the south-central part of the USA, with Missouri\n(172), Arkansas (123), and Oklahoma (79) leading the list. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia, feline - USA (UT): alert, RFI 20090802.2719\nPlague, tularemia, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20090712.2494\nTularemia, feline, canine - USA (SD) 20090711.2481\nTularemia, rabbits - USA (02): (NM) 20090417.1458\nTularemia, rabbits - USA (NM) 20090415.1429\n2008\n---\nTularemia, human, feline - USA: (NV) 20080825.2652\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA: (NYC) 20080612.1863\n2007\n---\nTularemia - USA (UT, NJ) (05): UT 20070809.2590\nTularemia - USA (UT, NJ) 20070716.2283\nTularemia, lagomorphs - USA (NM) 20070622.2013\nTularemia, feline - USA (SD) 20070614.1938\nTularemia, feline - USA (CO) 20070524.1658\nTularemia, ovine - USA (ID) 20070428.1391\n2006\n---\nTularemia, humans, rabbits - USA (WY) 20061101.3122\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA (MA) 20060731.2115\nTularemia, rabbits - USA (TX) 20060601.1531\nTularemia - USA (TX) (03) 20060224.0607\nTularemia, rodents, humans - USA (TX) (02): background 20060222.0577\nTularemia - USA (TX) 20060216.0508\nTularemia - USA (NE) 20060103.0024\n2004\n---\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA (NYC)(04) 20041115.3081\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA (NYC) 20041110.3033\n1998\n---\nTularemia - USA (New York City) (03) 19980804.1490\nTularemia - USA (New York City): RFI 19980724.1405\n\n..................ll/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It's unclear how the Fairbanks\nresidents contracted it.\n\nBeckmen says people are usually infected through the skin by handling sick\nhares, but they can also get it when bitten by ticks, flies, or mosquitoes\nthat fed on sick hares.\n\nA Fish and Game spokeswoman says the Fairbanks patients were treated with\nantibiotics and are doing well.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as\nvoles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found\nin a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at\nlow temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter.\nAlthough hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be\ninfected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are\nimportant in its ecology. Humans become infected through a variety of\nmechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks,\ndeerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food\nor water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type of exposure will\ndictate the form of the disease manifestation with cutaneous exposures\nusually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms. The type of\ndisease in these Alaskan cases is not stated.\n\nProMED-mail posted an alert (20041008.2760, see below) in October 2004\nregarding hamsters from a Canadian pet distributor that were found to be\ninfected with type B tularemia as well. No human cases were reported.\n\nTularemia in humans is generally a rural disease and occurs naturally\nthroughout much of North America and Eurasia. The type B strain (_F.\ntularensis_ biogroup palearctica) is the dominant strain in Eurasia,\nwhereas both biogroups (type A is biogroup tularensis) are found in the\nUSA. Type A is said to be more virulent than type B.\n\nAlthough not generally transferable from person to person, the infectious\ndose of _F. tularensis_ is quite low, and the organism is listed among the\ncategory A bioterrorism agents.\n\nAccording to statistics from the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, during the period 2000-2006, a total of 873 cases of human\ntularemia were reported in the USA. In the same period, there were a total\nof only 3 cases reported in Alaska, with annual reports of no more than one\nper year, although the disease is likely underreported. See\n<http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/Surveillance/Tul_CasesbyState.html> for the\nfull table of number of cases reported each year by state, 2000-2006. The\nlargest numbers were from the south-central part of the USA, with Missouri\n(172), Arkansas (123), and Oklahoma (79) leading the list. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia, feline - USA (UT): alert, RFI 20090802.2719\nPlague, tularemia, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20090712.2494\nTularemia, feline, canine - USA (SD) 20090711.2481\nTularemia, rabbits - USA (02): (NM) 20090417.1458\nTularemia, rabbits - USA (NM) 20090415.1429\n2008\n---\nTularemia, human, feline - USA: (NV) 20080825.2652\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA: (NYC) 20080612.1863\n2007\n---\nTularemia - USA (UT, NJ) (05): UT 20070809.2590\nTularemia - USA (UT, NJ) 20070716.2283\nTularemia, lagomorphs - USA (NM) 20070622.2013\nTularemia, feline - USA (SD) 20070614.1938\nTularemia, feline - USA (CO) 20070524.1658\nTularemia, ovine - USA (ID) 20070428.1391\n2006\n---\nTularemia, humans, rabbits - USA (WY) 20061101.3122\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA (MA) 20060731.2115\nTularemia, rabbits - USA (TX) 20060601.1531\nTularemia - USA (TX) (03) 20060224.0607\nTularemia, rodents, humans - USA (TX) (02): background 20060222.0577\nTularemia - USA (TX) 20060216.0508\nTularemia - USA (NE) 20060103.0024\n2004\n---\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA (NYC)(04) 20041115.3081\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA (NYC) 20041110.3033\n1998\n---\nTularemia - USA (New York City) (03) 19980804.1490\nTularemia - USA (New York City): RFI 19980724.1405\n\n..................ll/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
