For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alaska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fairbanks", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "469107", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, animal - USA: (CO) feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=469107", "date": "2009-08-10 18:00:25", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN - USA: (ALASKA), REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 Aug 2009\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\n<http://www.ktuu.com/Global/story.asp?S=10861604>\n\n\nTwo residents of Fairbanks, Alaska have been diagnosed with tularemia, a\npotentially fatal bacterial infection more commonly found in animals.\nAlaska Department of Fish and Game veterinarian Kimberlee Beckmen learned\nof the outbreak from state public health authorities late last week.\n\nThe disease can be transmitted to humans from snowshoe hares, and the hare\npopulation has been high in the interior. It's unclear how the Fairbanks\nresidents contracted it.\n\nBeckmen says people are usually infected through the skin by handling sick\nhares, but they can also get it when bitten by ticks, flies, or mosquitoes\nthat fed on sick hares.\n\nA Fish and Game spokeswoman says the Fairbanks patients were treated with\nantibiotics and are doing well.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as\nvoles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found\nin a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at\nlow temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter.\nAlthough hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be\ninfected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are\nimportant in its ecology. Humans become infected through a variety of\nmechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks,\ndeerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food\nor water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type of exposure will\ndictate the form of the disease manifestation with cutaneous exposures\nusually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms. The type of\ndisease in these Alaskan cases is not stated.\n\nProMED-mail posted an alert (20041008.2760, see below) in October 2004\nregarding hamsters from a Canadian pet distributor that were found to be\ninfected with type B tularemia as well. No human cases were reported.\n\nTularemia in humans is generally a rural disease and occurs naturally\nthroughout much of North America and Eurasia. The type B strain (_F.\ntularensis_ biogroup palearctica) is the dominant strain in Eurasia,\nwhereas both biogroups (type A is biogroup tularensis) are found in the\nUSA. Type A is said to be more virulent than type B.\n\nAlthough not generally transferable from person to person, the infectious\ndose of _F. tularensis_ is quite low, and the organism is listed among the\ncategory A bioterrorism agents.\n\nAccording to statistics from the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, during the period 2000-2006, a total of 873 cases of human\ntularemia were reported in the USA. In the same period, there were a total\nof only 3 cases reported in Alaska, with annual reports of no more than one\nper year, although the disease is likely underreported. See\n<http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/Surveillance/Tul_CasesbyState.html> for the\nfull table of number of cases reported each year by state, 2000-2006. The\nlargest numbers were from the south-central part of the USA, with Missouri\n(172), Arkansas (123), and Oklahoma (79) leading the list. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia, feline - USA (UT): alert, RFI 20090802.2719\nPlague, tularemia, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20090712.2494\nTularemia, feline, canine - USA (SD) 20090711.2481\nTularemia, rabbits - USA (02): (NM) 20090417.1458\nTularemia, rabbits - USA (NM) 20090415.1429\n2008\n---\nTularemia, human, feline - USA: (NV) 20080825.2652\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA: (NYC) 20080612.1863\n2007\n---\nTularemia - USA (UT, NJ) (05): UT 20070809.2590\nTularemia - USA (UT, NJ) 20070716.2283\nTularemia, lagomorphs - USA (NM) 20070622.2013\nTularemia, feline - USA (SD) 20070614.1938\nTularemia, feline - USA (CO) 20070524.1658\nTularemia, ovine - USA (ID) 20070428.1391\n2006\n---\nTularemia, humans, rabbits - USA (WY) 20061101.3122\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA (MA) 20060731.2115\nTularemia, rabbits - USA (TX) 20060601.1531\nTularemia - USA (TX) (03) 20060224.0607\nTularemia, rodents, humans - USA (TX) (02): background 20060222.0577\nTularemia - USA (TX) 20060216.0508\nTularemia - USA (NE) 20060103.0024\n2004\n---\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA (NYC)(04) 20041115.3081\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA (NYC) 20041110.3033\n1998\n---\nTularemia - USA (New York City) (03) 19980804.1490\nTularemia - USA (New York City): RFI 19980724.1405\n\n..................ll/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It's unclear how the Fairbanks\nresidents contracted it.\n\nBeckmen says people are usually infected through the skin by handling sick\nhares, but they can also get it when bitten by ticks, flies, or mosquitoes\nthat fed on sick hares.\n\nA Fish and Game spokeswoman says the Fairbanks patients were treated with\nantibiotics and are doing well.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as\nvoles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found\nin a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at\nlow temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter.\nAlthough hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be\ninfected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are\nimportant in its ecology. Humans become infected through a variety of\nmechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks,\ndeerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food\nor water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type of exposure will\ndictate the form of the disease manifestation with cutaneous exposures\nusually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms. The type of\ndisease in these Alaskan cases is not stated.\n\nProMED-mail posted an alert (20041008.2760, see below) in October 2004\nregarding hamsters from a Canadian pet distributor that were found to be\ninfected with type B tularemia as well. No human cases were reported.\n\nTularemia in humans is generally a rural disease and occurs naturally\nthroughout much of North America and Eurasia. The type B strain (_F.\ntularensis_ biogroup palearctica) is the dominant strain in Eurasia,\nwhereas both biogroups (type A is biogroup tularensis) are found in the\nUSA. Type A is said to be more virulent than type B.\n\nAlthough not generally transferable from person to person, the infectious\ndose of _F. tularensis_ is quite low, and the organism is listed among the\ncategory A bioterrorism agents.\n\nAccording to statistics from the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, during the period 2000-2006, a total of 873 cases of human\ntularemia were reported in the USA. In the same period, there were a total\nof only 3 cases reported in Alaska, with annual reports of no more than one\nper year, although the disease is likely underreported. See\n<http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/Surveillance/Tul_CasesbyState.html> for the\nfull table of number of cases reported each year by state, 2000-2006. The\nlargest numbers were from the south-central part of the USA, with Missouri\n(172), Arkansas (123), and Oklahoma (79) leading the list. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia, feline - USA (UT): alert, RFI 20090802.2719\nPlague, tularemia, prairie dogs - USA (SD) 20090712.2494\nTularemia, feline, canine - USA (SD) 20090711.2481\nTularemia, rabbits - USA (02): (NM) 20090417.1458\nTularemia, rabbits - USA (NM) 20090415.1429\n2008\n---\nTularemia, human, feline - USA: (NV) 20080825.2652\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA: (NYC) 20080612.1863\n2007\n---\nTularemia - USA (UT, NJ) (05): UT 20070809.2590\nTularemia - USA (UT, NJ) 20070716.2283\nTularemia, lagomorphs - USA (NM) 20070622.2013\nTularemia, feline - USA (SD) 20070614.1938\nTularemia, feline - USA (CO) 20070524.1658\nTularemia, ovine - USA (ID) 20070428.1391\n2006\n---\nTularemia, humans, rabbits - USA (WY) 20061101.3122\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA (MA) 20060731.2115\nTularemia, rabbits - USA (TX) 20060601.1531\nTularemia - USA (TX) (03) 20060224.0607\nTularemia, rodents, humans - USA (TX) (02): background 20060222.0577\nTularemia - USA (TX) 20060216.0508\nTularemia - USA (NE) 20060103.0024\n2004\n---\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA (NYC)(04) 20041115.3081\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA (NYC) 20041110.3033\n1998\n---\nTularemia - USA (New York City) (03) 19980804.1490\nTularemia - USA (New York City): RFI 19980724.1405\n\n..................ll/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It's unclear how the Fairbanks\nresidents contracted it.\n\nBeckmen says people are usually infected through the skin by handling sick\nhares, but they can also get it when bitten by ticks, flies, or mosquitoes\nthat fed on sick hares.\n\nA Fish and Game spokeswoman says the Fairbanks patients were treated with\nantibiotics and are doing well.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as\nvoles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found\nin a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at\nlow temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter.\nAlthough hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be\ninfected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are\nimportant in its ecology. No human cases were reported.\n\nTularemia in humans is generally a rural disease and occurs naturally\nthroughout much of North America and Eurasia. The type B strain (_F.\ntularensis_ biogroup palearctica) is the dominant strain in Eurasia,\nwhereas both biogroups (type A is biogroup tularensis) are found in the\nUSA. Type A is said to be more virulent than type B.\n\nAlthough not generally transferable from person to person, the infectious\ndose of _F. tularensis_ is quite low, and the organism is listed among the\ncategory A bioterrorism agents.\n\nAccording to statistics from the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, during the period 2000-2006, a total of 873 cases of human\ntularemia were reported in the USA. BA] [edited]\n<http://www.mk.ru/blogs/idmk/2008/07/21/mk-daily/362939/>\n\n\nPhysicians from an infectious clinical hospital have reported the 1st\ncase of tularemia in Moscow in 2008. A 53-year-old Muscovite had\nacquired tularemia in Naro-Fominsk, a Moscow suburban area, where he\nwas on vacation in the country. For several days he fished and\ncollected mushrooms. Symptoms of the infection began on 26 Jun 2008\nwith fever and groin swelling. Self-treatment had no success.\n\nIn the hospital his illness was suspected as tularemia and the\ndiagnosis was confirmed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is endemic, not emerging, in the region, but is reported here\nbecause it is listed as a Schedule A potential bioterror agent. There\nis, of course, no suggestion that this case was due to bioterrorism.\nSee images of a case at:\n<http://www.newscientist.com/data/images/ns/cms/dn12960/dn12960-1_500.jpg>\n& of the causative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_ at:\n<http://www.lcusd.net/lchs/mewoldsen/Image15.jpg>\n- Mod.JW\n\nPeriodically tularemia is observed in the European part of Russia.\nThe most significant outbreak was recorded in 2005 in the Nizhny\nNovgorod, Voronezh, Moscow, and Vladimir regions. In total 334 people\nwere hospitalized with symptoms of tularemia. The disease was\nlaboratory confirmed in 128 cases -- see ProMED refs. below. - Mod.NP\n\nThe glandular (or ulceroglandular if an ulcer was present distally)\ntularemia may have been acquired from an exposure to a [wild] animal\n[such as a rabbit or hare] during his vacation, from [contaminated]\nwater, or via an arthropod bite.\n\nThe Moscow area can be found on a map at:\n<http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/europe/9909/14/moscow.explosion.03/russia.moscow.lg.jpg>\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2007\n----\nTularemia, hunter - Russia: (Amur) 20071207.3946\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky)(03) 20070910.2988\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky) 20070826.2804\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) (02) 20070316.0918\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) 20070314.0901\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) (02) 20070127.0362\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) 20070124.0317\n2005\n----\nTularemia - Russia (European) 20050831.2577\nTularemia - Russia (Nizhniy Novgorod) 20050824.2503\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) (02) 20050822.2467\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) 20050718.2066\nTularemia, hunters - Russia (Stavropol) 20050322.0825\nTularemia - Ukraine (Donetsk) 20050304.0663\n.........................ba/np/ll/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. BA] [edited]\n<http://www.mk.ru/blogs/idmk/2008/07/21/mk-daily/362939/>\n\n\nPhysicians from an infectious clinical hospital have reported the 1st\ncase of tularemia in Moscow in 2008. A 53-year-old Muscovite had\nacquired tularemia in Naro-Fominsk, a Moscow suburban area, where he\nwas on vacation in the country. For several days he fished and\ncollected mushrooms. Symptoms of the infection began on 26 Jun 2008\nwith fever and groin swelling. Self-treatment had no success.\n\nIn the hospital his illness was suspected as tularemia and the\ndiagnosis was confirmed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is endemic, not emerging, in the region, but is reported here\nbecause it is listed as a Schedule A potential bioterror agent. In total 334 people\nwere hospitalized with symptoms of tularemia. The disease was\nlaboratory confirmed in 128 cases -- see ProMED refs. below. - Mod.NP\n\nThe glandular (or ulceroglandular if an ulcer was present distally)\ntularemia may have been acquired from an exposure to a [wild] animal\n[such as a rabbit or hare] during his vacation, from [contaminated]\nwater, or via an arthropod bite.\n\nThe Moscow area can be found on a map at:\n<http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/europe/9909/14/moscow.explosion.03/russia.moscow.lg.jpg>\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2007\n----\nTularemia, hunter - Russia: (Amur) 20071207.3946\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky)(03) 20070910.2988\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky) 20070826.2804\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) (02) 20070316.0918\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) 20070314.0901\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) (02) 20070127.0362\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) 20070124.0317\n2005\n----\nTularemia - Russia (European) 20050831.2577\nTularemia - Russia (Nizhniy Novgorod) 20050824.2503\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) (02) 20050822.2467\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) 20050718.2066\nTularemia, hunters - Russia (Stavropol) 20050322.0825\nTularemia - Ukraine (Donetsk) 20050304.0663\n.........................ba/np/ll/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. BA] [edited]\n<http://www.mk.ru/blogs/idmk/2008/07/21/mk-daily/362939/>\n\n\nPhysicians from an infectious clinical hospital have reported the 1st\ncase of tularemia in Moscow in 2008. A 53-year-old Muscovite had\nacquired tularemia in Naro-Fominsk, a Moscow suburban area, where he\nwas on vacation in the country. For several days he fished and\ncollected mushrooms. Symptoms of the infection began on 26 Jun 2008\nwith fever and groin swelling. Self-treatment had no success.\n\nIn the hospital his illness was suspected as tularemia and the\ndiagnosis was confirmed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is endemic, not emerging, in the region, but is reported here\nbecause it is listed as a Schedule A potential bioterror agent. There\nis, of course, no suggestion that this case was due to bioterrorism.\nSee images of a case at:\n<http://www.newscientist.com/data/images/ns/cms/dn12960/dn12960-1_500.jpg>\n& of the causative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_ at:\n<http://www.lcusd.net/lchs/mewoldsen/Image15.jpg>\n- Mod.JW\n\nPeriodically tularemia is observed in the European part of Russia.\nThe most significant outbreak was recorded in 2005 in the Nizhny\nNovgorod, Voronezh, Moscow, and Vladimir regions. In total 334 people\nwere hospitalized with symptoms of tularemia. The disease was\nlaboratory confirmed in 128 cases -- see ProMED refs. below. - Mod.NP\n\nThe glandular (or ulceroglandular if an ulcer was present distally)\ntularemia may have been acquired from an exposure to a [wild] animal\n[such as a rabbit or hare] during his vacation, from [contaminated]\nwater, or via an arthropod bite.\n\nThe Moscow area can be found on a map at:\n<http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/europe/9909/14/moscow.explosion.03/russia.moscow.lg.jpg>\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2007\n----\nTularemia, hunter - Russia: (Amur) 20071207.3946\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky)(03) 20070910.2988\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky) 20070826.2804\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) (02) 20070316.0918\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) 20070314.0901\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) (02) 20070127.0362\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) 20070124.0317\n2005\n----\nTularemia - Russia (European) 20050831.2577\nTularemia - Russia (Nizhniy Novgorod) 20050824.2503\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) (02) 20050822.2467\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) 20050718.2066\nTularemia, hunters - Russia (Stavropol) 20050322.0825\nTularemia - Ukraine (Donetsk) 20050304.0663\n.........................ba/np/ll/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. BA] [edited]\n<http://www.mk.ru/blogs/idmk/2008/07/21/mk-daily/362939/>\n\n\nPhysicians from an infectious clinical hospital have reported the 1st\ncase of tularemia in Moscow in 2008. A 53-year-old Muscovite had\nacquired tularemia in Naro-Fominsk, a Moscow suburban area, where he\nwas on vacation in the country. For several days he fished and\ncollected mushrooms. Symptoms of the infection began on 26 Jun 2008\nwith fever and groin swelling. Self-treatment had no success.\n\nIn the hospital his illness was suspected as tularemia and the\ndiagnosis was confirmed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is endemic, not emerging, in the region, but is reported here\nbecause it is listed as a Schedule A potential bioterror agent. There\nis, of course, no suggestion that this case was due to bioterrorism.\nSee images of a case at:\n<http://www.newscientist.com/data/images/ns/cms/dn12960/dn12960-1_500.jpg>\n& of the causative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_ at:\n<http://www.lcusd.net/lchs/mewoldsen/Image15.jpg>\n- Mod.JW\n\nPeriodically tularemia is observed in the European part of Russia.\nThe most significant outbreak was recorded in 2005 in the Nizhny\nNovgorod, Voronezh, Moscow, and Vladimir regions. In total 334 people\nwere hospitalized with symptoms of tularemia. The disease was\nlaboratory confirmed in 128 cases -- see ProMED refs. below. - Mod.NP\n\nThe glandular (or ulceroglandular if an ulcer was present distally)\ntularemia may have been acquired from an exposure to a [wild] animal\n[such as a rabbit or hare] during his vacation, from [contaminated]\nwater, or via an arthropod bite.\n\nThe Moscow area can be found on a map at:\n<http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/europe/9909/14/moscow.explosion.03/russia.moscow.lg.jpg>\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2007\n----\nTularemia, hunter - Russia: (Amur) 20071207.3946\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky)(03) 20070910.2988\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky) 20070826.2804\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) (02) 20070316.0918\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) 20070314.0901\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) (02) 20070127.0362\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) 20070124.0317\n2005\n----\nTularemia - Russia (European) 20050831.2577\nTularemia - Russia (Nizhniy Novgorod) 20050824.2503\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) (02) 20050822.2467\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) 20050718.2066\nTularemia, hunters - Russia (Stavropol) 20050322.0825\nTularemia - Ukraine (Donetsk) 20050304.0663\n.........................ba/np/ll/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. BA] [edited]\n<http://www.mk.ru/blogs/idmk/2008/07/21/mk-daily/362939/>\n\n\nPhysicians from an infectious clinical hospital have reported the 1st\ncase of tularemia in Moscow in 2008. A 53-year-old Muscovite had\nacquired tularemia in Naro-Fominsk, a Moscow suburban area, where he\nwas on vacation in the country. For several days he fished and\ncollected mushrooms. Symptoms of the infection began on 26 Jun 2008\nwith fever and groin swelling. Self-treatment had no success.\n\nIn the hospital his illness was suspected as tularemia and the\ndiagnosis was confirmed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is endemic, not emerging, in the region, but is reported here\nbecause it is listed as a Schedule A potential bioterror agent. There\nis, of course, no suggestion that this case was due to bioterrorism.\nSee images of a case at:\n<http://www.newscientist.com/data/images/ns/cms/dn12960/dn12960-1_500.jpg>\n& of the causative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_ at:\n<http://www.lcusd.net/lchs/mewoldsen/Image15.jpg>\n- Mod.JW\n\nPeriodically tularemia is observed in the European part of Russia.\nThe most significant outbreak was recorded in 2005 in the Nizhny\nNovgorod, Voronezh, Moscow, and Vladimir regions. In total 334 people\nwere hospitalized with symptoms of tularemia. The disease was\nlaboratory confirmed in 128 cases -- see ProMED refs. below. - Mod.NP\n\nThe glandular (or ulceroglandular if an ulcer was present distally)\ntularemia may have been acquired from an exposure to a [wild] animal\n[such as a rabbit or hare] during his vacation, from [contaminated]\nwater, or via an arthropod bite.\n\nThe Moscow area can be found on a map at:\n<http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/europe/9909/14/moscow.explosion.03/russia.moscow.lg.jpg>\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2007\n----\nTularemia, hunter - Russia: (Amur) 20071207.3946\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky)(03) 20070910.2988\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky) 20070826.2804\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) (02) 20070316.0918\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) 20070314.0901\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) (02) 20070127.0362\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) 20070124.0317\n2005\n----\nTularemia - Russia (European) 20050831.2577\nTularemia - Russia (Nizhniy Novgorod) 20050824.2503\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) (02) 20050822.2467\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) 20050718.2066\nTularemia, hunters - Russia (Stavropol) 20050322.0825\nTularemia - Ukraine (Donetsk) 20050304.0663\n.........................ba/np/ll/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. There\nis, of course, no suggestion that this case was due to bioterrorism.\nSee images of a case at:\n<http://www.newscientist.com/data/images/ns/cms/dn12960/dn12960-1_500.jpg>\n& of the causative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_ at:\n<http://www.lcusd.net/lchs/mewoldsen/Image15.jpg>\n- Mod.JW\n\nPeriodically tularemia is observed in the European part of Russia.\nThe most significant outbreak was recorded in 2005 in the Nizhny\nNovgorod, Voronezh, Moscow, and Vladimir regions. In total 334 people\nwere hospitalized with symptoms of tularemia. The disease was\nlaboratory confirmed in 128 cases -- see ProMED refs. below. - Mod.NP\n\nThe glandular (or ulceroglandular if an ulcer was present distally)\ntularemia may have been acquired from an exposure to a [wild] animal\n[such as a rabbit or hare] during his vacation, from [contaminated]\nwater, or via an arthropod bite.\n\nThe Moscow area can be found on a map at:\n<http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/europe/9909/14/moscow.explosion.03/russia.moscow.lg.jpg>\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2007\n----\nTularemia, hunter - Russia: (Amur) 20071207.3946\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky)(03) 20070910.2988\nTularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky) 20070826.2804\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) (02) 20070316.0918\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) 20070314.0901\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) (02) 20070127.0362\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) 20070124.0317\n2005\n----\nTularemia - Russia (European) 20050831.2577\nTularemia - Russia (Nizhniy Novgorod) 20050824.2503\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) (02) 20050822.2467\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) 20050718.2066\nTularemia, hunters - Russia (Stavropol) 20050322.0825\nTularemia - Ukraine (Donetsk) 20050304.0663\n.........................ba/np/ll/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Corr.ARS, edited]\n<http://www.nakanune.ru/news/2007/08/24/291400>\n\nAccording to the report of regional Rospotrebnadzor (Federal\nSupervision Agency for Customer Protection and Human Welfare), 7\ncases of tularemia were registered in the settlement of Berezovo from\n16 to 23 Aug 2007. Four cases have been confirmed by laboratory tests.\nA local authority has commissioned a plan for action to control the\nspread of infection. The movement of non-immunized people to the\nareas of risk is prohibited. Mass-information campaigns have been\nlaunched to deliver health and prevention information. A\nnon-scheduled immunization for tularemia has been planned. House\nvisits are being performed to identify sick people, to control rodent\ninvasion, and to supply repellents.\nNakanune reports that 191 884 people have received vaccine against\ntularemia during the last 6 years, 27 400 of them in 2006. During the\n6 months of 2007, 51.3 percent of the eligible population have\nreceived the vaccine.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n[Sporadic cases of tularemia are common in different regions of\nRussia, as the disease is endemic for all the country. Outbreaks,\nhowever, are emergent events, even if of local scale. The suspected\nroute of infection and the clinical form or forms are not given in this report.\nThe Khanti-Mansiysky Autonomous Okrug (also called Yugra) is located\non the West Siberian Plain. It is a part of the Tyumen Region. - Mod.NP/LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) (02) 20070316.0918\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) 20070314.0901\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) (02) 20070127.0362\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) 20070124.0317\n2005\n----\nTularemia - Russia (European) 20050831.2577\nTularemia - Russia (Nizhniy Novgorod) 20050824.2503\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) (02) 20050822.2467\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) 20050718.2066\nTularemia, hunters - Russia (Stavropol) 20050322.0825\nTularemia - Ukraine (Donetsk) 20050304.0663\n2003\n----\nTularemia, water-borne - Ukraine 20030808.1957\n2002\n----\nTularemia - Kosovo (02) 20020206.3498\nTularemia - Kosovo 20020118.3299\n..................................ll/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. A\nnon-scheduled immunization for tularemia has been planned. House\nvisits are being performed to identify sick people, to control rodent\ninvasion, and to supply repellents.\nNakanune reports that 191 884 people have received vaccine against\ntularemia during the last 6 years, 27 400 of them in 2006. During the\n6 months of 2007, 51.3 percent of the eligible population have\nreceived the vaccine.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n[Sporadic cases of tularemia are common in different regions of\nRussia, as the disease is endemic for all the country. Outbreaks,\nhowever, are emergent events, even if of local scale. The suspected\nroute of infection and the clinical form or forms are not given in this report.\nThe Khanti-Mansiysky Autonomous Okrug (also called Yugra) is located\non the West Siberian Plain. It is a part of the Tyumen Region. - Mod.NP/LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) (02) 20070316.0918\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) 20070314.0901\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) (02) 20070127.0362\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) 20070124.0317\n2005\n----\nTularemia - Russia (European) 20050831.2577\nTularemia - Russia (Nizhniy Novgorod) 20050824.2503\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) (02) 20050822.2467\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) 20050718.2066\nTularemia, hunters - Russia (Stavropol) 20050322.0825\nTularemia - Ukraine (Donetsk) 20050304.0663\n2003\n----\nTularemia, water-borne - Ukraine 20030808.1957\n2002\n----\nTularemia - Kosovo (02) 20020206.3498\nTularemia - Kosovo 20020118.3299\n..................................ll/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Corr.ARS, edited]\n<http://www.nakanune.ru/news/2007/08/24/291400>\n\nAccording to the report of regional Rospotrebnadzor (Federal\nSupervision Agency for Customer Protection and Human Welfare), 7\ncases of tularemia were registered in the settlement of Berezovo from\n16 to 23 Aug 2007. Four cases have been confirmed by laboratory tests.\nA local authority has commissioned a plan for action to control the\nspread of infection. The movement of non-immunized people to the\nareas of risk is prohibited. Mass-information campaigns have been\nlaunched to deliver health and prevention information. A\nnon-scheduled immunization for tularemia has been planned. House\nvisits are being performed to identify sick people, to control rodent\ninvasion, and to supply repellents.\nNakanune reports that 191 884 people have received vaccine against\ntularemia during the last 6 years, 27 400 of them in 2006. During the\n6 months of 2007, 51.3 percent of the eligible population have\nreceived the vaccine.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n[Sporadic cases of tularemia are common in different regions of\nRussia, as the disease is endemic for all the country. Outbreaks,\nhowever, are emergent events, even if of local scale. The suspected\nroute of infection and the clinical form or forms are not given in this report.\nThe Khanti-Mansiysky Autonomous Okrug (also called Yugra) is located\non the West Siberian Plain. Corr.ARS, edited]\n<http://www.nakanune.ru/news/2007/08/24/291400>\n\nAccording to the report of regional Rospotrebnadzor (Federal\nSupervision Agency for Customer Protection and Human Welfare), 7\ncases of tularemia were registered in the settlement of Berezovo from\n16 to 23 Aug 2007. Four cases have been confirmed by laboratory tests.\nA local authority has commissioned a plan for action to control the\nspread of infection. The movement of non-immunized people to the\nareas of risk is prohibited. Mass-information campaigns have been\nlaunched to deliver health and prevention information. A\nnon-scheduled immunization for tularemia has been planned. House\nvisits are being performed to identify sick people, to control rodent\ninvasion, and to supply repellents.\nNakanune reports that 191 884 people have received vaccine against\ntularemia during the last 6 years, 27 400 of them in 2006. During the\n6 months of 2007, 51.3 percent of the eligible population have\nreceived the vaccine.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n[Sporadic cases of tularemia are common in different regions of\nRussia, as the disease is endemic for all the country. Outbreaks,\nhowever, are emergent events, even if of local scale. The suspected\nroute of infection and the clinical form or forms are not given in this report.\nThe Khanti-Mansiysky Autonomous Okrug (also called Yugra) is located\non the West Siberian Plain. It is a part of the Tyumen Region. - Mod.NP/LL]\nSee Also\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) (02) 20070316.0918\nTularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) 20070314.0901\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) (02) 20070127.0362\nTularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy) 20070124.0317\n2005\n----\nTularemia - Russia (European) 20050831.2577\nTularemia - Russia (Nizhniy Novgorod) 20050824.2503\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) (02) 20050822.2467\nTularemia - Russia (Ryazan) 20050718.2066\nTularemia, hunters - Russia (Stavropol) 20050322.0825\nTularemia - Ukraine (Donetsk) 20050304.0663\n2003\n----\nTularemia, water-borne - Ukraine 20030808.1957\n2002\n----\nTularemia - Kosovo (02) 20020206.3498\nTularemia - Kosovo 20020118.3299\n..................................ll/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Stavropol", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Armenia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "22631", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=22631", "date": "2007-07-16 22:00:02", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (UTAH, NEW JERSEY)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1] Utah\nDate: Sat 14 Jul 2007\nSource: Deseretnews.com [edited]\n<http://deseretnews.com/dn/view/0,1249,685193576,00.html>\n\nSeveral people who mysteriously became sick after camping on the west\nside of Utah Lake might have contracted tularemia, officials at the\nUtah Department of Health said. While they are still awaiting lab\nconfirmation of the diagnosis, officials issued an advisory to avoid\ncontracting the infectious bacterium, which commonly causes fever and\nswollen lymph nodes. A treatable infection, tularemia usually spreads\nthrough tick and deerfly bites, but it also can be contracted through\nmosquitoes or by direct contact with an infected animal. Outdoor\nenthusiasts are advised to wear long, light-colored pants tucked into\nboots or socks and long-sleeved shirts, stay on marked trails, avoid\nwalking in tall grasses, use repellents containing DEET and avoid\ndirect contact with wild animals including their feces and carcasses.\nHealth officials advise those who believe they have infected bug\nbites to contact their physician or local health departments and\nmention tularemia. Treatments for the infection are different from\nthat typically used for skin infections.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Although the clinical manifestations in campers in the Utah outbreak\nare not described, they must have been characteristic enough of\ntularemia to warrant a presumptive diagnosis, pending laboratory\nconfirmation. Fever, chills, drenching sweats, muscle aches, malaise,\nnausea, vomiting, and weight loss usually appear 3 to 5 days after\nexposure to _Francisella tularensis_, but can take as long as 14\ndays. Other manifestations usually are specific for the mode of\ntransmission. For example, open painful sores develop where the\nbacteria entered the skin at the site of a scratch or abrasion,\nusually on the hands and fingers of hunters, or in the groin, axilla,\nand trunk in tick or deer fly-associated cases, accompanied by\nswollen, painful regional lymphadenopathy. A sore, inflamed throat\nand cervical swollen lymph nodes follow ingestion of undercooked\ninfected meat or contaminated water; abdominal pain, nausea,\nvomiting, diarrhea, and occasionally intestinal bleeding with swollen\nabdominal lymph nodes may also occur. Pneumonia may follow inhalation\nof infectious aerosols. Inhalation of an infectious aerosol is\nbelieved to be the mode of transmission if _F. tularensis_ were to be\nused as a bioweapon. A typhoidal type involves chills, high fever,\nand abdominal pain due to blood stream infection with _F. tularensis_\nin the absence of an ulcer or swollen lymph nodes. The animal source\nis usually an infected rodent or rabbit. Diagnosis is usually made on\nthe basis of positive cultures of blood or other infected material or\nserology.\nTularemia is usually treated with gentamicin or streptomycin for 7 to\n14 days, although other antibiotics, such as fluoroquinolones (e.g.,\nciprofloxacin or levofloxacin) or tetracyclines (minocyclne and\ndoxycycline) are also effective. If untreated, the overall death rate\nis 5-15 percent; less than one percent of appropriately treated\npatients die.\nUtah Lake is the largest natural freshwater lake in the state of Utah\n(see map of Utah at\n<http://www.enchantedlearning.com/usa/states/utah/>).\nWe await further reports from the Utah Department of Health on this\noutbreak. - Mod.ML]\n******\n[2] New Jersey\nDate: Sat 14 Jul 2007\nSource: Capemaycountyherald.com [edited]\n<http://www.capemaycountyherald.com/article/6917-tick-borne-illness-strikes-county-teenager>\n\nThe Cape May County Department of Health was notified on 12 Jul 2007\nthat a 14-year-old county resident has contracted tularemia, also\nknown as \"rabbit fever.\"\nTularemia is a rare, potentially serious illness caused by the\nbacterium _Francisella tularensis_, which occurs widely in nature and\ncan affect animals, particularly rodents and rabbits. Tularemia can\nbe acquired in multiple ways: such as being bitten by an infected\ntick; handling infected animal carcasses; eating or drinking\ncontaminated food or water; or inhaling the bacteria. The signs and\nsymptoms people develop depend on how they are exposed to tularemia.\nPossible symptoms include skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph\nglands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, diarrhea or\npneumonia. If the bacteria are inhaled, symptoms can include abrupt\nonset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry\ncough, and progressive weakness. Tularemia can be fatal if the person\nis not treated with appropriate antibiotics.\nTo minimize risk of infection, Kevin Thomas, health officer, advises\nresidents \"to cook food thoroughly and to drink water from a safe\nsource, use a DEET-containing insect repellent on the skin, and avoid\nhandling\nanimal carcasses. If contact with animal carcasses cannot be avoided,\npersons should wear gloves and wash hands thoroughly with soap and\nwater after removing gloves.\"\nFewer than 200 cases of tularemia are reported annually in the United\nStates, mainly in western and south central states. The last reported\nNew Jersey tularemia case occurred in September 2004 in a 31-year-old\nCape May County resident with extensive outdoor exposure history.\nNJDHSS is working closely with the New Jersey Department of\nEnvironmental Protection's (NJDEP) Division of Fish and Wildlife,\nwhich has not identified unusual animal die-off activity in the state\nto date.\nThe American dog tick and the Lone star tick, both found in Cape May\nCounty, are known to carry tularemia. To protect against all\ntick-borne disease, residents should follow these guidelines when\noutside with known ticks: Wear light-colored, tightly woven clothing\nto make it easier to spot ticks; tuck shirts into pants and pants\ninto socks; wear closed shoes/sneakers rather than open sandals. Use\na tick repellent as directed. Products should contain DEET (for\nclothing or skin) or Permethrin (for clothing only). Remind children\nto ask an adult to apply the tick repellent and do not apply to hands\nor face. Use products with less than 10 percent DEET, and always\nfollow manufacturers' directions carefully. Do not use repellents on\nchildren under 3 years of age. While outside, stay in the center of\ntrails, avoid low bushes and leafy brush, periodically check clothing\nand skin for ticks and remove. Once inside, check clothing, skin, and\nhair for ticks (take special note of a child's navel, underarm, groin\narea and behind the ears). If a tick is found, remove it carefully\nwith tweezers.\nInformation on tularemia is available at\n<http://www.state.nj.us/health/er/tularemia.shtml>,\nand information on tick-borne disease at\n<http://www.cmchealth.net>.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[The instructions on use of DEET in the news release above are\nsomewhat confusing. DEET, a broad-spectrum insect repellant, should\nbe applied to exposed, unbroken skin of adults and children, avoiding\nthe eyes and mouth (see\n<http://www.deet.com/content/htm/child.html>).\nThis is done by adults applying DEET to their hands and then\nspreading over exposed areas of the face and body of themselves and\nchildren. Do not allow children to apply the product themselves. Do\nnot apply to open wounds and scratches, and do not apply to the hands\nof small children, since they frequently put their hands into their\nmouths. Never spray DEET onto anyone's face, as it can cause eye\nirritation.\nThe higher the DEET concentration, the longer the hours of protection\nagainst insect bites, although concentrations exceeding about 30\npercent DEET offer little additional advantage. While several lower\nconcentrations of DEET formulations (20 percent-34 percent) offer 3-6\nhours of protection, an extended-release preparation of 35 percent\nDEET offers up to 12 hours of protection, (see\n<http://www.annals.org/cgi/content/full/128/11/931>).\nThe American Academy of Pediatrics found no difference in safety for\nchildren between products containing 10 percent and 30 percent DEET\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/westnile/qa/insect_repellent.htm>)\nwhen used as directed but is said to recommend that repellents used\non children should contain no more than 10 percent DEET\n(<http://www.annals.org/cgi/content/full/128/11/931>).\nThe insect repellent products that contain oil of lemon eucalyptus,\nnot DEET, should not be used on children less than 3 years of age.\nThe American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that repellents with\nDEET should not be used on infants less than 2 months old.\nDEET also can be applied to clothing made of natural fibers and nylon\nbut may destroy other synthetic fibers and plastic (such as eyeglass\nframes and watch crystals). Permethrin insect repellent can be\napplied to clothing, tents, sleeping bags, backpacks, mosquito\nnetting, etc., as directed (see\n<http://www.permethrin-repellent.com.permethrin-spray.htm>).\n- Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTularemia, lagamorphs - USA (NM) 20070622.2013\nTularemia, feline - USA (SD) 20070614.1938\nTularemia, feline - USA (CO) 20070524.1658\nTularemia, ovine - USA (ID) 20070428.1391\n2006\n----\nTularemia, humans, rabbits - USA (WY) 20061101.3122\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA (MA) 20060731.2115\nTularemia, rabbits - USA (TX) 20060601.1531\nTularemia - USA (TX) (03) 20060224.0607\nTularemia, rodents, humans - USA (TX) (02): background 20060222.0577\nTularemia - USA (TX) 20060216.0508\nTularemia - USA (NE) 20060103.0024\n.............................................ml/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cape May", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Permethrin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DEET", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "May County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "22359", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=22359", "date": "2007-07-16 22:00:02", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (UTAH, NEW JERSEY)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1] Utah\nDate: Sat 14 Jul 2007\nSource: Deseretnews.com [edited]\n<http://deseretnews.com/dn/view/0,1249,685193576,00.html>\n\nSeveral people who mysteriously became sick after camping on the west\nside of Utah Lake might have contracted tularemia, officials at the\nUtah Department of Health said. If untreated, the overall death rate\nis 5-15 percent; less than one percent of appropriately treated\npatients die.\nUtah Lake is the largest natural freshwater lake in the state of Utah\n(see map of Utah at\n<http://www.enchantedlearning.com/usa/states/utah/>).\nWe await further reports from the Utah Department of Health on this\noutbreak. - Mod.ML]\n******\n[2] New Jersey\nDate: Sat 14 Jul 2007\nSource: Capemaycountyherald.com [edited]\n<http://www.capemaycountyherald.com/article/6917-tick-borne-illness-strikes-county-teenager>\n\nThe Cape May County Department of Health was notified on 12 Jul 2007\nthat a 14-year-old county resident has contracted tularemia, also\nknown as \"rabbit fever.\"\nTularemia is a rare, potentially serious illness caused by the\nbacterium _Francisella tularensis_, which occurs widely in nature and\ncan affect animals, particularly rodents and rabbits. Tularemia can\nbe acquired in multiple ways: such as being bitten by an infected\ntick; handling infected animal carcasses; eating or drinking\ncontaminated food or water; or inhaling the bacteria. The signs and\nsymptoms people develop depend on how they are exposed to tularemia.\nPossible symptoms include skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph\nglands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, diarrhea or\npneumonia. If the bacteria are inhaled, symptoms can include abrupt\nonset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry\ncough, and progressive weakness. Tularemia can be fatal if the person\nis not treated with appropriate antibiotics.\nTo minimize risk of infection, Kevin Thomas, health officer, advises\nresidents \"to cook food thoroughly and to drink water from a safe\nsource, use a DEET-containing insect repellent on the skin, and avoid\nhandling\nanimal carcasses. If contact with animal carcasses cannot be avoided,\npersons should wear gloves and wash hands thoroughly with soap and\nwater after removing gloves.\"\nFewer than 200 cases of tularemia are reported annually in the United\nStates, mainly in western and south central states. The last reported\nNew Jersey tularemia case occurred in September 2004 in a 31-year-old\nCape May County resident with extensive outdoor exposure history.\nNJDHSS is working closely with the New Jersey Department of\nEnvironmental Protection's (NJDEP) Division of Fish and Wildlife,\nwhich has not identified unusual animal die-off activity in the state\nto date.\nThe American dog tick and the Lone star tick, both found in Cape May\nCounty, are known to carry tularemia. To protect against all\ntick-borne disease, residents should follow these guidelines when\noutside with known ticks: Wear light-colored, tightly woven clothing\nto make it easier to spot ticks; tuck shirts into pants and pants\ninto socks; wear closed shoes/sneakers rather than open sandals. Use\na tick repellent as directed. Products should contain DEET (for\nclothing or skin) or Permethrin (for clothing only). Remind children\nto ask an adult to apply the tick repellent and do not apply to hands\nor face. Use products with less than 10 percent DEET, and always\nfollow manufacturers' directions carefully. Do not use repellents on\nchildren under 3 years of age. While outside, stay in the center of\ntrails, avoid low bushes and leafy brush, periodically check clothing\nand skin for ticks and remove. Once inside, check clothing, skin, and\nhair for ticks (take special note of a child's navel, underarm, groin\narea and behind the ears). If a tick is found, remove it carefully\nwith tweezers.\nInformation on tularemia is available at\n<http://www.state.nj.us/health/er/tularemia.shtml>,\nand information on tick-borne disease at\n<http://www.cmchealth.net>.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[The instructions on use of DEET in the news release above are\nsomewhat confusing. DEET, a broad-spectrum insect repellant, should\nbe applied to exposed, unbroken skin of adults and children, avoiding\nthe eyes and mouth (see\n<http://www.deet.com/content/htm/child.html>).\nThis is done by adults applying DEET to their hands and then\nspreading over exposed areas of the face and body of themselves and\nchildren. Do not allow children to apply the product themselves. Do\nnot apply to open wounds and scratches, and do not apply to the hands\nof small children, since they frequently put their hands into their\nmouths. Never spray DEET onto anyone's face, as it can cause eye\nirritation.\nThe higher the DEET concentration, the longer the hours of protection\nagainst insect bites, although concentrations exceeding about 30\npercent DEET offer little additional advantage. While several lower\nconcentrations of DEET formulations (20 percent-34 percent) offer 3-6\nhours of protection, an extended-release preparation of 35 percent\nDEET offers up to 12 hours of protection, (see\n<http://www.annals.org/cgi/content/full/128/11/931>).\nThe American Academy of Pediatrics found no difference in safety for\nchildren between products containing 10 percent and 30 percent DEET\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/westnile/qa/insect_repellent.htm>)\nwhen used as directed but is said to recommend that repellents used\non children should contain no more than 10 percent DEET\n(<http://www.annals.org/cgi/content/full/128/11/931>).\nThe insect repellent products that contain oil of lemon eucalyptus,\nnot DEET, should not be used on children less than 3 years of age.\nThe American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that repellents with\nDEET should not be used on infants less than 2 months old.\nDEET also can be applied to clothing made of natural fibers and nylon\nbut may destroy other synthetic fibers and plastic (such as eyeglass\nframes and watch crystals). Permethrin insect repellent can be\napplied to clothing, tents, sleeping bags, backpacks, mosquito\nnetting, etc., as directed (see\n<http://www.permethrin-repellent.com.permethrin-spray.htm>).\n- Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTularemia, lagamorphs - USA (NM) 20070622.2013\nTularemia, feline - USA (SD) 20070614.1938\nTularemia, feline - USA (CO) 20070524.1658\nTularemia, ovine - USA (ID) 20070428.1391\n2006\n----\nTularemia, humans, rabbits - USA (WY) 20061101.3122\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA (MA) 20060731.2115\nTularemia, rabbits - USA (TX) 20060601.1531\nTularemia - USA (TX) (03) 20060224.0607\nTularemia, rodents, humans - USA (TX) (02): background 20060222.0577\nTularemia - USA (TX) 20060216.0508\nTularemia - USA (NE) 20060103.0024\n.............................................ml/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cape May", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Permethrin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DEET", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "May County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "22088", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (UT,NJ) (05): UT", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=22088", "date": "2007-07-16 22:00:02", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (UTAH, NEW JERSEY)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1] Utah\nDate: Sat 14 Jul 2007\nSource: Deseretnews.com [edited]\n<http://deseretnews.com/dn/view/0,1249,685193576,00.html>\n\nSeveral people who mysteriously became sick after camping on the west\nside of Utah Lake might have contracted tularemia, officials at the\nUtah Department of Health said. While they are still awaiting lab\nconfirmation of the diagnosis, officials issued an advisory to avoid\ncontracting the infectious bacterium, which commonly causes fever and\nswollen lymph nodes. A treatable infection, tularemia usually spreads\nthrough tick and deerfly bites, but it also can be contracted through\nmosquitoes or by direct contact with an infected animal. Outdoor\nenthusiasts are advised to wear long, light-colored pants tucked into\nboots or socks and long-sleeved shirts, stay on marked trails, avoid\nwalking in tall grasses, use repellents containing DEET and avoid\ndirect contact with wild animals including their feces and carcasses.\nHealth officials advise those who believe they have infected bug\nbites to contact their physician or local health departments and\nmention tularemia. Treatments for the infection are different from\nthat typically used for skin infections.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Although the clinical manifestations in campers in the Utah outbreak\nare not described, they must have been characteristic enough of\ntularemia to warrant a presumptive diagnosis, pending laboratory\nconfirmation. Fever, chills, drenching sweats, muscle aches, malaise,\nnausea, vomiting, and weight loss usually appear 3 to 5 days after\nexposure to _Francisella tularensis_, but can take as long as 14\ndays. Other manifestations usually are specific for the mode of\ntransmission. For example, open painful sores develop where the\nbacteria entered the skin at the site of a scratch or abrasion,\nusually on the hands and fingers of hunters, or in the groin, axilla,\nand trunk in tick or deer fly-associated cases, accompanied by\nswollen, painful regional lymphadenopathy. A sore, inflamed throat\nand cervical swollen lymph nodes follow ingestion of undercooked\ninfected meat or contaminated water; abdominal pain, nausea,\nvomiting, diarrhea, and occasionally intestinal bleeding with swollen\nabdominal lymph nodes may also occur. Pneumonia may follow inhalation\nof infectious aerosols. Inhalation of an infectious aerosol is\nbelieved to be the mode of transmission if _F. tularensis_ were to be\nused as a bioweapon. A typhoidal type involves chills, high fever,\nand abdominal pain due to blood stream infection with _F. tularensis_\nin the absence of an ulcer or swollen lymph nodes. The animal source\nis usually an infected rodent or rabbit. Diagnosis is usually made on\nthe basis of positive cultures of blood or other infected material or\nserology.\nTularemia is usually treated with gentamicin or streptomycin for 7 to\n14 days, although other antibiotics, such as fluoroquinolones (e.g.,\nciprofloxacin or levofloxacin) or tetracyclines (minocyclne and\ndoxycycline) are also effective. If untreated, the overall death rate\nis 5-15 percent; less than one percent of appropriately treated\npatients die.\nUtah Lake is the largest natural freshwater lake in the state of Utah\n(see map of Utah at\n<http://www.enchantedlearning.com/usa/states/utah/>).\nWe await further reports from the Utah Department of Health on this\noutbreak. - Mod.ML]\n******\n[2] New Jersey\nDate: Sat 14 Jul 2007\nSource: Capemaycountyherald.com [edited]\n<http://www.capemaycountyherald.com/article/6917-tick-borne-illness-strikes-county-teenager>\n\nThe Cape May County Department of Health was notified on 12 Jul 2007\nthat a 14-year-old county resident has contracted tularemia, also\nknown as \"rabbit fever.\"\nTularemia is a rare, potentially serious illness caused by the\nbacterium _Francisella tularensis_, which occurs widely in nature and\ncan affect animals, particularly rodents and rabbits. Tularemia can\nbe acquired in multiple ways: such as being bitten by an infected\ntick; handling infected animal carcasses; eating or drinking\ncontaminated food or water; or inhaling the bacteria. The signs and\nsymptoms people develop depend on how they are exposed to tularemia.\nPossible symptoms include skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph\nglands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, diarrhea or\npneumonia. If the bacteria are inhaled, symptoms can include abrupt\nonset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry\ncough, and progressive weakness. Tularemia can be fatal if the person\nis not treated with appropriate antibiotics.\nTo minimize risk of infection, Kevin Thomas, health officer, advises\nresidents \"to cook food thoroughly and to drink water from a safe\nsource, use a DEET-containing insect repellent on the skin, and avoid\nhandling\nanimal carcasses. If contact with animal carcasses cannot be avoided,\npersons should wear gloves and wash hands thoroughly with soap and\nwater after removing gloves.\"\nFewer than 200 cases of tularemia are reported annually in the United\nStates, mainly in western and south central states. The last reported\nNew Jersey tularemia case occurred in September 2004 in a 31-year-old\nCape May County resident with extensive outdoor exposure history.\nNJDHSS is working closely with the New Jersey Department of\nEnvironmental Protection's (NJDEP) Division of Fish and Wildlife,\nwhich has not identified unusual animal die-off activity in the state\nto date.\nThe American dog tick and the Lone star tick, both found in Cape May\nCounty, are known to carry tularemia. To protect against all\ntick-borne disease, residents should follow these guidelines when\noutside with known ticks: Wear light-colored, tightly woven clothing\nto make it easier to spot ticks; tuck shirts into pants and pants\ninto socks; wear closed shoes/sneakers rather than open sandals. Use\na tick repellent as directed. Products should contain DEET (for\nclothing or skin) or Permethrin (for clothing only). Remind children\nto ask an adult to apply the tick repellent and do not apply to hands\nor face. Use products with less than 10 percent DEET, and always\nfollow manufacturers' directions carefully. Do not use repellents on\nchildren under 3 years of age. While outside, stay in the center of\ntrails, avoid low bushes and leafy brush, periodically check clothing\nand skin for ticks and remove. Once inside, check clothing, skin, and\nhair for ticks (take special note of a child's navel, underarm, groin\narea and behind the ears). If a tick is found, remove it carefully\nwith tweezers.\nInformation on tularemia is available at\n<http://www.state.nj.us/health/er/tularemia.shtml>,\nand information on tick-borne disease at\n<http://www.cmchealth.net>.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[The instructions on use of DEET in the news release above are\nsomewhat confusing. DEET, a broad-spectrum insect repellant, should\nbe applied to exposed, unbroken skin of adults and children, avoiding\nthe eyes and mouth (see\n<http://www.deet.com/content/htm/child.html>).\nThis is done by adults applying DEET to their hands and then\nspreading over exposed areas of the face and body of themselves and\nchildren. Do not allow children to apply the product themselves. Do\nnot apply to open wounds and scratches, and do not apply to the hands\nof small children, since they frequently put their hands into their\nmouths. Never spray DEET onto anyone's face, as it can cause eye\nirritation.\nThe higher the DEET concentration, the longer the hours of protection\nagainst insect bites, although concentrations exceeding about 30\npercent DEET offer little additional advantage. While several lower\nconcentrations of DEET formulations (20 percent-34 percent) offer 3-6\nhours of protection, an extended-release preparation of 35 percent\nDEET offers up to 12 hours of protection, (see\n<http://www.annals.org/cgi/content/full/128/11/931>).\nThe American Academy of Pediatrics found no difference in safety for\nchildren between products containing 10 percent and 30 percent DEET\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/westnile/qa/insect_repellent.htm>)\nwhen used as directed but is said to recommend that repellents used\non children should contain no more than 10 percent DEET\n(<http://www.annals.org/cgi/content/full/128/11/931>).\nThe insect repellent products that contain oil of lemon eucalyptus,\nnot DEET, should not be used on children less than 3 years of age.\nThe American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that repellents with\nDEET should not be used on infants less than 2 months old.\nDEET also can be applied to clothing made of natural fibers and nylon\nbut may destroy other synthetic fibers and plastic (such as eyeglass\nframes and watch crystals). Permethrin insect repellent can be\napplied to clothing, tents, sleeping bags, backpacks, mosquito\nnetting, etc., as directed (see\n<http://www.permethrin-repellent.com.permethrin-spray.htm>).\n- Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTularemia, lagamorphs - USA (NM) 20070622.2013\nTularemia, feline - USA (SD) 20070614.1938\nTularemia, feline - USA (CO) 20070524.1658\nTularemia, ovine - USA (ID) 20070428.1391\n2006\n----\nTularemia, humans, rabbits - USA (WY) 20061101.3122\nTularemia, pneumonic - USA (MA) 20060731.2115\nTularemia, rabbits - USA (TX) 20060601.1531\nTularemia - USA (TX) (03) 20060224.0607\nTularemia, rodents, humans - USA (TX) (02): background 20060222.0577\nTularemia - USA (TX) 20060216.0508\nTularemia - USA (NE) 20060103.0024\n.............................................ml/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
